PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrage throughout Australia at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we citizens of Australia support a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support our call for a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines, give high priority to support for efforts to clear land mines in affected countries and use its influence to encourage other countries to financially support the clearance of land mines in poor countries.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Service: Higher Duties
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned federal Public Servants respectfully submit that:

The introduction of a Public Service Act regulation removing appeals against higher duties of 12 months or less has the potential to undermine the principle of selection on merit and the principle of an apolitical public service and lead to staffing decisions based on patronage and favouritism.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Disallow the Public Service Act regulation removing the aforesaid appeal right.

PETITION.TITLE: World Bank: Papua New Guinea
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned recognises that there is an urgent need for Papua New Guinea to address their economic ills. This needs to occur with the involvement of the people of that country so a model of development that is appropriate socially and environmentally is adopted.

Your petitioners request that the Senate should direct the executive director representing Australia at the World Bank, Mr Peter Nichols, work for the renegotiation of the Structural Adjustment Program that has been imposed on PNG, by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, with the support of the Australian government. Further we request that the National Coalition for Socio-Economic Justice, representing trade unions and community groups opposing the current SAPs, be consulted on adjustment measures advocated by the international finance institutions.

(1)That for the reasons, and bearing in mind the considerations, set out in paragraph (2), the Senate resolves and reaffirms that prior to the printing of a committee report a member or a group of members of the committee is not required to disclose to the committee any minority or dissenting report or any relevant conclusions and recommendations which the member or group of members proposes to add or attach to the report after it has been agreed to by the committee.

(c)the need to protect the integrity of the right of a minority group to dissent from the `agreed' report of a majority group; and

(d)the need to recognise that use of procedures, practices or guidelines designed in effect to make the majority report provisional until the minority report is seen and dissected by the majority group, completely undermines the right of a minority to express its dissent from the `agreed' report of a majority group.

PARA.TAB: (3)That, under the resolution of 13 February 1991, this resolution is an order of continuing effect.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—We agree to the passage of this motion which records the practice of the Senate as it has been in the past, in accordance with my understanding. I think it is worth putting on the record that that practice is very much to the advantage of a minority within a committee—in other words, those who wish to put down a minority report—in that the practice we have endorsed is that they have the right to do that after the majority have reached their position, and the majority have no opportunity to revisit their considerations after the minority have made their dissenting report. In fact, on the face of the motion, they have not even got the right to see the minority report before it is put down in this place.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, I think it needs to be said that those who wish to dissent should understand that in those terms it really is a privilege. In the negotiation of the majority report they should take into account that if they are in effect misleading their majority colleagues to a compromise majority report and then add a dissenting minority report, they are really being unfair. I think all of us should appreciate that as we endorse this practice and recognise that for it to work effectively it does require goodwill, good faith and cooperation within committees.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Faulkner, on behalf of Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:

Motion (by Senator Faulkner) agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the bill and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The EMDG scheme is recognised as contributing significantly to the enhancement of an export culture in this country.

Our potential and emerging exporters are by their nature often small businesses with limited experience and resources. The government wishes to provide some guidance to these exporters while limiting public expenditure where support is least likely to have a chance of success. To this end this bill introduces the framework for a flexible grants entry test.

The bill also reduces the maximum annual grant from $250,000 to $200,000, providing for fairer distribution of the available funding amongst small and medium exporters, whilst continuing to provide a substantial grant to the larger claimants.

The effective management of risk to the public purse, accountability of all participants and a transparency of operation, are considerations to which government financial assistance schemes must have high regard.

This bill addresses a number of matters associated with these considerations as they apply to the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974. The Australian National Audit Office, which undertook in 1993/94 an extensive effectiveness and efficiency audit of the scheme, made a number of recommendations on issues of risk management and accountability. Austrade, the agency responsible for the administration of the scheme, had already commenced enhancing procedures in a number of related areas. The audit office's recommendations gave further focus and emphasis to the upgrading process.

Raising the standard and accuracy of lodged claims benefits the client through faster processing and subsequent payment of grants, and benefits Austrade by facilitating the movement of resources away from routine administrative matters. By limiting the amount by which a claim for grant can be increased between the time of lodgement and its assessment, this bill reduces the scope for lodgement of ill prepared or ambit claims.

There is currently no limit to the number of EMDG approved Joint Venture and Consortium (AJVC) of which a "person" may be a member. As the EMDG scheme is focused on small to medium size business, it is considered that the resources of these organisations could not reasonably support involvement in more than a limited number of AJVC, and maintain focus. Further, the potential for individual organisations to receive very large amounts of EMDG funding through multiple membership is significant. AJVC have no automatic right to access the EMDG scheme, and are provided with EMDG claimant status against ministerially approved guidelines. To provide flexibility in establishing the optimal maximum number of AJVC membership, this bill provides for the limit to be set by ministerially approved guideline. Membership of a maximum of three AJVC is considered appropriate at this time.

Austrade has the power to cancel the status of an AJVC where it breaches the provisions of the act or ministerially approved guidelines, or specific conditions of its approval. However, regardless of the circumstances of the breach of conditions, Austrade does not have the power to deduct from a previously lodged but yet unassessed AJVC claim, the amount of grant generated by the breach of conditions. This bill allows that deduction.

Austrade is moving to minimise scope for fraudulent or dishonest behaviour under the EMDG scheme. Recent amendments prevent insolvent persons and persons convicted of certain offences from claiming EMDG. This bill excludes from eligibility claims prepared with the assistance of a consultant or other person convicted of fraud or dishonesty offences.

Whilst disclosure requirements under the EMDG scheme would severely inhibit lodgement of a claim for the promotion of an illegal activity, the EMDG act does not specifically prevent the payment of grant in respect of expenditure which is related to illegal activities. The bill formalises this implied limitation.

Finally, except in limited specified circumstances, an `in house' expense such as the salary of a claimant's Australian based employee, is not claimable under the scheme. The wording of the legislation, however, does not preclude such a payment where it is made to an interposed company which, to all intents and purposes is a payment to a person ordinarily employed in australia by the claimant. This bill renders payments in these circumstances, ineligible.
I commend this bill to honourable senators.

None of this comes as a surprise to any senator. I have talked about it at length to the whips. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement on this matter.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: HMAS Sydney

PARA.TAB: The government will not be opposing the motion we have before us today.
That does not mean that I believe a search for the whereabouts of HMAS Sydney should be a task for the Australian Defence Force.
However I do want to take some time to put the issue into some context.
The loss of HMAS Sydney with 645 personnel was the single greatest disaster to befall the Royal Australian Navy in wartime.
Clearly defence has a keen interest in the whereabouts of the wreck.
However, the fact is that while the general vicinity of the battle in which HMAS Sydney was lost is known, there is no firm information available as to the location of the vessel.
The lack of accurate information and the depth of water in the region makes searching for the hull extremely difficult.

A search for Sydney was made after it was realised that the ship could not be contacted and was overdue. While there was a delay between the time Sydney was due to return and the start of the search, the reasons for that delay simply are not known.
HMAS Moresby, the western based hydrographic ship, has in the past conducted sweeps of the area as well as checking various magnetic anomalies and underwater structures.
The navy has also conducted ad hoc searches as ships pass through the possible area of the engagement, and has investigated potentially favourable reports of sightings.
None have turned out to be the HMAS Sydney.

Given the technology of today, a search may be possible using a deep water search vessel fitted with sophisticated equipment. However, the search area would be so large that there could be no guarantee of success.
It is certainly not a task for the defence force.
Let me turn now to the circumstances surrounding the loss of HMAS Sydney.
The weight of historical fact clearly supports the theory that the Sydney was lost after engaging with the German vessel Kormoran.
There have been numerous conspiracy theories raised over the years. None with any foundation.
Some suggest that either a Japanese or Vichy French submarine was involved in the loss of Sydney.

There is simply no evidence to suggest the involvement of any third party in the loss of Sydney. Also, given the timings involved it is difficult to give any credence to why such vessels would be in the vicinity.

Speculation that signals from Sydney were received in HMAS Perth while the ship was in Port Phillip Bay are also unfounded. The only known signal which may have been transmitted from Sydney was a garbled message picked up by Geraldton radio. Records show that Perth was refitting in Sydney at that time.

There has also been much speculation surrounding the carley float found off Christmas Island. There is sufficient evidence to support the theory that the carley float was of Australian manufacture and possible from a naval vessel.
However, this in itself, does not justify claiming the float came from Sydney. The evidence available to date could support either case.
A second carley float was picked up in the waters off Western Australia by HMAS Heros, during the original search for Sydney.

This float is on display at the Australian War Memorial, where it recently underwent non-destructive scientific examination to ascertain whether there was evidence to indicate that the float had been machine gunned in the water.
Though evidence of battle damage was found there was no evidence to support the theory that the float had been machine gunned.

The possibility of the body buried on Christmas Island being that of a member of the ship's company of HMAS Sydney was also investigated back in 1949. Based on information then close at hand his investigation concluded that the body could not have come from HMAS Sydney.

Since then there has been no evidence produced which could overturn this finding. Unfortunately, given the passage of time and the paucity of records it is highly unlikely that the true identity of this individual will ever be known.
There is a body of opinion which suggests that the Defence Department has a secret vault of information and has been guilty of a massive coverup. Again that is simply not true.
Records which are over thirty years old may be accessed via the provisions of the archives act.
In conclusion let me say that even if the ship were to be found, many of the questions associated with its loss would still not be answered.

SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

This bill contains several important measures announced in the 1995 budget for the social security and veterans' affairs portfolios. The reforms will bring increased security and stability to customers while continuing the government's commitment to target assistance to those in our community who are most in need.

A common thread throughout these initiatives is the simplification of existing policy and the elimination of excessively bureaucratic procedures. It is true that the scope and complexity of the Australian social security system, placing as it does considerable demands on administrators, has sometimes created procedures and rules that confuse and frustrate people. The government has made it a priority in recent times to examine ways in which the system may be simplified and made more user friendly. That work continues, with this bill marking a further step.

One major initiative in this bill arises directly from the recommendations on the pension income and assets tests contained in the independently commissioned report "Targeting for Equity". The report was based on extensive consultations with pensioners, retirement community groups and industry groups who supported simple and more predictable means testing arrangements.

At present, there are many different and complex rules for assessing the income generated by financial investments. In some cases, the rules depend on when the investment was made. From 1 July 1996, all of these rules (including the rules for assessing unrealised capital growth on managed investments and shares) will be replaced with one set of rules for working out income from financial investments. These rules will apply to all social security and veterans' affairs pensions and allowances (with the exception of family payments).

These amendments build on the successful bank deeming measure. They respond to the concerns of pensioners themselves about the complexity of investment rules, the frequent changes caused to pension payments and the effect on incentives to earn more from investments. The new rules are simpler, fairer and more predictable, and will encourage people to maximise their resources.

The extended deeming rules will apply to bank, building society and credit union accounts, cash, term deposits, friendly society bonds and other managed investments, shares, loans and debentures. They will also apply to gifts of assets of more than the allowable limit. The rules will not apply to the principal home or its contents; cars, boats or caravans; antiques or stamp or coin collections; standard life insurance policies; or holiday homes, farms or other real estate. They also will not apply to income stream products such as superannuation pensions, allocated pensions, immediate annuities or allocated annuities.

Under extended deeming, the total value of a person's financial investments will be used to work out income from these investments. A deeming rate of 5 per cent will apply to the first $30,000 of the total for single people, to the first $50,000 (combined) for pensioner couples and to the first $25,000 for each member of a non-pensioner couple. A deeming rate of 7 per cent will apply to the value of investments over these thresholds.

The 5 per cent and 7 per cent deeming rates have been set so that they are easily achievable in safe investments. The deeming rates will be reviewed periodically to take into account movements in financial markets.

Importantly, people who earn more than the deeming rates will not have the extra counted as income and it will not reduce their payments. This significant change will encourage people to maximise their income.

The current rule assessing capital growth on certain managed investments when they are cashed in will be abolished from Royal Assent to this bill. This concession will allow people who wish to change their investments before July 1996 to do so, without their payments being adversely affected by past capital growth.

People will have plenty of time (until July 1996) to consider their situation and adjust their investments if they wish. They will be encouraged to use the free and significantly expanded Social Security Financial Information Service for information on whether they will be affected, and on the issues they could consider in making any investment changes. They could also get information from the National Information Centre on Retirement Investments, which has had its funding further increased in the 1995 budget.
The simplifying and customer oriented changes to the Pension Loans Scheme will give social security and veterans' affairs pensioners more say in when and how they receive their pensions.

The Pension Loans Scheme is a scheme under which the assets of a pensioner whose pension would otherwise be reduced because of the assets test are disregarded so that they no longer have any effect on the pension. The difference between what the pension is under the scheme and what it should be under the assets test is the "loan". In return, the pensioner incurs a debt of the difference in the pension plus a specified rate of interest, but the debt is not recoverable until after the pensioner's death. The loan is secured by the disregarded assets.

The Pension Loans Scheme will be made more attractive to age pensioners and their partners by relaxing or abolishing some of the current loan conditions. The fortnightly rate of the loan will be lifted to the maximum pension rate or a rate specified by the pensioner, whichever is the lower. Therefore, pensioners will be able to take maximum advantage of their assets under the scheme. However, to participate in the scheme, the pensioner would have to be entitled to some payment under either the income or assets test.

Participants in the scheme will become entitled to withdraw from the arrangement at any time. If they do so, either the loan could be repaid immediately or the debt could be left to be recovered after death, although it continues to accrue interest until it has been repaid.

To participate in the scheme, there is a current arbitrary rule that at least $100,000 must be left in a person's estate after the debt is repaid. This rule will be replaced with a new, more flexible one. Under the new rule, the pensioner may nominate a "guaranteed amount" to be left in the estate after the loan is repaid.

The asset types to be used as security by the commonwealth will now be limited to real estate. Also, the interest rate used in the Pension Loans Scheme will now be expressed in compound interest terms.

In recognition of the difficulties faced by many older unemployed people in the labour market, mature age allowance was introduced in 1994, with a sunset clause of June 1996,. There are over 37,000 mature age allowance recipients.

The mature age allowance regime has proven so effective in providing appropriate support for older disadvantaged workers that the government has decided to remove the sunset clause. At the same time, other simplifying changes are being made.

The current requirement that recipients have 12 months' CES registration will be replaced with a requirement that they have no recent workforce experience. People transferring to mature age allowance from unemployment payments will now have to have nine months', rather than 12 months', history on income support. People who lose entitlement to other payments such as carer pension and parenting allowance will not have to establish any particular period of income support history to transfer to mature age allowance.

Although recipients will not be required to look for work, they may do so if they wish. If they do so, they may register with the CES and receive labour market program assistance. The allowance will be payable under social security benefit conditions (including benefit income and assets tests), although it will continue to be based on pension rates and carry pension-type concessions. However, existing recipients will continue to be paid under pension conditions.

Another major change brought into effect by this bill is the streamlining of payments for unemployed people into a single system which will tailor administrative requirements according to people's individual needs and circumstances.

The current distinction between job search and newstart allowances is primarily based on CES registration for 12 months. This distinction once represented a move from one level of income support to a more active promotion of labour market and training opportunities. However, over the years, the distinction has become more blurred, with additional labour market help such as training programs and case management support now being based on the likelihood of becoming long term unemployed, rather than being in receipt of newstart allowance.

From September 1996, the current two-tiered system will be replaced by a single payment called newstart allowance which will be available to people regardless of their period of unemployment. The simplified system will be coupled with an earlier review process in an intensive effort to prevent people from joining the ranks of the long term unemployed.

There will be an intensive review of all those who have remained unemployed for nine months. Some of those will also be selected for an additional review. The existing three month review of all recipients will remain. This review will identify people at risk of becoming long term unemployed, so that they can be referred to appropriate services and assistance.

Furthermore, people whose job search efforts are already being closely monitored or who face particular hurdles such as age, will benefit from more flexible reporting requirements. Some people whose search for work is closely supervised via one-on-one case management will be given the option of submitting forms every four weeks. This option will also be available to people undertaking formal training, voluntary work or short courses. Anyone over 50 who is unemployed and is transferring to job search or newstart allowance after at least 12 months on a pension such as carer pension, will have the option of reporting every 12 weeks.

People to be offered the reduced reporting option will be carefully selected using a screening tool that will take into account factors such as age, length of time on income support, past record of compliance with reporting and other requirements and local labour market conditions. The measures will not relax the job search efforts required of unemployed people in return for their income support, but they will streamline those requirements.

People in rural and remote areas will also have the option of making individual arrangements with their regional office about how and when they lodge their forms. For example, this may include lodging forms when visiting services are available.

From March 1996, people receiving job search, newstart or youth training allowance who become temporarily incapacitated for work will no longer have to transfer to sickness allowance. Instead, they will remain on their usual allowance but will be exempt from job search activity while they are ill. People who become unemployed because of illness and those who suffer a potential loss of income due to illness will be paid the appropriate unemployment payment instead of sickness allowance. Sickness allowance will be paid only to those who will return to their jobs or study when they recover.

This measure makes much more sense administratively, and it will allow people who are ill to undertake part-time work if they are capable of it and to retain access to employment and education entry payments. They will also maintain continuity of unemployment history so that they are not disadvantaged later in relation to access to labour market programs, case management and job compact eligibility.

The allowance earnings credit scheme will be modified from March 1996 to eliminate some anomalies and to focus it more effectively on customers with casual or part-time earnings. An allowance recipient's earnings credit will accrue at a rate equal to the amount of the unused free area in any fortnight. The maximum amount of the earnings credit that can be used in any fortnight will be limited to $100.

Lastly, the bill also contains two Protocols that amend the international social security agreement between Australia and New Zealand. The first Protocol provides for amendments mainly of a technical nature, while the second Protocol enables people being paid under the agreement to leave their country of residence for short periods of time without losing entitlement to their pensions. It also provides for reimbursement by the country of origin to continue during these absences.

When negotiating the Protocols, it was Australia's objective to extend the temporary absence period for all pension types to 26 weeks (that is, not just for age pensions). New Zealand would not agree to this. We believe that 26 weeks is a fair period of time to allow for the continuation of pension payments for people moving temporarily between Australia and New Zealand. It is our intention to continue urging New Zealand to reconsider its position on this issue. Nevertheless the Protocols will improve the operation of the agreement for both countries.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.
VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (1995-96 BUDGET MEASURES) BILL (No. 2) 1995

This is the second Veterans' Affairs 1995-96 Budget Measures Bill. It gives effect to the remaining Government Budget initiatives that need legislation. Many of the measures in this bill address the particular needs of our older veterans, most of whom are now in their 70s and served in World War Two. In this year, while we have commemorated their achievements and sacrifices in that conflict, it is important that we continue to look at ways to improve our caring for their immediate and future needs.
The initiatives in this bill, and other related measures that do not require legislation, demonstrate once again that the Department of Veterans' Affairs is at the cutting edge of aged care.
Before I address the specific items in this bill, I want to mention some of the Government's 1995-96 Budget initiatives that do not require legislation.

First is the extension of the free advisory and referral services of the very successful Veterans' Home Maintenance Helpline. This Service will now be available to all veterans, war widows and war widowers. It provides a valuable support to those who own their own home, by providing advice on a broad range of matters, from replacing a fuse to installing a new bathroom. Wherever possible, the Helpline links the client to Government subsidised services.

The second valuable supporting initiative is the development of a program for discharge planning. This program will ensure appropriate care continues after an eligible veteran, war widow or war widower is discharged from hospital. The program recognises that attention to the special needs of patients in the post acute phase of an illness is important to their successful rehabilitation.

People who provide full time care for our veterans play an invaluable role. They allow many veterans to continue to live in their own home or in the community when they would otherwise be unable to manage. The carer's task is often a difficult one. The Department of Veterans' Affairs is continuing to look at ways to assist the carers. Recently the Minister for Veterans' Affairs launched a practical guide for carers of people with dementia. Other initiatives to provide practical assistance to carers are being developed.

Part of the support for those providing care in the veteran community is through the provision of carer service pensions. This bill includes a number of measures that extend access to carer service pensions, and it also puts into place a number of changes that reflect the needs and situations of many carers.

Carer service pensions are now available only to those who are caring for veterans who receive a service pension. The bill extends eligibility for a carer service pension to those who are caring for certain veterans who do not receive an income support payment from either the Department of Veterans' Affairs or the Department of Social Security. If the carer meets other, existing eligibility criteria, a carer service pension will become payable to a person providing care for a veteran whose family income is less than $61 020, with assets of less than $559 250. These limits will rise in line with increases in the family payment income and assets tests.

A similar extension of carer benefits will be made to war widows and war widowers who provide care for another person. These carers will be eligible for an income support supplement if the person under care does not receive a service pension from the Department of Veterans' Affairs or a pension or benefit from the Department of Social Security, but does meet the basic family payment income and assets tests.

The bill removes the current requirement that allows a carer service pension to be paid only where the carer lives in the same house as the person receiving care, or adjacent to that house. As long as the person provides the necessary level of care, it will not matter where the carer lives.

Another important Budget measure in this bill is the continuation of the carer service pension for 14 weeks after the veteran is admitted permanently to a nursing home or other institutionalised care. The carer service pension currently ceases as soon as the veteran permanently enters a nursing home. The continuation of the payment to the carer will allow that person time to adjust to changed responsibilities and to make arrangements for their future income and, possibly, a new place to live.

The bill ensures those receiving or providing community care are not financially disadvantaged by entering into that arrangement. If a person leaves their home to provide care for a veteran, the value of their home will be disregarded under the service pension assets test for two years. Similarly, if the veteran leaves his or her home to receive care in some other place in the community, the value of the veteran's home will not be included as an asset for two years. In addition, those leaving their home to provide or to receive care will be immediately eligible for rent assistance if they are paying rent for their new residence.
Mr President, in addition to the change in rent assistance I just mentioned, this bill contains a number of other rent assistance measures.

From March 1996, the maximum rates of rent assistance for families with children will be increased by $5 a fortnight. This increase reflects the higher cost often associated with renting private accommodation that meets the needs of families with children. The Government also recognises the extra costs incurred by a single pensioner raising a child and, in this bill, increases the rate of guardian allowance by $4 a fortnight.

The bill increases rent thresholds by $5 a fortnight to coincide with the March 1996 CPI increase. This increase ensures rent assistance continues to target pensioners who pay relatively higher rents.

There are currently a number of pensioners who retained eligibility for rent assistance, or for a beneficial rate of rent assistance, that they were receiving at the time of rent assistance reforms in 1989 and 1993. These people have continued to receive a higher rate of income support than others who are assessed under current provisions. The bill makes two specific provisions relating to these pensioners. First it ensures that those income support pensioners eligible for one of these retained rent assistance payments, who transfer back to the Department of Veterans' Affairs from the Department of Social Security, can continue to receive that payment. Second, the retained payments are to be gradually phased out. From March 1996, any CPI increase in the total service pension payments will be offset against those rent assistance payments until the total amount payable is equal to the total amount payable to others in the same circumstances. This change will achieve equity in income support payments without reducing the total amount paid to the pensioners.

The bill provides for the payment of a residential care allowance to certain pensioners in a nursing home or hostel. The allowance replaces any rent assistance now paid to these pensioners. It will be paid at the same rate and subject to the same threshold, indexation and all other provisions as are now applied to rent assistance.
Mr President, the bill also includes two measures to assist veterans and other income support beneficiaries under Veterans' Affairs legislation in the management of their living expenses.

The bill will allow certain specified classes of deductions to be made from service pensions at the request of the pensioner. This will allow payments, such as rent to government housing authorities, to be deducted and paid direct to the authority. This arrangement will provide a valuable service to veterans and other income support recipients, particularly our aged and infirm pensioners.

The second measure will allow certain service pensioners access to an advance of their pension of up to $500 to assist them to meet unexpected living expenses. The Government recognises that many service pensioners have limited cash reserves and can have difficulty obtaining access to lump sum amounts to help them meet costs associated with, say emergency repairs and replacements. The lump sum advance of pension will have no interest or other charges. Repayments will be at a level the pensioner can afford, and can be spread out over 6 months.

The Budget provided for an adjustment to be made to the bereavement payment to the partner of a person who was also receiving a war widow or war widower pension at the time of death. The adjustment removes the limitation on the amount of the war widow or war widower's income support pension from the calculation of the bereavement payment to the surviving partner. The bill gives effect to this adjustment within a major re-write of the Veterans' Affairs legislation relating to bereavement payments. This re-write includes some minor policy changes to remove superfluous provisions or to correct inconsistencies. The new provisions significantly simplify what had become very complex legislation.

The bill makes a number of minor changes to other acts. The Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 is to be changed as a consequence of the introduction of the residential care allowance, and the re-write of the bereavement payment provisions in this bill. That act will also include changes that follow on previous Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Acts. These changes include the introduction of income support supplement, and the repeal of the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940. There are also minor changes to the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Act 1986 as a result of the repeal of the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940. The Social Security Act 1991 is to be amended to incorporate a provision relating to rent assistance to social security pensioners or beneficiaries that is now included in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, but is being repealed.
In concluding, Mr President, I believe this bill provides sound and positive measures that respond to the changing needs of the veteran community.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

The purpose of this bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 (the Tariff Act) to incorporate into the Tariff Act Excise Tariff Proposals Nos. 1, 2 and 3 of 1995, which were tabled in the Parliament earlier in the year. In addition, this bill proposes to implement changes in the excise treatment of condensate and topped crude petroleum oil (topped crude).
The principal changes contained in the bill relate to:
(i)the exclusion of the rate of excise duty applicable to beer produced from "micro-breweries" and "U-brews" from indexation from 1 April 1994;
(ii)the increase in excise duty on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products by 10 per cent from 10 May 1995;
(iii)the amendment of the physical characteristics of fuel oil from 1 July 1995, to effectively remove "light" fuel oil from the concessional rate of excise applying to fuel oil;
(iv)an increase in the excise duty on aviation gasoline (avgas) and aviation kerosene (avtur) from 1 July 1995;

(v)the exemption of condensate from the application of the Tariff Act where it is separately produced, or separately marketed, from stabilized crude petroleum oil (stabilized oil) from 11 October 1995; and
(vi)the removal of the transport fuel substitution potential for topped crude from 11 October 1995.
(I)Exclusion of the rate of excise duty applicable to beer produced from "micro-breweries" and "U-brews" from indexation

Under section 6A of the Tariff Act, rates of excise duty set out in the Schedule to the Tariff Act may be subject to indexation in accordance with the Consumer Price Index on February 1 and August 1 of any year. Presently, specified rates of excise duty are not subject to indexation.

On 1 April 1994, beer produced from "micro-breweries" and "U-brews" was made excisable under the Tariff Act. Under the present provisions of section 6A, the rate of excise duty that applies to such beer is subject to indexation. However, this amounts to a double indexation of this rate of duty as this rate is directly linked to the rate of excise on commercially produced beer.
Clause 3 and Schedule 1 of the bill propose to amend section 6A of the Tariff Act to ensure that the rate of excise duty on beer produced from "micro-breweries" and
"U-brews" is not subject to indexation. This amendment is also proposed to take effect from 1 April 1994.
This amendment was proposed in Excise Tariff Proposal No. 1 of 1995, which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 8 February 1995 and took effect on and from 1 April 1994.
(II)Increase in excise duty on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products by 10 per cent

On Budget night, the Treasurer announced a 10 per cent increase in the rate of excise duty payable on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products with effect from 10 May 1995. While raising additional revenue, this measure also supports Government health policy that is aimed at discouraging smoking. As a consequence of this 10 per cent increase, it is also proposed to remove manufactured tobacco and tobacco products from the 5 per cent discretionary increase in excise duty which was due to take effect on 1 August 1995.
Clause 4 and Schedule 2 of the bill propose to amend the Tariff Act to implement these changes.
This amendment was proposed in Excise Tariff Proposal No. 2 of 1995, which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 9 May 1995 and took effect on and from
(III)Amendment of the physical characteristics of fuel oil from 1 July 1995, to effectively remove "light" fuel oil from the concessional rate of excise applying to fuel oil

On Budget night, the Treasurer also announced measures that were intended to close the revenue loophole allowing "light" fuel oil to be used as a substitute for diesel, especially in the transport area. "Light" fuel oil is excisable at the concessional rate of duty applying to fuel oil and diesel is excisable at a considerably higher rate of duty. It is proposed to amend the physical characteristics of fuel oil, as set out in subsection 3(4) of the Tariff Act, in order to exclude "light" fuel oil with effect from 1 July 1995.

The effect of this proposed amendment is that "light" fuel oil will no longer comply with the physical characteristics of fuel oil. As a result, "light" fuel oil will become excisable at the higher rate of duty applying the diesel fuel, thus removing the commercial incentive to continue to use "light" fuel oil as a transport fuel substitute for diesel.
Clause 5 and item 1 of Schedule 3 propose to amend the Tariff Act to implement this amendment.
This amendment was proposed in Excise Tariff Proposal No. 3 of 1995, which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 29 June 1995 and took effect on and from
1 July 1995.
(IV)Increase in the excise duty on aviation gasoline (avgas) and aviation kerosene (avtur)
Clause 5 and items 2 and 3 of Schedule 3 propose increases in the rates of excise duty payable on avgas and avtur with effect from 1 July 1995.
It is proposed to increase the rate of excise duty on avgas by 1.847 cents per litre.

Of this increase, 0.883 cents will contribute to funding air safety regulation, undertaken by the new Civil Aviation Safety Authority, that benefits the travelling public and, in part, aviation industry participants. The remaining increase of 0.964 cents per litre on avgas will recover part of the airways costs that are attributable to avgas powered aircraft.

It is also proposed to increase the excise duty on (avtur) by 0.883 cents per litre. As with avgas, this increase will contribute to funding air safety regulation that benefits the travelling public and, in part, aviation industry participants.
These increases were announced in the 1995-96 Budget and form part of the Government's continuing cost recovery strategy with respect to air safety regulation and the provision of airways services.
These amendments were also proposed in Excise Tariff Proposal No. 3 of 1995, which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 29 June 1995 and took effect on and from 1 July 1995.
(V)Exemption of condensate from the application of the Tariff Act where it is separately produced, or separately marketed, from stabilized crude petroleum oil (stabilized oil)
This bill also proposes to remove an unintended consequence of the Tariff Act with respect to condensate that is separately produced from stabilized oil.

With the first crude oil development soon to commence production from the North West Shelf Project area (which is now the only offshore area subject to the excise regime), small quantities of stabilized oil will be mixed with the condensate stream. It is not technically possible to remove all the stabilized oil from the natural gas/condensate stream.

Under subsection 5B(3) of the Tariff Act, where this mixture of condensate and stabilized oil is entered for home consumption, all the condensate will be deemed to be stabilized oil and excisable at the rate of excise under sub-item 17A. This is clearly not the intention of the policy first introduced in 1977 which was designed to encourage condensate production by giving condensate concessional excise treatment.

It is, therefore, proposed to create an exception to the operation of subsection 5B(3) in respect of condensate that is separately produced from stabilized oil. As a corollary to this, it is also proposed to make condensate that is separately produced, or separately marketed, from stabilized oil excise exempt. However, condensate that is for use as a fuel will continue to be excisable under other provisions of the Tariff Act as will condensate that is produced with, and entered as a mixture with, stabilized oil.
These amendments are contained in clause 6 and items 1, 2 and 4 of Schedule 4 to the bill and are to take effect from 11 October 1995.
(VI)Removal of the transport fuel substitution potential for topped crude

This bill proposes to increase the rate of excise duty payable on certain topped crude from its present concessional rate to the rate applying to diesel with effect from 11 October 1995. Presently, topped crude is excisable at the same concessional rate as fuel oil. Topped crude will continue to be excise free where it is for use as refinery feedstock. Topped crude which has the same characteristics as fuel oil as defined under subsection 3(4) of the Tariff Act will also continue to be excisable at the concessional rate applying to fuel oil.

This amendment is intended to remove a potential diesel fuel substitution problem with topped crude that exists due to the excise rate differentials between topped crude and diesel. This substitution problem is similar to the "light" fuel oil substitution, which has also been addressed by this bill, as it is possible for some topped crudes to be used as transport fuel substitutes for diesel fuel. Therefore, by increasing the excise duty payable on topped crude not having the characteristics of fuel oil to the same rate as diesel fuel, the commercial incentive to use topped crude as a substitute for diesel, particularly in the transport area, is removed.
This amendment is contained in clause 6 and item 3 of Schedule 4 to the bill.
(I)exclusion of the rate of excise duty applicable to beer produced from"micro-breweries" and "U-brews" from indexation
This amendment has no financial impact.
(II)increase in excise duty on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products
The increase by 10 per cent in the rate of excise duty on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products will result in an increase in revenue of $70 million in 1995-96 and $66 million in 1996-97.
(III)amendment of the physical characteristics of fuel oil to effectively exclude "light" fuel oil
The amendment to the Tariff Act in respect of the physical characteristics of fuel oil will result in an increase in revenue of $100 million in 1995-96 and $100 million in 1996-97.
(IV)increases in the excise duty on avgas and avtur

The increase of 1.847 cents per litre in the excise duty on avgas is balanced by an equivalent increase in the moneys appropriated to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and Air Services Australia. The financial impact is neutral.

The increase of 0.883 cents per litre in the excise duty on avtur is balanced by an equivalent increase in the moneys appropriated to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. The financial impact is neutral.
(V)amendments to the excise treatment of condensate
The amendments proposed to the excise treatment of condensate have no financial impact.
(VI)removal of the transport fuel substitution potential for topped crude

The amendment to eliminate the potential diesel fuel substitution problem with topped crude oil closes down a potential revenue drain of the same magnitude as the $100 million per annum "light" fuel oil revenue impact in paragraph (III) above.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present its explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill is aimed at increasing the flexibility of the operations of the Industry Commission, which is the government's major advisory body on industry matters, broadly defined.

The government values the major contribution of the Industry Commission as a catalyst for microeconomic reform in Australia. Its strengths are its independence, established expertise, public inquiry process, and economy-wide approach to examining issues.
The amendments contained in the bill are of a purely procedural nature, and involve three basic changes:
allowing Commissioners to be appointed on a part-time basis, including permanent part-time employment, in addition to the current full-time basis;
a consequential increase in the number of Commissioners, other than the Chairperson, from eight to eleven; and
allowing the progression of the Commission's public hearings in emergency situations, where one or more Commissioners may be unable to attend due to circumstances beyond their control.

The first basic change follows from the current provision in the Industry Commission Act 1989 which only allows Commissioners to be appointed on a full-time basis. The government has found that this provision limits its ability to attract a more diverse range of suitably qualified people. This change will allow the government to recruit those who hold other positions and are unwilling to become full-time Commissioners. Consequently the bill has been drafted to allow the appointment of Commissioners on either a full-time or a part-time basis, with equal powers.

The second basic change, of increasing the maximum number of Commissioners, necessarily follows the first. The Commission will need to maintain the same level of resources at the Commissioner level, thus requiring more Commissioners in total if there are to be part-time appointees.

The third basic change is intended to provide additional flexibility to the Commission in the conduct of its public hearings. Where one or more Commissioners on an inquiry are unable to attend a scheduled public hearing, due to unforeseen circumstances such as accident, illness or injury, the remaining Commissioner will be able to preside at the public hearings.
The remaining amendments are drafting changes consequential on the above proposed amendments.

The proposed amendments do not have any financial implications. However should the number and mix of full-time and part-time Commissioners increase beyond the present funding levels, an increase in funding will be sought through the normal budgetary processes.
This bill will allow the Commission greater flexibility in its operations, and increase its chances of attracting a more diverse range of suitably qualified people to the Commission.
I commend the bill to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time the debate was curtailed last night, I was speaking about the first of two unrelated tax bills; that is, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). I was mentioning that the Australian Taxation Office will have to fight out with academic linguists the definition about what is deductible, but the important thing is that they appear willing to have lime to reduce soil acidity included under section 75D(1B)(c).

PARA.TAB: To continue, the rest of the lack of clarity appears to be that there has been some confusion, at least at the level of farmers and some rural tax agents, about the deductibility of lime in fields to reduce acidity. Our amendment will clarify the situation, and hopefully Primary Industries and Energy will explicitly exclude in its future booklets the application of lime or other agents to reduce acidity or salinity.

While the ATO says our amendment makes no difference under law, there may be a financial impact from increased clarity. Any decrease in tax revenue should be weighed against the total impact of the benefits of soil improvement. The whole issue really came to my attention when farmers expressed some concern about the potential increase in the cost of lime due to the changes in the diesel rebate.

The application of lime is an agricultural practice, so diesel use in application is already rebatable. The entire cost of the operation, including materials, should be 100 per cent rebatable. Since the application is periodic rather than annual, choices can be made over a five- to 10-year time frame to allow farmers to maximise the benefits of a rebate. It is not a simple case of a required expense where rebates are worthless because there is no profit and no tax paid.

The Greens would love to do more and have supported increases to rebates for landcare of greater than 100 per cent. We have put them in budget requests and have supported such measures in the Senate. We also support other measures to reduce cost or provide positive benefits for landcare. But we hope we can get at the very least support from all members of the Senate on this simple request. I commend those amendments to the Senate.

I turn now to the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill. Fringe benefits and their taxation will always be a contentious issue, but I do not propose to review the inadequacies of the FBT law at this time. This late in the session I will confine myself to the major issues of this bill.

From our standpoint, a major issue has been and remains the cost of compliance in relation to the fringe benefits tax and other tax regimes. These costs generally are the result of two factors: the push for self-assessment and the refusal of the ATO to establish what are reasonable general costs of certain things so that massive documentation of the exact expense can be avoided.

I have spoken on the self-assessment issue several times. Basically, the push for self-assessment allows the ATO to avoid employing people to do an expert assessment by shifting that responsibility to the taxpayer. The ATO then employs people to check the taxpayer's assessment and then prosecutes if any mistakes are made. The taxpayer works under the assumption of knowledge under the law and any mistake is categorised as tax fraud, regardless of how confusing the tax laws are. I have had senior ATO staff in my office saying that some of the laws are so convoluted that they do not know what the laws mean.

If the ATO decides that the interpretation of a taxpayer is wrong, the taxpayer is stigmatised as a tax cheat and punished. They are not people who might want to work the system to their benefit, but there is this general assumption.

Other senators who deal regularly with taxation would certainly know of cases where the interpretations and rulings of the ATO are questionable. Several have been challenged in the AAT or in the courts. Others have also heard stories about how punitive and vindictive the ATO might be, sending businesses bankrupt during extensive court cases, which ultimately the taxpayer won, although the businesses had since been liquidated.

This whole situation creates an environment of suspicion, antagonism and vilification, one in which businesses especially operate in a miasma of justified fear lest they inevitably make some error. As a result, many businesses go to great lengths to try to comply with tax requirements. The more onerous those requirements are, the more time and cost are involved in compliance.

In terms of fringe benefits, the major issue is determining when an expense is required by the nature of the business and when it is part of a remuneration package. For example, when is accommodation reasonable to meet the requirements of the work and when is it unnecessarily luxurious, a fringe benefit to the employee?

It should be possible to sit down with industry to work out what a reasonable standard of accommodation is for various jobs and locations and then ask that the company show evidence that a trip was made—for example, cheque or credit card records of a flight booking—and verify that it was made for business purposes. A base level of accommodation and food costs should be assumed and verification required only for expenses above that level.

Might employees cheat, stay in a cheap dosshouse, eat peanut butter sandwiches and pocket the money saved? I suppose so. But if we assume that level of calculation by employees then, if forced to verify everything, they will go out to restaurants and ensure that they spend their allowance. The government or business will get nothing out of it. Businesses will have a vastly increased compliance cost in the need to collect, verify, process and store every receipt the employee gets.

Since there is a greater chance that some receipts will get lost, it will be difficult to obtain from employees a satisfactory receipt. There is a greater chance that employers will make a mistake or some claim based on a specific receipt may be interpreted as invalid. There is a much greater chance that the ATO will get a bit of extra money and the business be branded as tax cheats.

For us, the major impediment in this bill was the huge extra compliance costs involved in absolute justification and verification of each actual expense under the living away from home allowance. It seemed to me that it would have greatly increased the cost of compliance in time, useless effort and money, and with very little positive outcome. I am very pleased that the government has put forward amendments to delete its proposed living away from home compliance provisions.

With that change, I feel that the rest of the bill is basically acceptable. I understand there are a few amendments; for instance, in relation to taxis. The proposal is to extend the hours at which a taxi is considered a valid expense from 7.00 p.m. to 7.00 a.m., rather than from 8.00 p.m. to 8.00 a.m. That might well be reasonable. Most people do not start work before 8.00 a.m., and they finish by 6.00 p.m. It gets dark in winter before 6.00 p.m.

I do not think the amendment would make much difference. It would allow those asked to work overtime or at times when walking the streets may be dangerous to get transport. Perhaps during the committee stage the government, if it has problems with that in terms of the cost of the measure, will be able to give us further details.

If it will impose an extra cost on government, it might be small. If it opens the door for rorts, we need to know about that. How many people does the government expect will come in one or two hours early or stay one or two hours late, with the connivance of their employer, in order to get a non-FBT taxi ride? I guess it would be about the same number as those who come in before 6 o'clock to get a non-FBT taxi ride and spend an hour or so having breakfast before work or those who do an hour overtime and then go out for a drink while waiting for non-FBT taxi time to arrive. Of course, these people would also need the connivance of their employer.

Realistically, I do not think the number of people who go out of their way to get an FBT-free taxi ride is high, especially since their employer is paying for the taxi whether or not FBT is owing. I do not think the number of businesses that connive to convince employees to live out their lives so that the ATO can get cheated out of FBT is particularly high. Frankly, I think the ATO perception that everybody lives their lives with the sole goal of tax evasion may be somewhat paranoid. I can understand that it is necessary for them to protect revenue. It is equally necessary for the Senate to inject a bit of balance.

I understand the coalition will be putting amendments on the taxi issue and will also be putting amendments to index the $5 level in car parking to the CPI. The $5 level is the figure used to calculate car parks as a fringe benefit. I understand the government's argument that car parking costs do not generally vary gradually with the CPI, but the government has no method for determining how the costs do vary. This leaves a situation where more and more parking will be considered a fringe benefit, against the principle that it should represent a real advantage relative to the availability and cost of car parking for those not provided a place at work. Since the government suggests no mechanism for recognising real variation in cost, we will support the coalition measure as better than the existing situation.

I will digress briefly here to say that parking is a slightly strange situation, since many businesses are required by zoning ordinances to provide parking. They then must make employees pay, tell employees to park elsewhere, or pay FBT. We will also support the coalition change to the parking formula in item 4 of schedule 3.

If we multiply the 52 weeks in the year by five days a week, we get 260 working days. If we subtract the four weeks of annual leave, we are down to 240 days of government formula. If we subtract a further 12 days for state and federal public holidays, we are down to the 228 days in the coalition formula. This seems logical, since employees generally do get annual leave and public holidays.

People should know that the Greens are not in favour of encouraging more people to use cars and car parks. But, if you are proposing a formula in order to calculate what the real costs are, then the formula must be realistic. Most employees would probably use the parking less, since they would have at least one or two days sick leave. We will certainly look at these amendments and any other amendments during the committee stage to make fringe benefits tax more rational. Basically, we will support these bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering concurrently two tax measures: the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995. I am going to address my remarks to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995. The general outline and financial impact of that legislation is contained on page 1 of the explanatory memorandum. I do not intend to repeat that for honourable senators. It is there before them and obviously they have studied it.

PARA.TAB: But I do want to deal directly with a couple of matters of principle in this second reading debate, and I will be very brief. Taxation legislation is notoriously complex, as has been said around the chamber by I think almost every speaker. There is one aspect of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995 which deserves some consideration against the background of what principles should be applied in taxation laws. That aspect is the proposal to eliminate dividend rebates and franking credits where dividends are paid out of accounts such as share capital or share premium accounts.

The government has taken great pride, and rightly so, in abolishing the double taxation of dividends through the imputation system. Now, however, it is virtually turning its back on that because it is turning taxation of dividends on its head and is working on taxing repayment of capital as income. It is really quite bizarre that 10 years after capital gains tax was announced the government is still mucking around with the legislation because it cannot work out how to compute the cost base for shares where dividends have been declared in some form and various capital or asset accounts have been reduced.

I do not see how it is a neutral or equitable taxation system if, one month, a company pays $100,000 of a non-deductible amount as share capital in a subsidiary, and the next month, if for some reason—such as needing the money back—that $100,000 is returned as dividend in some form, the parent company then has to pay 36 per cent tax with no franking credit available. The amendments in part 2 of schedule 1 are really about capital gains tax and the appropriate cost base for shares after capital has been returned.

Instead of adjusting the cost base for capital gains tax, the Treasury and the Tax Office are tampering with the taxation of dividends. Instead of adjusting the capital gains tax cost base of shares directly, they have persuaded the government to make an attack on basic principles for the taxing of dividends. To my mind, this is a very serious matter because it strikes at the heart of taxing principles.

In the process, as has been pointed out in another place, the government is creating, no doubt unwittingly, considerable problems for Australian insurance companies, which must debit some of the so-called disqualifying accounts for company reporting reasons. The net result is that Australian insurance companies will now be disadvantaged as against overseas insurers who operate in Australia through branches or reinsurance arrangements and do not have to worry about rebatable dividends or franking credits.

The government should closely examine this measure. I invite Minister Cook to address three issues. If he does not do that in his response to the second reading debate—at the present time he appears to be otherwise engaged in having a discussion with his officials—I invite him to address those matters in greater detail in the committee stage.

Firstly, it appears wrong to attempt to correct a capital gains tax problem by undermining fundamental income tax principles against double taxation and against taxation of a return of capital. Secondly, as I have mentioned, this bill will put Australian insurers at a commercial disadvantage and push Australian insurance business offshore. I am not sure that we are being a very clever country or being very sensible in doing that. We already have a deficit problem with the balance of payments and a deficit on invisible exports such as services.

We had the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Senator McMullan, the Minister for Trade, in Osaka arguing for free trade in services such as insurance. Yet here we are being asked to do the opposite—unwittingly, it appears, through the misguided tax measures that handicap our insurance industry in the race to compete with offshore insurers. That is not the total result of this bill, but that is one of the results of this bill.

How can you on the one hand be acting as the Prime Minister and as Senator McMullan were in Osaka and on the other hand make it more difficult for Australian insurers to operate and give a free kick to international insurers? That is what you are doing here. It does not seem to be a sensible way of helping our balance of payments deficit.

Thirdly—and this is not unusual in taxation legislation—it may be that these so-called anti-capital gains tax avoidance measures will not work anyhow. It is not for me or any member of the Senate to suggest how they will not work. But at least the taxation officials or the minister should have a look for clues as to why it will not work. The clues may be found in an article published in the Canadian Tax Journal in the late 1970s. I have no doubt that taxation officials are well aware of that article. If they are not, they should be and they should take other measures than those that are now proposed to address the situation.

I do hope that the minister, if he is not able to respond to those matters in his second reading response—and I acknowledge that he was not here when I commenced my address—will address those matters in the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I apologise to the Senate, but last night I did mention I would be seeking to table a letter from the ATO, which I did circulate last night. I forgot at the end of my speech today to do that because of its jointed nature, so I am seeking leave to table it now.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is cognately debating two bills: the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995, which is an omnibus bill containing several measures to improve the tax act; and the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995.

PARA.TAB: There has been a range of senators participating in this debate. Trying to tally the list is a bit elusive, but it seems to me the sum comes out this way: taking the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), subject to my grasping in more detail the points raised by Senator Harradine, there is nonetheless broad approval for this bill in this chamber from the coalition and, as I understand it, also from the minor parties. Therefore, it seems to me that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) has the numbers and will pass, subject to what Senator Harradine has raised, which I will deal with in the committee stage but not now. I note that.
The Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995 does not have the numbers perfectly, if I tally the remarks and pay some due attention to the amendments that have been put forward.

Senator Gibson, on behalf of the coalition, has a series of amendments which he will no doubt move in the committee stage. The Australian Democrats have this morning put forward some amendments. The Greens have raised an issue and may seek to amend the bill also. I do not want to canvass all the arguments about that. It is more appropriate to do that when those amendments come before the chamber.

In congratulating those who have participated in this debate, I want to say that the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995 implements a package of measures that is designed to reduce FBT compliance costs for employers. These changes have been generally welcomed therefore, and not surprisingly, by employers. The government will be moving some amendments to this bill in the committee stage, and I foreshadow that now.

The main amendment that we will move will be to remove the proposed changes dealing with living away from home benefits. It is our contention that we should take that out of the bill. In this debate on the second reading stage, Senator Gibson asked me why the government is proposing to do this. After perusing the record of the debate, I think the senator set down a series of reasons why it should not be there and then asked why the government is removing it. His series of reasons have some resonance in our thinking. I say that without endorsing them. Nonetheless, we have had our ear cocked to public debate on this issue and want to reflect the will of that debate. It seems appropriate for us to remove those provisions, and thus do so. I formally advise that the main amendment which deals with the living away from home allowance acknowledges the substantial concerns expressed by industry groups about the effect of the present proposals and the effect that they might have on business. That is the reason for our changes.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995 will give effect to a number of 1995 budget proposals as well as some superannuation measures originally announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 18 June this year. I have made my general observations about that bill. At this stage of the debate I do not think it requires me to say anything more other than that it has been carried on in good heart by all participants. I congratulate them for that, while not necessarily agreeing with their views. I commend these bills to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before proceeding with the consideration of the bills in the committee, I wish to make a statement about the bills and the amendments. The three government amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill 1995 have been circulated in the form of requests for amendments. It is not clear why it is thought that the amendments should be in the form of requests, but it appears to be based on a theory about taxation bills which has been put forward during the inquiry by the Legal and Constitutional References Committee into the interpretation and application of section 53 of the constitution.

PARA.TAB: The committee will recall that in the context of certain taxation measures in 1993 there was a difference of opinion between the majority of the Senate and the government about the application of section 53 of the constitution to those measures. The government's advisers maintained that, although the measures increased the rates of various taxes, they did not impose taxation and could therefore be combined in one bill. Following this disagreement, the matter of the interpretation and application of section 53 of the constitution was referred to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee. The committee has not yet reported.

In the course of the committee's inquiry, a number of theories about section 53 have been put forward, particularly in relation to taxation bills. One of the theories put forward is that, where a bill does not impose taxation but a Senate amendment might have the effect of increasing the amount of taxation which would be collected by comparison with the terms of the bill, as distinct from the status quo applying in the absence of the bill, such an amendment should take the form of a request. This theory seems to be the basis of the amendments to this bill being circulated as requests. The bill is not a bill imposing taxation. But it has been suggested that the amendments might increase the amount of tax payable by comparison with the terms of the bill, although not by comparison with the status quo in the absence of the bill.

The Senate has not had an opportunity to consider the proper application of section 53 to taxation bills and has certainly not adopted this theory which is not in accord with past practice. It would, therefore, be premature for the committee to act as if this theory had been adopted. In any case, it is by no means clear that the amendments increase the amount of tax otherwise payable. The explanatory memorandum accompanying the amendments states that the financial impact of the amendments is nil. I therefore direct, subject to any contrary determination by the Senate, that the amendments are to be moved and determined as amendments rather than as requests.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move government amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Schedule 1, page 9, item 6, proposed subsection 51AEA(1), after "If a" insert "meal entertainment fringe benefit arises for a taxpayer for an FBT year and the".
(2)Schedule 1, page 9, item 6, proposed subsection 51AEA(1), omit "for an FBT year", substitute "for the FBT year".
(3)Schedule 2, pages 11 to 18, omit the Schedule.

Amendments Nos 1 and 2 concern the income tax deduction under the proposed new section 51AEA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 for employers who elect to use the fifty-fifty split method for calculating the taxable value of meal entertainment fringe benefits. As currently drafted, proposed new section 51AEA will allow any employer a deduction of 50 per cent of expenses for meal entertainment even though the employer does not incur any FBT liability in respect of the entertainment. This was never intended.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the fifty-fifty split method is to simplify calculations and record keeping requirements for employers who provide meal entertainment benefits to both employees and non-employees by providing a simple arbitrary method of apportionment of expenses between employees and non-employees. The amendments will confine the entitlement to a deduction under proposed new section 51AEA to employers who are provided meal entertainment fringe benefits. This will ensure that an employer is entitled to a deduction of 50 per cent of meal entertainment expenses only where an employer has incurred an FBT liability in relation to meal entertainment fringe benefits.

Amendment No. 3 removes the proposed living away from home provisions contained in schedule 2. Schedule 2 of the bill clarified the basis for dealing with the tax treatment of living away from home allowance benefits. A large number of submissions, as I said earlier, have been made to the government about the effect of this proposal. The government has decided to consider further the impact of these proposed changes on the basis of these submissions. For that reason, the government has decided not to proceed with the present proposals. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the government for moving these amendments. I commend to the Senate and to the Australian public the report by the Senate committee, which was largely written by my colleague Senator Watson. I think the quality of that report is showing. I congratulate the government for moving that way.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
