TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be supporting these amendments. We realise that the CPI indexing will lead to some pretty weird figures, but it is more appropriate for it to be indexed than to be left at a flat rate. The tax act is riddled with figures that should have been indexed. We should not allow that practice to continue. We should support these amendments.

—The Greens have already indicated that it might not be perfect but it is better than actually leaving it with no indication, which will mean we have to keep revisiting the Senate each time there needs to be an increase, which will obviously be a waste of everybody's time, so we will support the amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the amendments. The government's ears are open and hears all the other parties supporting them. We can count, so we know we will lose this. But for the record we oppose them because the amendments would index the $5 limit used to determine whether employer provided parking is subject to this fringe benefits tax.

PARA.TAB: These amendments are meant to allow the limit to reflect increases in the cost of car parking. That is a principle to which we have no objection. However, we do not believe the amendments will achieve that aim. That is the reason for our opposition. Indexing the $5 limit would involve small annual changes that cause odd figures like $5.16, for instance, to be used. That would add great complexity to an understanding of these provisions, in our submission. Most commercial car parking operations increase their fees irregularly by, say, $1 rather than by small annual increments. It would be simpler and more efficient to change the limit from time to time to reflect actual changes in car parking costs, which is what the government would propose to do.

We have here a great contest on a simple principle, which is about complexity and the best way of reflecting actual costs rather than using an index like the cost of living index, which may not reflect the actual costs incurred and introduce complexity in the act by throwing up odd numbers, making it more difficult for beneficiaries to interpret. Those are the reasons for our opposition.
Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment. The same comment applies: I see where the numbers are. Senator Margetts talked about logic. Perhaps I can explain the logic of the government's position and entice you, Senator Margetts, on the face of logic and evidence, to change your position. This is an argument about different figures—240 days, 228 days and the figure that Senator Kernot submitted, 230 days. So we are dickering around that point, which some observers of the debate might characterise as arguing about how many angels can dance on the head of a pin. But let us be precise about this because the logic underpinning it ought to be explained.

PARA.TAB: What the government has done in this bill is define business days. These are work days. You subtract from the total number of days a year, which is 365 days, the weekends. They are all out. We have also taken out public holidays. The business days are the days actually worked without weekends or public holidays included. The difference in our positions seems to me to relate to annual leave entitlements or recreation leave entitlements.

The illogicality of the opposition's position, if I may say so, is the presumption that a car parking space provided to a senior executive is vacant when that senior executive goes on annual leave. We know in industry that that is not the case. The provision of fringe benefits free car parking goes to senior executives and senior management of companies. We all drive into car parks and see the reserved general managers car park. That is what we are talking about.

When a key executive goes on annual leave that person is replaced, because of their strategic and administrative importance to that corporation, by somebody who then uses the car park. The benefit continues on. If one is trying to fairly work out what applies, you cannot reduce the number of days by the annual leave requirement, in our view. To do so is to give a benefit to senior executives or companies that employ senior executives who use this as a minor loophole.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sounds like double dipping to me.

—The fringe benefit applies to the user. The user may be the senior executive for whom it is reserved up until the time that senior executive goes on annual leave. The person who acts in their position while they are away then uses that car park so there is still a fringe benefit. For those reasons we think that our number of days properly expresses—
—Does only one person get a car park?

—I am getting a lot of background noise. Let me make my case for you and then I will move on. Our number of days properly expresses the principle. We reject the other numbers that have been calculated. I know where the numbers are, but we want our position on the record.
—There are a lot of firms where the minister's case really does not apply. A lot of firms actually close down for their annual leave in which case this should not apply. We stick by our amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Schedule 3, page 23, item 4, proposed section 39FC, omit the section, substitute the following section:
"'39FC. The daily rate amount for a space is the amount that would be worked out using whichever of the following methods that the taxpayer chooses:
(a)the commercial parking station method;

PARA.TAB: (b)the market value method;
(c)the average cost method;

SPEECH.PARA: as the taxable value of the car parking fringe benefit for the space, if there were no recipients contribution.".

I think there is a drafting error in the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill which resulted from the original announcement in February. The compliance package made it clear that the car parking fringe benefits compliance issue was to be addressed in two ways. The first was in relation to when FBT applies. The second was to provide three alternative methods for determining the number of parking benefits provided during the fringe benefits tax year. The announcement in February went on to make it clear that further options would be provided for the actual valuation of benefits—that is, the current lowest fee charged by the commercial operator method, the market value method or the value of the parking space determined by a value or new average cost based on the average of a nearby commercial parking stations.

PARA.TAB: While the option of the three valuation method was made available for two of the three methods of determining the number of parking benefits provided, the government provided only the average cost valuation method for the new statutory formula for the FBT calculation process. By seeking to redress that situation, this amendment gives taxpayers who are using the statutory formula the same choice of the three valuation methods as taxpayers using the other two formulas. This is what you intended to do in your February statement and I wonder why you did not do it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We accept the amendment. It does add another couple of options. I could talk about what that does overall, but there is no point in doing that. We accept the amendment.
—The coalition supports the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Schedule 4, page 44, item 2, proposed paragraph 58Z(1)(b), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:
"(b) commences between 7.00 p.m. and 7.00 a.m.".

This amendment seeks to set the time period for taxi travel limited between 7 p.m. and 7 a.m., as opposed to the government's 8 p.m. and 6 a.m. We think it is much more sensible and practical for employees to have the 7 o'clock time period.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens actually mentioned that we were inclined to support it, but we were interested in the government's comments. There are obviously implications, especially with deregulation of labour hours and so on in relation to the antisocial hours that people are expected to work more and more these days. So there is an implication in terms of employees, especially female employees, and the ability to safely get home if they are in an area where there are problems involved with this.

PARA.TAB: I will be interested to hear the government's comments in relation to usage, costs and any other problems associated with this. It seems to me it may be a reasonable assumption that certainly in winter these are times when it may be dark, and there may be a very good reason why it would be useful to allow this as a legitimate exception.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess we are being a bit arbitrary here—8 p.m. to 6 a.m., 7 p.m. to 7 a.m., sunrise till sunset. It is hard to know, except it is true that many industrial awards require an employer to provide a taxi where the employee completes work after 7 p.m., and I think that that is at least a starting point.

PARA.TAB: I am interested too in the minister's comments. Firstly, when it is required of employers to provide a taxi, then it should not attract a tax. Secondly, I think the security issues are very important. I think that, with deregulation in the labour market and the increasing expectation of unusual work hours, this is something that we have to address appropriately. We should not be discouraging security through the tax system. I do not say it affects only female employees, but there are far too many examples of on-campus attacks and nurses on shift work being attacked after hours and having insufficient security.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept this amendment either. This amendment would extend the hours which employers can provide FBT exempt taxi travel. The principle in which we look at this is to essentially take a rough rule of when it is dark and when it might be unsafe.
—We have daylight saving all around the country.
—Yes, 7 p.m. to 7 a.m. would obviously mean that in states in which daylight saving applies it is still quite light and bright.
—In summertime.
—In summertime, yes, absolutely.
—But not in winter.

—In some states it is still relatively bright at that hour, but the government proposes that the exemption apply for 8 p.m. to 6 a.m. The amendment would add two extra hours to what we propose. I also mention that that two extra hours is calculated by the tax office to be worth $10 million a year to revenue forgone.

PARA.TAB: I do say, though, that there is no difference in principle. We do want to get this right about what the right spread of hours might be. The amendment provides a more generous spread of hours than we think is appropriate is the fundamental point. The hours of 8 p.m. to 6 a.m. would cover the times when public transport is least available, whereas between 7 p.m. to 7 a.m. it is usually very well available.

I also point out that Mr Michael Evans from the Institute of Chartered Accountants made the observation during the Senate Economics Legislation Committee hearings about this bill that changing the hours to 7 p.m. to 7 a.m. would offer opportunities for salary sacrifice arrangements which were not intended. On those grounds, the government does not support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the question that arises here is the reasonableness to assume whether this extra hour in general is a fringe benefit or a condition of work. If, on balance, because of the points that have been mentioned in relation to it being a condition of an award, it might not be reasonable—there certainly may be a revenue implication—to assume that this is a fringe benefit rather than a condition of work.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make one comment on the availability of public transport. I think you will find that public transport starts shutting down a lot after 6 p.m. Public transport which is available after that time usually runs on the hour. That can make a lot of difference between when you leave work and when you get home.

—I assume that that intervention by Senator Kernot was an indication that the Democrats will be supporting the amendment. I will not bother the committee with my thoughts on the matter. It is obvious that if that is the case, it will be adopted. I will vote for the amendment for the reasons that have been advanced by Senator Gibson and Senator Margetts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The only comment I have is to Senator Margetts, who raised an argumentative point. The rest of the participants in this debate made observations of their belief about things.
—This is about more than public transport.

—You can reason with logic but you cannot reason with belief. If people believe things, they believe them and that is that. They often believe things in the face of what the evidence might be, but that is their right I suppose.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts made the observation about fringe benefits and the award. Awards are prime vehicles for conferring fringe benefits on employees. There is the distinction to be drawn here between income in kind and income in money. I will not go on and draw this out at any great length, but I do not think it can be contended that what is provided in an award is therefore not a fringe benefit. I simply make that point.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1995
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 1, page 7, item 20, omit "ending", substitute "commencing".

At present the application provision means that any accounting period after 30 June 1995 would be captured by the division. Any business which had an accounting period ending in July, August, September or October would be captured by the division. Given that they would have finalised their affairs in accordance with the law as it stood at the time, their accounting period ended the provision as it stands would have a retrospective application. This would require them to resubmit their tax affairs and may leave them open to penalties, even if the minister says it could not happen. Therefore, it is intended to remove the retrospective application and apply the division only to accounting periods commencing after 30 June this year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to hear the minister's comments on this because we have not seen this amendment before now. We were advised that the opposition was not moving any amendments to this bill, so I need to hear the minister's response to Senator Gibson's case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware of these amendments until this morning, hence I am caught short a little. This is an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) moved by Senator Gibson to schedule 1, page 7, item 20. The government's amendments will simply overcome a weakness that has been exploited by parties seeking to escape accruals of taxation on insurance—I have to say that the problem I am having is that I cannot read the writing of my advisers—but it should not be taxed on the CFC measures.

PARA.TAB: Consideration of the proposed amendments of Senator Gibson will defer the commencement of the measures by up to a year. This last paragraph of my advisers is simply undecipherable, but the nub of the advice is that this defers the commencement for up to a year and therefore it allows artificial arrangements to be pursued for up to another year. The government's view is that that should not be permitted.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about firms that have already closed off in the last few months their accounts for the last financial year? This is in fact suggesting a retrospective change.

—Retrospectivity is always abhorrent to the Senate. The amendment that has been put down is to replace the `period ending' with the `period commencing', because a transaction that was, for example, good in July, August, September, October or November and right through will suddenly have, according to the legislation before us, a retrospective application. I do not think that this parliament should be passing that sort of legislation.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of Senator Gibson's amendment, which I applaud, is to make it prospective as from the end of the financial year rather than for the year ending on that particular date. The purpose of the amendment is to remove the whole of the retrospective nature of the legislation to make it a lot fairer.

Even though it is prefaced by, in the government's language, an attempt to overcome tax avoidance et cetera and is associated with what is known as a CFC, a controlled foreign company, associated with tainted income, the principle should still be there in whatever guise the government may clothe this particular amendment in. I have much pleasure in supporting this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Gibson's question, I am advised, is this: it will have no effect for companies that have a standard accounting year because they will lodge for the standard year. My understanding is that companies with non-standard accounting years will not as yet have lodged their returns. By and large, the purpose of their returns is about tax avoidance. Therefore, it is appropriate that this measure be put in place now in order to prevent that.
—How many people does the minister estimate would already have lodged their returns?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have that information available to me. I am talking about the standard accounting year. The overwhelming number of firms adhere to that. The important point is not so much numbers as principle. The principle is about tax avoidance.

—With due respect, the minister said the principle is about tax avoidance. If you put in place legislation that affects people who have already put in their tax returns, it is not a principle of tax avoidance; it is putting in something they are meant to have adhered to before they put in their returns. It is a problem when the government puts in place legislation which it cannot reasonably expect people to have complied with. Therefore, we would be inclined to support the opposition's amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Schedule 1, page 10, item 21, proposed paragraph 46J(3)(b), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:
"(b)the transfer of itself, or as part of a series of integrated accounting entries, reflects a reduction in the carrying amount of an asset in the accounts.".
This amendment has arisen as a result of a letter sent to the government and the opposition by Greenwoods and Freehills. The government has received this letter and therefore is aware of the problem.

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister: what action is the government proposing to take in response to that letter? If it has rejected the argument, why has it done so? If it claims that there is not a problem it is important that the government state it clearly on the public record. Therefore it is important that the minister state that transfers from revaluation reserves to the profit and loss account which give effect to a reduction in the value of the asset through the amortisation of that asset will be treated as excluded transfers. That is the key point. I defer to my colleague Senator Watson, who is an expert on taxation matters, to comment further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Gibson for his contribution. This is a clarifying type of amendment that we have moved. For that reason, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard part of a document that I have already given to the government. It is necessary for the government to respond to that document. If it is in a position to respond to that document and to give assurances, then the amendment moved by Senator Gibson is not necessary.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Effectively, certain bona fide commercial transactions involving transfers from otherwise disqualifying accounts will not, under the amendments, give rise to NDA credits. As far as is relevant for present purposes, these `excluded transfers' include transfers from asset revaluation reserves which give effect to a reduction in the value of an asset.

The present drafting of this exclusion, however, is too narrow. Many other commercial transactions are not eligible for the protection which the amendment was intended to provide. While transfers from revaluation reserves which are directly charged against the relevant asset account will be `excluded transfers', transfers from the revaluation reserves to the profit and loss account for the same reason and to the same effect will not be `excluded transfers'. In some circumstances accounting standards require the reduction in the value of an asset to be reflected by the amortisation of that asset through the profit and loss account, and hence the transfer from the asset revaluation reserve is the second step in the required accounting treatment.
For example, companies which acquire or create intangible assets (for example, management agreements) for no cost will recognise those assets as follows:

PARA.TAB: DRAsset100
CRRevaluation Reserve100

SPEECH.PARA: Accounting standards may require the amortisation of such assets over their effective life:

PARA.TAB: DRAmortisation Expense10
CRAccumulated Amortisation10
(Assuming a 10 year life)

SPEECH.PARA: However, this amortisation artificially reduces realised profits of the company so that the profit as per the profit and loss statement is not indicative of the true results of the company, nor of the extent of realise profits from which dividends may be paid. Accordingly, companies invariably restore the profit and loss account by effectively passing on the charge to the revaluation reserve as follows:

PARA.TAB: DRAsset Revaluation Reserve10
CRRetained Earnings10

SPEECH.PARA: This final entry is a transfer out of the revaluation reserve which does not of itself reflect a reduction in the value of the asset and so cannot with certainty, be considered an `excluded transfer' under the current drafting of the Bill. It is submitted that this entry taken together with the previous entry should be an `excluded transfer' given that they do not facilitate the payment of dividends out of unrealised profits.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. You might recall during the debate in the other house the government introduced certain changes which were intended to overcome this type of problem. The difficulty arises if one takes a literal meaning of the words in the act. On such a literal meaning, it will be necessary to pass the amendment that my colleague Senator Gibson moved.

PARA.TAB: There could be a number of steps involved in the transaction. If it is a one-step transaction there is no doubt at all that the government's previous amendment overcomes the problem. If we apply a literal translation it is possible to take it either way.

In case of litigation, it is necessary to go back to the second reading speech and the assurances given by the minister that that literal interpretation is not necessary. If we can get that assurance it will not be necessary for us to press the amendment moved by Senator Gibson. It depends on the quality of the response by the minister.

I think this gives some idea of the complexity and the uncertainty that taxation laws are often fraught with. The purpose of the committee is to remove any possibility of ambiguity in terms of application or what is meant.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little doubtful about us saying that if we receive an assurance from the minister then it will not be necessary to proceed with this amendment. We receive an assurance from the minister. So what? The courts are not going to take any notice of that.
—They go to the second reading speech.

—The courts are required to make their decisions on the basis of the meaning of the words of the legislation. They will put the construction on the words of the legislation. They may take into account matters that are contained in the explanatory memorandum particularly. They may take into account matters that have been referred to in the second reading speech. They may indeed take into account assurances given in the committee. But, then again, they may not.

PARA.TAB: It is far preferable to have these matters specifically detailed and determined in the legislation itself. As I said in the second reading debate, it is a vital issue. As I would interpret it, on the face of the legislation that has been presented to us, I would fear that Australian insurance companies will now be disadvantaged compared to their overseas insurers who operate through branches or reinsurance arrangements in this country. Of course, they do not have to worry about rebatable dividends or franking credits.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might start this by going to the last point—the point made by Senator Harradine—and by placing on the record my understanding of the situation. The Acts Interpretation Act does require a court, in the event of there being doubt in the mind of that court, to have resort to extraneous material which may resolve that doubt. Among that extraneous material are the comments, in the committee stage of a bill, by the government minister who has carriage of that bill saying what the intention of that bill is in the mind of the government. That may not be entirely to your liking, Senator, given the harder test you have applied in your own comments.

PARA.TAB: I make that observation because I am about to say some things about the meaning of this bill. If there is a court in the future adjudicating on this that has doubt in its mind, I would like to draw its attention to these comments—that is, if you like, to raise them in the text of the Hansard a bit more prominently than might otherwise be the case in order to resolve doubt. The comments I now make are by my reading from the advice I have been given by the officers here. So it is not just me saying this; it is me reading advice given to the government, and the government saying and endorsing that advice.

With regard to amendment No. 2 moved by Senator Gibson, this amendment is being moved because some concern was expressed about the amendments affecting rebatable and frankable dividends. This was on the basis that the exemption for transfers that give effect to a reduction in the value of an asset may not apply in certain circumstances where an asset revaluation reserve has been created for an asset that is being amortised.

I am advised that the exemption proposed in paragraph 46J(3)(b) will apply in such a case. This is because the reduction in the carrying value of the asset and the charge to the asset revaluation reserve, although achieved in two stages, does give effect to a reduction in the value of the asset. In this context the value of an asset can include the carrying or book value as well as the market value.

To the final point: the government does not support the amendment because it is not necessary. That is the advice I have; that is the advice I give; and I draw attention to it as an answer to the question that Senator Watson has put and Senator Gibson has raised.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have only had a very short time in which to consider this amendment. I think it is too complex and I do not intend to vote for it. The opposition might want to revisit it but I am not prepared to vote for it under these circumstances.

—After taking advice, we are inclined to withdraw opposition amendment No. 2. We take the government's assurance that the matter will be dealt with under the Acts Interpretation Act. I therefore seek leave to withdraw the amendment.
—Is leave granted to the opposition to withdraw amendment No. 2?
—Reluctantly, I must agree because it appears that if we were to proceed with this amendment it would not obtain the necessary majority.
—Leave is granted for the withdrawal of opposition amendment No. 2.

—On the same matter, Minister Cook, I am perfectly well aware, having been here for a few years now, of the implications of the second reading speeches and explanatory memorandum for what is and is not said in the committee stage of the debate. If you look at the Hansard it is clear that on a number of occasions I have deliberately sought to do the same thing that Senator Gibson has done in the event of a disagreement among the judiciary.

PARA.TAB: The plain fact of the matter is that, where there is no such disagreement, the judiciary will make up its mind on the interpretation of the words in the actual statute. As I said in my speech on the second reading, these bills are of a complex nature. That is why it is so essential for the legislature to get it right. That is part of democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can revisit it though.
—Yes, we can, and I have no doubt that we will be revisiting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 19, after Part 4 add the following Part:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "PART 5—DEDUCTION OF EXPENDITURE ON PREVENTION OF LAND DEGRADATION

SPEECH.PARA: "43A. Paragraph 75D(1B)(c):
After `degradation', insert', including an operation to apply limestone or other soil agents designed to address soil acidification, salinity or other forms of soil degradation on the subject land,'.
"43B. Application:
The amendment made by this Part applies in relation to expenditure incurred in the 1995-96 year of income and all later years of income.".

This amendment relates to the deduction of expenditure in relation to the prevention of land degradation. In my speech on the second reading I gave my reason for wanting that issue dealt with. I tabled a letter from the Taxation Office giving assurances in that regard.

PARA.TAB: It would be useful if we could get a minister's commitment on the record to the effect that lime application, in its fullest sense, is covered. It would be useful to have a debate on this amendment. However, if there were an undertaking to inform rural tax agents of full coverage in relation to tax deductibility of five- to 10-year lime applications for salinity, and an undertaking that pamphlets on landcare and taxation issued by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy not mislead people into not applying for that rebate, this amendment might not be necessary. I look forward to hearing the contributions, particularly as to whether those assurances will be forthcoming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think this particular amendment is necessary. Following discussions I have had with Senator Margetts, I think the confusion could have arisen not from a publication from the Taxation Office but from something that came from one of the subsidiary departments, maybe Primary Industries. I think the legislation is quite clear. If I could just quote from Butterworths Australian Tax Handbook:

PARA.TAB: A taxpayer who carries on a business of primary production on any land in Australia is entitled to a deduction for certain capital expenditure incurred for the purpose of combating land degradation. In respect of expenditure incurred after 21 August 1990 the deduction is also available to a taxpayer who carries on a business, other than primary production, mining or quarrying, for the purpose of gaining or producing assessable income from the use of any rural land in Australia.
Expenditure which qualifies for the deductions as set out in s 75D(1B)—

SPEECH.PARA: and for the purpose of the record I will identify it:
3expenditure incurred primarily and principally in preventing or combating land degradation otherwise than by the erection of fences on the land . . .

So it really comes back to an issue of land degradation. Because there has been some doubt, I think it is desirable to make a couple of contributions on the value of limestone and lime in combating land degradation in Australia, which is so important. Limestone is a basic essential to Australian industry. While it might also be used in the manufacture of glass, plastic, paint, rubber, aluminium, cement, et cetera, by far the major usage of limestone in Australia is for agriculture. It is the major source of calcium in the treatment of acid soils, and that is where it relates to land degradation.

PARA.TAB: In Australia, because of high rainfall or utilisation for cropping or animal production, much of our nation's soils are naturally acidic. Degradation by high acidity is a widespread and gradually occurring problem, and reduces the productivity and output of agricultural soil. Because of its gradual nature, high acidity is often referred to as the unseen landcare problem.

Any time produce is removed from the farm, lime is reduced. For example, the baling of a hectare of lucerne hay removes approximately 250 kilograms of lime from the soil. Animal production is less destructive of lime content, but also has a marked effect. This means that farmers must work to replace the lime in their soil if it is not to become too acidic and lose productivity as a result.

Modern high technology testing processes allow farmers to determine accurately just how acidic or alkaline their soil is and what other nutrients may be needed to maximise their output. Farmers, therefore, are able to accurately apply and supplement their soil with very little guesswork or the waste of earlier days.

The point I really want to make is that, unlike some other fertilisers which need to have annual applications, the lime content is a long-term management issue with applications usually necessary only every three to 10 years depending on soil type, rainfall, zone and the type of production. Perhaps the writer of the publication that Senator Margetts referred to may have thought that, because the limestone was irregularly applied rather than annually applied, it had a capital nature.

Despite the capital nature, I think the wording of section 75D is quite clear—that section 75D also applies to capital items. The particular reference you had was talking about section 51, which has a recurring nature to it. There is another specific section which I think should also have been referred to in the particular application that caused you just concern. It is very important, and I am pleased you raised it, because it has enabled us to clarify this point.

I would also like to take this opportunity of pointing out that I think it is quite reprehensible that the government has removed the diesel fuel rebate for those people who manufacture lime for agricultural applications. These two things certainly go hand in hand. It has certainly given us another opportunity in another area to air our concern about the removal of the diesel fuel rebate from the manufacturers of lime for agricultural purposes. As we have mentioned before, this will raise the price of lime by between $1.60 per tonne to perhaps $2 per tonne. That will vary. It could be a bit lower depending on the types of applications that are used to extract that limestone.

I would also like to impress on you, Minister, that you should discuss with your colleagues further the need to come back and have a look at your government's intention to remove the diesel fuel rebate from the production of limestone. I do not think it is necessary to proceed with Senator Margetts's amendment, because I think there is adequate protection in section 75D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The actual wording of section 75D relates to an operation primarily and principally for the purpose of preventing or combating land degradation other than in the erection of fences on the subject land. The document that I was referring to and which was produced by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy was apparently produced in consultation with the Australian Taxation Office, though representatives of the tax office are now saying that the interpretation made by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy was not what it should have been. If the interpretation made by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in conjunction with the tax office could be faulty, then it could also be faulty for a number of other people, because it is not clearly specified in 75D that that application was intended.

PARA.TAB: I continue to ask that these undertakings be made: that the minister makes a clear statement that the lime application is covered, that rural taxation officers, in particular, be informed clearly of the situation and that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy moves to clarify that information on their pamphlets.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, starting right at the basics, it is the government's intention to provide a tax incentive to combat soil degradation in Australia. Our broad view is that that is the most serious environmental and ecological issue for this nation; thus, there is a provision in the act to encourage that via a tax incentive.

PARA.TAB: The second point is that work has now been done under the auspices of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy—and I think the CSIRO participated in this, too—which argues that liming in certain circumstances is a proven and valuable combating agent for soil degradation. The issue at contest is whether we should amend the tax act to specify this new insight or whether it is covered by the existing words in the tax act. I will read my formal advice into the record shortly but, in essence, it underlines and corresponds with the advice that Senator Watson read into the record and spoke to a moment ago. The bottom line here is that the existing act covers it.

The third point is that we are looking at words here that confer a benefit and which may be subject to litigation, although I must say that I think it is quite clear here. While I do not think there is a likelihood of litigation, there is always the possibility of it and one has to guard against that possibility.

I mention this in a cautionary way. When a settled set of words which specifies specific things are changed, the tendency in legal interpretation is to regard the whole text as being limited by those items that are set out. Thus it may be that, if an amendment were made here, it could have the reverse effect to what is intended. I do not say that it will—I am not giving a legal opinion here because I am not competent to do so—but I do make that observation under the heading of `let us be careful about how we proceed here'. This is just a cautionary note.

Turning to my advice: this amendment is related to measures in the bill. It adds further words to paragraph 75D(1B)(c). The proposed words are wholly unnecessary. The paragraph is part of the section that gives deductions to those who carry out primary production or other business using rural land for a variety of capital expenditures on the fighting or preventing of land degradation where they are in that business or in a business related to that. It gives deductions for operations primarily and principally for the purpose of preventing and combating land degradation other than by fencing, which is dealt with in another paragraph.

Senator Margetts's proposal refers expressly to operations to apply limestone or other soil agents designed to address soil acidification, salinity, or other forms of soil degradation on the land. Such operations are already covered by the plain words of the existing paragraph. Senator Margetts does not propose to deem all liming or other dressing of land to be an operation primarily and principally for the purpose of preventing or combating land degradation. Whether it is or not, not all dressing of land is meant to fight or prevent land degradation.

The words of Senator Margetts's amendment add nothing to the law, and so can do no good. The words may obscure the meaning of the law and, if so, would do harm. The government does not oppose the purpose that Senator Margetts wishes to support; the government opposes an amendment which will not help and may, in fact, hinder that purpose.

That concludes my advice. But to put this matter beyond any doubt, I refer to the letter that Senator Margetts has had leave to table. It is a letter from the Commissioner of Taxation, dated 16 November 1995, to a Mr River, one of Senator Margetts's advisers who is situated in Parliament House. The letter is signed by Mr C. L. Hood, Assistant Commissioner, Business Tax Branch, Australian Tax Office. Senator, I suggest that you incorporate this letter. That would put the advice of the department on this point as well in the record. It is yours to move on; it is not appropriate for me to do it. But I would suggest that if you were to seek leave to incorporate the letter, I would support its incorporation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to do so. I seek the leave of the committee to incorporate the letter from the Australian Tax Office into the Hansard of this debate.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

2 Constitution Avenue, Canberra ACT
PO Box 900, Civic Square ACT 2608

Mr Dhanu River

Senator Dee Margetts

If a taxpayer applies lime to soil either to prevent or combat land degradation, and the taxpayer is either carrying on a business of primary production or carrying on a business for the purpose of gaining assessable income from the use of rural land then the amount spent on the lime would be deductible under paragraph 75D(1B)(c) in the year in which the expenditure was incurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said this twice. I am still asking two questions: is it possible for the minister to ask the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to clarify the pamphlets in relation to the deductibility of liming applications for land care; and could rural tax agents be informed clearly of the situation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give an unfettered guarantee on behalf of another minister in another portfolio. But your question to me is whether I would proceed to ask the minister to do that. The answer to that question is: yes, I will.
—I will take the government at its word. I feel happy that, in fact, it is clear that it was intended. I seek leave of the committee to withdraw the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be quick because the amendment has been withdrawn. I was going to say that we obviously support the government's intention to give a tax incentive for expenditure on prevention of land degradation. Normally, if the government and the opposition were agreed on this, it would be a bit of a worry to me.

PARA.TAB: But there has been much history in this place of how we can rely on Senator Watson's interpretation. I am persuaded by him that it is already covered, as he clarified, primarily and principally for the purpose of preventing land degradation. But I think Senator Margetts raised an important point of how that can be lost down the chain of communication in a pamphlet. Not only do we support the tax incentive but Senator Spindler has given notice that he intends, via the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995, to make that limestone $2 a tonne cheaper to farmers.

DEBATE.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1995HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 25 September and 23 October, on motions by Senator Sherry and Senator Bob Collins:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating two higher education funding bills—the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1995 and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. The first of these bills we support. This is really an omnibus bill dealing with a range of different subject matters. Probably the most important part of it is the introduction of cooperative multimedia centres.

PARA.TAB: In that instance, we suggested changes in the debate in the other place so that there would be the capacity for research and development to be incorporated within the purposes as defined for the centres. I am pleased that the government accepted our suggestions and amended the bill before it reached the Senate in that regard. The major issue of concern we had in relation to this bill has now been rectified. The first bill, as I said, we support.

The second of the bills is a bit more difficult. Part 1 sets out the revised funding levels of grants for operating purposes, superannuation expenses, open learning organisations, teaching hospitals and special capital projects. These are relatively marginal increases and we do not oppose those amendments. Part 2 provides a 15 per cent discount in respect of voluntary payments of $500 or more in discharge of certain HECS and open learning debts. We do not oppose that.

Part 3 of the bill redefines taxable income for HEC assessment purposes. We do not oppose that. Part 4 of the bill makes provision for a discount to be offered to persons who voluntarily commence to repay their HEC debt when their income reaches $20,000. Currently, the level at which the debt must commence to be repaid is $26,853. We have some reservations about this in light of the government's record in relation to HECS. Of course, this was the `no up-front fees' government at one time. It seems to have modified its position on a number of occasions over the years. One of the modifications was the introduction of HECS so that students are now obliged to pay a share of the cost of their undergraduate course. Certainly, it is by a deferred system so that they repay that debt when their income from employment subsequent to graduation reaches just over $26,000, as I indicated a moment ago.

On the face of it, one would say that the voluntary right to commence repayment at a lower income seems to be rational and sensible, but as this government since the introduction of HECS has had the habit of seeking to increase the percentage that is repayable by students—in other words, extending the obligation of students—and also reducing the threshold at which they must commence repayment, one suspects that if this government is re-elected a voluntary payment to commence at $20,000 will soon become a compulsory repayment to commence at $20,000. It is not surprising that student unions have also been expressing that concern. So we have that reservation.

There is also some worry that students may well get themselves into financial difficulty by accepting this invitation and seeking to repay the debt before they are economically sensibly able to do so. I think that is relatively unlikely. But we do have reservations about the provision because of our concern that this is really the first step towards the government's intention of reducing the threshold at which repayment must commence. Nevertheless, we are willing to address the provision in the terms in which it is put before us. At the moment it is voluntary and we will not oppose it. But we do express the reservation that I have mentioned.

As I said, students are concerned because of the government's poor record in this regard. The government makes promises one day and breaks them the next. Students are as disillusioned as the rest of the Australian community in relation to this government's performance. Of course, there is another option—that they support us and we get elected; we will keep our promises and they will be better off.

Part 5 of the bill provides three new repayment thresholds for HECS. This is a demonstration of the validity of students' concerns. What the government is doing here is breaking another promise. What it is doing is inserting three new levels for repayment that has the effect of obliging students to accelerate repayment of their HECS debt.

It is true that the government is not increasing the debt, but it is requiring students, depending on their incomes, to repay earlier. We have taken the view that this is a compact between students and the government. Students entered into higher education on the basis that they would accept an obligation to pay a portion of the costs on a certain fixed basis.

What we have here is the government unilaterally determining to vary the repayment basis to the students' disadvantage. It is not surprising that students are upset by this. They have every reason to be upset because the government has broken the compact that it entered into with them. We believe that the government should stick to the agreements it reached with students in the past and keep the promises that it made to students in the past. We do not see why this provision should be supported. We will vote against it as it applies to existing students or past students.

It is a different issue in relation to future students; however, it is again a broken promise. The government keeps promoting the no up-front fees rhetoric. Future students know the basis upon which they enter higher education, including the requirement for accelerated repayment of their HECS. In relation to existing and past students, we believe it is a blatant abuse of students. In effect, it is in the spirit of another tax. This is an accelerated payment to get the money in earlier. It is a promise to students that has been broken. We will stand by the students' interests in this regard and will not support this measure.

Part 6 of the bill provides no discount on HECS contributions for students who are required to pay up-front fees. That amendment is consequential on the introduction of mandatory up-front fees, which is an issue tied into another part of the bill that I will get to in a moment. Part 7 of the bill provides for projects concerned with maintaining and enhancing innovation to be funded by way of a national priority reserve fund. We do not oppose that amendment.

Part 8 eliminates HECS exemption scholarships for the professional development of teachers. I, along with my political colleagues from across the spectrum, attended a breakfast this morning with representatives of the Australian Education Union. Those people who represent the teaching profession were stressing to us not only the importance of education for the benefit of Australian students but also the importance of the proper status and recognition of the skills of teachers within the sector. We have to address the government's decision to eliminate a particular type of scholarship that would offer further professional development to teachers.

The lot of teachers has not been easy, particularly during the recession we had to have, which was inflicted upon us by this Labor government. The social consequences of a million people unemployed and the record levels of family breakup provide pressure points for teachers. Obviously, a great deal of extra pressure was put on the teaching profession arising out of family stresses. Teachers have found it a difficult lot.

On top of having to cope with these increased pressures arising from the recession, the challenge of teaching has become ever more complex. More is continually expected of teachers—and one thinks of the expanding obligations, for example, in relation to vocational education. We all support students staying longer at school, but it is necessary in the post-compulsory years that there be sufficient educational choice in order that the educational product presented to students is relevant to their skills and aspirations, which is the need for a broader range of educational opportunity. Again, the pressure is put back on teachers to respond to this. Of course, it means they need to respond in areas in which they may not have had training, so the need for further professional development is obvious.

Within the traditional educational areas, science immediately comes to mind. Science is changing so quickly—information technology, for example, is changing so quickly—that it is extremely difficult for teachers to maintain the level of professionalism that they would wish without having the opportunity for upgrading their qualifications and skills.

So in that environment we find the government has made a decision that the HECS exemption scholarships for professional development of teachers should be scrapped. Since the introduction of HECS in 1989, some 4,000 HECS exemption scholarships per year have been made available for professional development of teachers employed in Australian schools. So, for a saving of $4.82 million, they are to be scrapped. I think that is regrettable.

Part 9 is, I guess, the most controversial part of this bill which has upset a lot of immigrants in Australia. This is the attempt by the government to change the entitlement for getting the benefit of a HECS education system for permanent residence, which is the test at the moment, to citizenship. In other words, with a phasing-in period, it will only be Australian citizens who can get this benefit, whereas in the past it has always been a test based on permanent residency. As a matter of interest, according to the DEET figures, I understand there are currently some 26,000 permanent residents studying at Australian universities.

The government has promoted this as an anti-avoidance mechanism. There has been an argument that there are some who come here as permanent residents, take the benefit of the Australian HECS education system—in other words, one that is predominantly publicly funded, with a contribution by students on a deferred basis—and then leave the country without taking employment here and repaying the HECS debt. I suppose it is pretty obvious that they may well do that whether they are permanent residents or Australian citizens but, nevertheless, the government has assessed that it is more likely to happen in relation to those who do not go on to be citizens. It is, therefore, planning to change the test, as I said, from permanent residency to citizenship.

It has not been the normal practice in relation to the granting of Australian benefits to base those benefits on citizenship. In fact, I think most of us would like to think that citizenship is something to which new Australians aspire, not just for reasons of what material benefits might flow from it but, rather, because they wish to be Australians in the terms of Australian citizens and to contribute to our community to the full extent of normal citizenship obligations—commitment and citizenship.

What the government is seeking to do here is really quite new. In fact, we might argue that it is almost forcing permanent residents, in effect, to become citizens by the threat that unless they do so they will not otherwise receive a benefit that other Australians will have.

It flows from what I have said that we have considerable misgivings about the argument that the government is putting and the precedent that it is creating. It is not surprising that the representative groups of Australians who are not citizens have argued strongly against this. Again, a number of student interest groups have also argued strongly against it and pointed out particular examples where students will suffer. An example, which I notice is picked up in one of the Australian Democrats' amendments, is where a student's country of birth is unwilling to accept dual citizenship and therefore there is loss of access to return and the relationship with their family may flow as a consequence and the student therefore suffers.

We have decided to draw the line again at the point of those who came to this country and became permanent residents on the understanding of the existing arrangement. We do not believe that they specifically should suffer as a result of the changes that the government is imposing. Therefore, when it gets to the committee stage, we will seek to amend this bill to remove them from this proposed change by the government, which we think will be a just solution in all the circumstances. It does not answer all the worries that I have. It is something of a compromise, I acknowledge, but, nevertheless, it is a reasonably fair and just solution for those who are particularly disadvantaged by the change that the government is proposing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats certainly have misgivings about this higher education legislation, the purpose of which seems to be no more than to arrive at a greater amount of revenue for the government from adjustments to legislation which is in force in Australia. As such, it is a continuation of strategies which have been attempted before and a continuation of an attitude which sees Australian students as a potential source of income for the government. This is a group of people who have been targeted before as having been the source of what the government has previously described as bad debts and people who have been seen before as a source of different opportunities for the government to get in the money.

PARA.TAB: We have seen in this chamber before several examples of the government trying to rearrange things so that it can get the money in faster or get in more money in total. On several occasions in this chamber we have expressed our opposition to such measures. We are here again forming somewhat of an alliance with the coalition, the Greens and other independents in this chamber to oppose these rearrangements. Sometimes this alliance has worked and at other times it has not. I hope that on this occasion we in this chamber are able to sufficiently draw the attention of all honourable senators to the inequity that has been introduced by these proposed changes and the unfairness that it would visit upon Australia's student population and the community in general.

Senator Hill was right to draw attention to the fact that these proposed changes have received opposition from various parts of the community. The correspondence I have in front of me now—from which I will quote shortly—expresses that opposition. It is becoming somewhat annoying to have to come into this chamber yet again to defend the position which I would have thought this government would have stood for; that is, maintaining equity for students who are following what they thought the arrangement was. But yet again the government is initiating a change which is, using the cliche, moving the goalposts during the game. It is annoying to have to use that cliche to refer to what the government is doing.

This argument is accurate, and I cannot see why we should have to repeat it. Nevertheless, we have the argument and I repeat our opposition to the changes which are being foisted upon Australia's students. I want to give an example of the correspondence that I have received on this, and I am sure that other senators have as well. On 12 October this year I received a letter from the National Union of Students which says in part:

SPEECH.PARA: With reference to Part 5 of the Bill, NUS is concerned at the continuing trend of increasing the burden placed on students, and past students, through changing the rates at which repayments are made. NUS feel that, despite the claimed merits of the changes, the constant tampering with the repayment conditions of HECS fees is unfair on students who have already incurred a debt.
That says it simply. I would like to hear the government's reason and the government's rationale for bringing to people with whom it has made an agreement a change such as those proposed.

PARA.TAB: I now want to quote further from the correspondence so that the Senate has the benefit of knowing exactly what the students of Australia are saying through their national body. They say:

SPEECH.PARA: NUS is more gravely concerned by Parts 6 and 9 of the Bill regarding up front HECS fees for Permanent Residents. NUS feels that this is the most regressive policy change contained within the Bill and as such the most important section to be removed, or amended. This change constitutes the introduction of up front fees for undergraduate domestic students and strikes at the core of issues of access and equity. This change is by no means the first step toward the introduction of up front fees for Australian undergraduate students, as this process has been occurring for the last decade. This change could be more accurately described as the last step before up front fees for Australian undergraduate students, as the Government has few other categories of students to target.

The government can deny that. The government can say that they do not want undergraduates to be charged up-front fees but the fact is that, under the regime that the government has established here, those trends are occurring. That is what is happening. Although I hear the minister constantly saying that the government oppose such moves, universities in Australia have found ways to effectively do this, and here we have the government taking steps which, for some students, will mean up-front fees will be charged.

PARA.TAB: We cannot blame students for getting the message that a certain trend is occurring even though the government is denying that it can occur. If on the ground and in reality that is what is occurring at the universities, do not blame the students for thinking that the reality is in fact what is happening.
Other correspondence I have received on this legislation includes a letter from the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia. FECCA writes:

As you are aware, Australia's multicultural policy is based on the principle of inclusiveness and therefore is a policy for all residents of Australia. The exception to this principle to date has been the denial of Social Security benefits to newly arrived migrants for a period of two years. The proposed changes to Austudy and HECS are further exceptions.

FECCA contends that these three exceptions are creating two classes within Australia—residents and citizens. FECCA would hold that such a division is at odds with the development of multiculturalism and detrimental to our relatively harmonious community relations record.

Finally, FECCA would assert that the spirit behind the proposed changes, which links financial incentives to citizenship, is at odds with the appropriate promotion of citizenship as an active voluntary commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: If that group perceives that is how the government is doing things we should recognise that perception because they are the people who are the subject of the government's movements. We should understand what affect those movements will have directly upon them.

PARA.TAB: Another piece of correspondence I received on this matter was from the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee. I received this the day after the minister received a little publicity over his claim that the stated position of the Australian Democrats and the coalition on this matter would cost the government a certain amount of money and that that amount of money would be denied to the tertiary education sector.

It may be a coincidence that the correspondence came to me. I suspect it also went to Senator Hill. That correspondence came to me at the same time as the publicity about the minister's assertion that there would be certain costs associated with it. I note that the AAP placed a low priority on the report that the Queensland minister reacted to this threat from the federal minister. I note also that the publicity that the minister was able to achieve on this is quite small. From the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee I received correspondence which said in part:

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the Government's statement that the budget for Higher Education was budget neutral, and subsequent discussions with the Department of Employment, Education and Training indicate that this will result in either reduced places for new students and/or reduced funding for research infrastructure. In the budget lead up these were the system's—
presumably, the tertiary education system's—
top priority for funding and so the Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee is very troubled by the amendments which have been prepared without any consultation with the AVCC or universities.

My reaction is to say that the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee's letter and the discussion with DEET about where this money was coming from or going to beg several questions. I would like to raise those questions here at this time.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that the questions derive from the assertions made by the Queensland Minister for Education, David Hamill, who issued a press release which said in part:
"Thousands of final year students throughout Queensland are this week writing their applications for positions at our universities in 1996.
"They were doing this in the knowledge that 1,700 more students would be accepted following the successful negotiation between the Goss and Keating governments earlier this year . . .

SPEECH.PARA: He thought that many dreams may be smashed by petty party political games in federal parliament.

PARA.TAB: The questions which arise from the AVCC correspondence to me and from the statement by the Queensland minister are, as far as I am concerned, basic questions. I wonder whether the negotiators were told that these extra places relied upon greater returns from HECS to the government. I wonder whether the negotiators asked the government how it would find the money. Did the government tell the negotiators that it did not have that money in hand but was hoping to gain this money from the payment of HECS liabilities?

I wonder whether during these negotiations the government reminded the AVCC and the Queensland minister that HECS liabilities are repaid only when certain income thresholds are reached? I wonder whether the negotiators considered that forcing people to become citizens would magically place them over these income thresholds to start returning this money to the government? I wonder whether the government explained during these negotiations how this extra money would come to pass if everybody actually obeyed this new legislation?

It seems to me that the purpose of passing legislation is in the expectation that people will actually comply with it. If everybody to whom this legislation is directed actually complies with it and becomes a citizen of Australia under the provisions that Senator Hill has so adequately described, I wonder whether any extra money will come the government's way anyway? Presumably you bring legislation in here with the intention that it will be something to which people will comply.

On what basis do we have these precise figures that are quoted? In one piece of correspondence I have here we are told that in 1996 the government will receive $11.7 million; in 1997, $18.7 million; and in 1998, $19.4 million. Upon what basis can the government seriously make these claims that this extra money will be available and that it will be sufficient to fund 1,750 extra places in Queensland universities? On what basis are we supposed to receive this threat that unless we agree with all this we will somehow be responsible for such moneys not being available?

If the government wanted to recognise the need for these extra places, then surely it would be providing the funding on a much more sound basis than a vague assertion that there will be so many people not complying with the legislation, and therefore having to pay fees up front, and that that money will be available to the government. There is not much of a leg to stand on there. I will be very interested to hear the government's explanation of where these extra funds have been calculated and on what basis and what they are going to do if everybody complies with the legislation.

Anticipating that that will not come about, I will be moving in the committee stage on behalf of the Democrats some amendments which will again oppose changes to HECS. That is consistent with our position we have maintained ever since the higher education contribution scheme was introduced into Australia. Having had it introduced, we have consistently opposed any changes to it and we will do so again. I will be moving amendments which seek to do that.

I will also be moving amendments which will seek to ensure that certain categories of students will not be affected by the changes with regard to the citizenship requirements. Certainly, for that considerable number of students who are under 18 years of age, it seems to us to be grossly unfair that somebody who is under 18 years of age should be penalised in anyway for not becoming a citizen. That seems obvious to us and that is our first priority here.

Our other amendments will seek not to disadvantage a citizen of a country which does not permit its students to hold dual citizenship; not to disadvantage somebody who is applying for and waiting conferral of citizenship; and enable the minister to have some discretion to recognise a particular situation where a student may be suffering extreme hardship. I will be moving those amendments in the committee stage to give effect to our position that this concept introduces inequities and unfairness. We see there are unfair aspects of this legislation to which the government has not paid sufficient regard.

Senator Hill also gave details with regard to part 8. We need to recognise that the effect of these provisions would be to remove the exempt scholarships from professional development for teachers. As I understand it, the government proposes to fund such applications from teachers from what is virtually the leftovers of university funding in other categories. I have seen no evidence that the government is meeting that funding requirement in any other way. It may be redirecting teachers to a different source of funds for professional development.

I hope the government is not ignoring teachers in need of professional development. As I said, it is directing teachers to another source of funding but I have seen no evidence that it has increased that source to provide for teachers who have been so directed. To continue the theme, from the point of view of people who are living in reality, they see a cut in funding because that is what has happened.

Do you blame teachers who are offended, upset and disenchanted with this trend? The psychological effect is to wipe away any respect the government has had for their professional development. I am offended by that. I am offended by the suggestion that it is not worth investing in the professional development of teachers. This legislation has offended a considerable number of participants in higher education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are addressing the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1995 and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995, which are being debated cognately. I rise to support the comments of my colleague Senator Hill and to endorse most of what Senator Bell has had to say today. The focus in the debate so far has been on bill No. 2, which I will be spending most of my time discussing as well, but I want to make some initial comments on the first bill, particularly its proposal to fund cooperative multimedia centres.

PARA.TAB: The bill provides $8.2 million for this purpose each year from 1997 to 1999. What are these centres? The government's proposed definition of CMCs was originally deficient. It stated that the centres should be concerned with providing services relating to education and training and to undertake activities to assist in the development of the Australian information industry. The major oversight was no reference to the role that CMCs could possibly have in research and development. With the convergence of multimedia and information technology, research and development should be prominent in the work priorities of these cooperative multimedia centres.

I note that the government in the other place has accepted the coalition's amendment to incorporate research and development into the definition of these centres. However, I remain concerned about another aspect of the proposal by the government and that is the establishment of these centres under the education portfolio. I question whether this is the right way to go. Perhaps they should be more closely aligned with the information technology area, given the way they might develop over the next few years and the very vital role they will play in the development of this very rapidly expanding industry in Australia.

I am also concerned that they come specifically under the control of DEET. DEET has a record of being very interventionist and this would be yet another tentacle of the DEET octopus. The work of these centres in service and training, and in R&D for the multimedia industry, could be hindered by DEET if it follows the centralist approach it has taken in many other areas.

We have to question whether the vast and cumbersome DEET bureaucracy will treat these centres in a way that will enable them to flourish and grow. Given the key position we are now in and the advantages we now have with the development of information technology compared with many other countries, it is vital that this very new area is nurtured properly. I express some concern about whether this will happen under the aegis of DEET.

The second bill is the main one we are considering today. It contains two very controversial measures which have been alluded to in some detail by Senators Hill and Bell. The government is introducing under this legislation three new HECS repayment thresholds and the requirement of permanent residents who have not taken out Australian citizenship to pay HECS charges up front. Senator Hill has foreshadowed amendments to bring fairness and equity to this legislation. From comments so far by Senator Bell, I think we can fairly safely assume that the Democrats will support those.

We are moving to amend the bill so the government's three repayment thresholds will apply only to those students who commence their studies from 1996 onwards. Labor is trying to extract more money from over 800,000 tertiary students yet again. This is the second time in the three years since the last election that the ALP government has tried to accelerate HECS repayments. I was very much involved in the education area before the last election and listened to what the government had to say in its policy back then. I can't recall any statements or any whisper that the government was going to change, fiddle or increase HECS at all. I would ask all students right around the nation, before they cast their vote in the next election, to very much take this into account.

You can't really trust what this government says or what it does not say, the things that it does not reveal, because it has certainly had a secret agenda in terms of extracting more money from students in this term of government. There was no hint of it before the last election. But the record of what it has done over the last three years now stands exposed. Students should consider that very carefully before casting their vote in the next election.

With the arrangements this government has made since 1987 for the funding of higher education, particularly student contributions, students in this country now have an accumulated HECS debt of $2 billion. The government is very anxious to reel in as much of this as possible as quickly as possible. That is why it keeps changing the ground rules. This creates great uncertainty for parents and students right across the nation.

When you undertake a course of study, particularly one where you do have to pay fees over a number of years, you should be certain about what your financial commitment is at that point. Particularly for people who are not well off, they must know what the ground rules are and, one would hope, have some security that those ground rules will stay right through their period of study. The basic principle is that each cohort of students should start and finish their degree under the same rules. But it is not so under this government. Every year we see they keep chopping and changing the rules for their own financial convenience.

The coalition amendment will introduce a degree of financial certainty for students who undertake courses in the future. It will protect current students and undergraduate students from the Keating HECS grab, none of which, as I mentioned, had been foreshadowed before the last election. The ALP government is also targeting another group in this HECS grab. The government wants this bill to amend the law so that permanent residents who do not take up Australian citizenship have to pay HECS up front. It requires permanent residents who have met the residency requirement for citizenship one year or more before enrolment to pay up-front fees.

This measure is aimed at stopping persons from overseas undertaking education in Australia and then leaving the country without paying their HECS debt. The coalition amendment will have the effect of making this apply only to permanent residents who undertake studies from 1996 onwards. This is in line with the sound principle that I outlined earlier. Students should start and finish their degrees under the same set of rules.

According to DEET there are 26,800 permanent residents studying at Australian universities. Of those, only 2,200 would be liable for up-front fees under the government's plan. Most will take out citizenship in Australia. Over half would not have been permanent residents for three years and would therefore have the right to defer their HECS debt. The government's estimate that in 1995-96 it will save $1.8 million and $3.8 million in the following two financial years is a very dubious projection.
