As Senator Bell commented in his speech, the government has said that this money will be used to fund places in universities. He also stated that the government is holding a threat over the opposition parties that we will be responsible in some way if we amend the bill and do not allow this plan to go ahead.

I point out very strongly to everyone involved that that $1.8 million, and subsequent $3.8 million, is very dubious in its calculation. If you look back to the number of students who will not have to pay the debt by the various means that I have already indicated, the sum will be that much lower. But, of course, we will not know that until after the next election. So the government has really developed a furphy here. There will not be the funding available to fund those other places. If the government plans to do that, it really needs to work out a different mechanism for bringing that about.

The opposition believes this amendment will in only a very small way address the problem of rorting the system, which the government claims is the rationale for the legislation in the first place. It is possible to complete a degree as a permanent resident before becoming eligible for citizenship, and the government amendment would not have any effect on this. For those whose nation of origin permits dual citizenship it would be easy to become a token Australian and then return home, paying no debt at all. So a great number of groups will not be caught by this net that the government is setting.

What we have before us is a proposal that is very cumbersome. There are some possible savings, but in reality probably very little at all. We feel the coalition amendment probably makes the best of a bad situation. It enforces that basic principle which I outlined earlier. People have some security in their future financial planning under our amendment. It gets rid of the sense of retrospectivity that is included in the proposed legislation.

The ALP's HECS grab which we have been discussing and which is embodied in this bill underlines the government's underfunding of the whole higher education system. It is the government's latest pathetic attempt to squeeze more money into a system that it has grossly underfunded since the disaster of the Dawkins reforms eight years ago. The Higher Education Council and a research committee of the AVCC have nailed the ALP government on its university spending record over these years.

The Sydney Morning Herald on 1 November this year reported that Minister Crean has been forced to defend the government's record in the light of the reported findings that recurrent per capita funding for students has declined by seven per cent since 1983. I will just repeat that point: since the government came to power, the funding for each student is seven per cent lower than when we left government. That starkly highlights what this government has done over its 13-year stewardship of the universities. It has made the funding base poorer off and therefore has threatened quality right across the system. It just has not put enough money into the system.
The AVCC Acting Executive Director, Mr John Mullarvey, is quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald story as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the first time the government has come clean and conceded its operating grant per student has decreased.

This underfunding is affecting teaching, research and university administration right across the country. Financially, universities are under great stress. There is overcrowding in lecture theatres and poor library and research facilities. This stress on university infrastructure, having been caused by underfunding, will continue to be produced as a result of this bill.

PARA.TAB: The bill hopes, in some small way, to try to get just a little more money in to overcome this gross underfunding. But it will not have much of an effect. As a matter of fact, on our calculations, it will hardly change the bottom line at all. Also, it is creating a form of injustice against these students. This legislation highlights, yet again, the failure of this government's higher education policy and the inadequacy of its funding mechanisms which over the last 13 years have been developed by the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating two bills here today: the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995 and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. The first bill, funding bill No. 1, is a general funding bill which increases recurrent funding grants to universities, and provides funding grants for teaching hospitals, capital projects and cooperative multimedia centres.

PARA.TAB: Section 5 allows greater ministerial powers for approving moneys for any institution. It sets up funding structures which may be positive if we are talking about funding increases. But it allows flexibility in funding, according to the whim of the government of the day.

This bill also allows rewarding systems of tertiary institutions research priorities, for instance, which the Greens do not necessarily agree with. It allows for responsiveness to whatever the government's funding priorities happen to be at the time.

So there are some concerns with this bill. There are also possible areas of contention in relation to subsection 35(5). This section allows for students in jointly funded industry places to be exempt from HECS.

I guess it is more a watching brief that we are holding on this. We do not, in the end, know what the impact will be as to the places available and the effect of making certain courses exempt and others not. We do not know whether the impact will mean that there will be a greater level of control of industry in connection with what goes on in our university system. So, as I say, in that case we, the Greens, will be looking more closely at those issues and keeping a watching brief on any resulting impacts.

Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 does a lot of things, such as providing for funding—as does Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995; introducing discounts for voluntary repayments; removing the discount for up-front HECS payments; and redefining taxable income for HECS assessments, and so on. However, this bill also brings in some dreadful measures against which, since they were announced in the 1995-96 budget, students have been campaigning.

These are, firstly, bringing in the new voluntary HECS repayment threshold of $20,000. At the moment you only start repaying HECS once you earn over $27,000. To claw more money back faster, the government is selling a lower threshold as a voluntary repayment scheme—which it is, until you make the first voluntary repayment. It then is not voluntary any more, and you are locked in for good. We will be seeking to amend this.

Secondly, this second bill removes the HECS option for New Zealand citizens and Australian permanent residents, replacing it with up-front fees; although they are not full fees, they are still at the HECS rate. The government should come clean about this. It is a revenue raising measure to force 27,000 students into citizenship, which would be a windfall in the demanding of birth and citizenship certificates. There is an irony here: we do not limit taxation liabilities in Australia to those who are citizens, and it is fair enough to provide a requirement for length of residency; but it is amazing that people can be fully required to pay tax for years and yet be considered in a category of not being able to receive any of the benefits of those taxation contributions on the basis of their citizenship.

This is a revenue raising measure, as I said. Universities themselves will find the whole process administratively unworkable. Universities fear that they will have to verify every one of Australia's 550,000 students for Australian citizenship, including those born in Australia or permanent residents who have been resident for more than three years.

Monash University researchers have found an unexpected twist to all of this. Students who have taken out citizenship can prove their status by showing their certificates to the university or Austudy authorities, but those born in Australia may face problems. They claim that this is because neither an Australian passport nor birth certificate states that a person is an Australian citizen. The only proof is a statutory declaratory certificate of Australian citizenship, which costs $55. Therefore, state governments are likely to receive a financial windfall for issuing birth certificates and extracts of entry while the Commonwealth could earn a fortune providing new passports and citizenship documents. This came from the Bulletin on 11 July 1995, page 49.

Monash researchers looking at the impact of this policy say that the thought of up to 550,000 applicants for certificates of some sort is a sobering one. It will be an enormous inconvenience and cost to students who will need their proof of citizenship by February 1996 when these changes, if passed, are due to come in. I would appreciate some response from the government on these claims by the researchers at Monash University. There certainly appears to be some dispute over the level of documentary evidence for Australian born citizens, but this does need to be clarified.

Also, the government claims that those 27,000 students can just become citizens and they will not have to pay up-front HECS. However, there are many of these people whose former countries preclude them from accepting citizenship of another country. Yet they want to retain dual citizenship so they can keep up their family relationships and cultural identity. Some of the countries that do not accept dual citizenship are Austria, Malaysia, Germany and Chile.

In response to my questions to the budget estimates committee, I was told that 2,200 students would refuse to give up their birth country citizenship and will therefore be affected. It is from these 2,200 students that the government hopes to claw back around $12 million until the year 2000. If so few students are being attacked for more money at such a high administrative cost, the question needs to be asked: why bother? It should also be noted that the government's rationale is to target its education benefits at students who have a `demonstrated commitment to Australia'.

I would like to question this fundamental point because can citizenship really be seen as a demonstrated commitment to Australia? Out of the 27,000 permanent residents affected, more than one-third have lived in Australia for 10 years or more. They have clearly demonstrated their commitment and are unlikely to flee the country. Someone who has been here for less time could change to Australian citizenship and flee the country anyway or revert to their former citizenship and still leave the country.

This policy decision is a knee-jerk response from the government that allegedly wants to prevent rorting by permanent residents who finish their education in Australia, go straight back to their home countries to work and avoid paying their HECS debts. There are other ways of solving this problem such as appointing guarantors for the debt, as with any private debt for people who may be returning home within five years of completing their degree, for example. These possibilities need to be explored. If the government has other ways of doing that, perhaps it might suggest those as well.

Thirdly, the bill introduces additional HECS repayment thresholds for income levels between $30,000 and $51,000. The $27,000 first compulsory threshold level will remain at three per cent but, instead of rates at three per cent, four per cent and five per cent, there will now be intermediate rates as well of 3.5 per cent, 4.5 per cent and 5.5 per cent for the top income earners at $51,000 per annum.

The Greens have no problem with progressive taxation of the highest income brackets. However, we do not think it is fair to burden new graduates with high rates of repayment on average incomes when the financial burdens of life are at their greatest, for instance, with children and mortgage commitments. Also, we think it is very unfair for the government to have increased HECS three times in the last two years. That means that someone starting a degree first undertook that degree with a commitment that repayment rates were two per cent, three per cent and four per cent. They were promptly raised to three per cent, four per cent and five per cent and now to three per cent, 3.5 per cent, four per cent, 4.5 per cent, five per cent and 5.5 per cent.

For this reason we will be moving a second reading amendment to get the government's commitment to hold down these repayment levels for the next triennium, for the future budget years 1996-97, 1997-98 and 1998-99. We hear a lot about certainty in this place but often those people who are influenced by government decisions and clients are the ones who do not get certainty. Student groups have been trying to get such an undertaking from the government and the opposition. This may be the most effective way of getting the different sides' commitments on the public record.

I also mention that students and tertiary lobby groups have been blackmailed, effectively, and put in a situation where the government is threatening them with HECS increases or a loss of increased places for 1996-97. In no way should these groups accept the government's hollow threats. The government's lack of commitment to providing places in line with demand has already been demonstrated. In no way is such a measure dependent on revenue from another budgetary measure. This is plain nonsense.

This is part of the government's tactics to cut money from budgets wherever it pleases and substitute it with user-pays systems. Its commitment to full access to public education has been exposed as rhetoric when you have a government looking for excuses as to how to make cuts and make students pay more. There are plenty of sources of revenue for the government to provide higher education places. It is the government's priorities with this revenue that have gone awry. I therefore move the following second reading amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:

PARA.TAB: "but the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)notes that Higher Educatio Contribution Scheme (HECS) thresholds and repayment levels have now been raised by the Government for the third time since the inception of HECS;

(b)further notes that, although students have undertaken degrees with the understanding that they will be liable for a certain amount of debt, payable at certain rates, the Government has changed the circumstances of this arrangement many times; and

(c)therefore calls on the Government to give an undertaking that, in view of the proposed amendments in items 17 to 20 of Part 5 of the Schedule of the bill, neither the HECS thresholds nor the repayment levels will be increased for the next triennium, that is at least until 30 June 1999, to give students certainty in their financial commitments with the Government".

This is somewhat self-explanatory. It is designed to provide students with some degree of certainty. As others have indicated in the debate on this bill, the government is continually changing the goalposts with respect to HECS and the repayment thresholds. This is creating some degree of difficulty. It is also, to some degree, one of the reasons for a decline in demand for university places. I trust that the Senate will support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Margetts and Senator Tierney, who participated in this debate, that I will not attempt, in the couple of minutes remaining, to respond to their detailed concerns. Would a response during the committee stage be adequate or do you want it as part of the formal conclusion of the second reading debate?
—It is fine whenever it comes. Perhaps before I move my amendments.
—It will be done in committee, then. There is not the time to respond; we have to finish in about a minute.
—You will have another 18 minutes if you wanted to use it.

—Yes, but we are conscious of time as well, and not wanting to double up. I will consult whoever is going to be speaking on this matter when we go into committee. Cognisant of the time and the factors I have just outlined, this bill, which amends the Higher Education Funding Act 1988, implements some critical budget decisions to increase student places and research funding. They are very important measures in the context of our higher education and research policies. The costs of these initiatives will be offset by the re-allocation of existing discriminatory funds.

SPEECH.PARA: Delegate interrupted.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we now proceed to debate matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the debate on matters of public interest today to speak on a matter of great concern in this country and that is long-term unemployment. Several weeks ago, the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee tabled a report into long-term unemployment. It revealed the absolutely disastrous situation facing people in this country, some of whom are amongst the most disadvantaged, in terms of what is now happening in the job market right across the country.

PARA.TAB: We have had a Labor government that has been unable to grapple in any meaningful way with the scale and dimensions of this problem. The problem involves not just economic dimensions. We lose an enormous amount of productive capacity because up to 20 per cent of the work force are not fully engaged in productive and financially rewarding work. We also have a situation where special groups in society are devastated by the effects of unemployment, particularly long-term unemployment. The groups that seem to be most disadvantaged by this are the ones that are least able to defend themselves, particular those young and mature age people who find that their skills are no longer relevant in a rapidly changing work force.

There is a very high social and economic cost of long-term unemployment. Today, and in a series of speeches over the next two weeks, I want to highlight the plight of those people and also the terrible implications for the Australian economy and society of sustained levels of long-term unemployment, which under this government have risen steadily over the last 13 years. There has been a minor decrease in recent times because of the boom but it has not been to the extent that the government has indicated. We are now seeing that part of the economic cycle change again. We are now heading into a time of further increases in long-term unemployment.

The government's response to this social disaster we have on our hands has been grossly inadequate. The whole foundation of the so-called Working Nation program—and what a laughable title that is, because large numbers of Australians are not working—was to make people job ready. If you look at what the government has done to this economy over the last 13 years, you find that people can be as job ready as they like, but there is no work for them. People in Wollongong kept telling us that they have been trained and trained again and we have the best trained dole queue in the world. It is the failure of this government's policies that has created that situation. If you are going to train people it must be related to work. It is no good continually churning over the dole queue. This makes the government's unemployment figures look better, but it leads to total despair for the people involved.

The Working Nation report was scrutinised by our committee over a period of several months. What we found was that the programs that had been set up to solve the problems of long-term unemployment over the last year and a half are not delivering effective workplace training regimes that lead to sustainable work for the long-term employed.

The cruel hoax of Working Nation is that it leads battling Australians to realise that this Keating government is not really the Labor Party of yesteryear. Labor has changed; it has become very complacent and smug, thinking that it has successfully hidden this problem away from the Australian people. The plight of the long-term unemployed is off the agenda of this government. It is the purpose of this series of speeches to really highlight to the Australian people that this is still a major problem facing the country and that the government has to do something about it.

Their response to date with their labour market and training programs has only really had the aim of concealing the real level of long-term unemployment and the pain that is creating for people. In the run-up to the next election, you can see why they would want to conceal their disgraceful record in this area.

The report in today's Financial Review of Quantum Harris confirms that there is deep unrest about the direction of the Keating government in this area and in many others as well. Fifty-four per cent of respondents, despite the government trying to cover things up, have revealed that they think ALP policies are on the wrong track. Sixty-one per cent describe this Keating government as tired and say that it is time for a change.

It is issues like long-term unemployment in the fringe suburbs of our cities and out in rural and regional Australia that are causing this unease and unrest. It is not just the unfortunate long-term unemployed that are suffering now. Parents of today's teenagers fear for the job prospects of their children. Today's school children could be tomorrow's long-term unemployed people under the current policy regime of this ALP government.

The Senate committee report is full of evidence from Australians who fear that the government's programs, including so-called Working Nation, cannot deliver. The committee heard evidence right across Australia from February this year and it laid out in stark reality the picture of despair that has developed across our country under this government's policies and failure to address unemployment, particularly long-term unemployment.

They feel abandoned by the system, particularly the long-term unemployed. A submission to the inquiry from a 42-year-old woman who had been without full-time work for 12 years underlines this. This summarised the feeling expressed by many who gave evidence. She wrote, `I feel abandoned by the system, exploited by the system.' That `system' is the so-called Working Nation program and the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

The voice of despair comes from people with impeccable qualifications who find themselves out of work for long periods of time. The message is that their previous work experience and qualifications are of little help, and this intensifies their despair. Again, this is from the evidence that we received on the south-west outskirts of Sydney:

SPEECH.PARA: I have an honours degree and three post graduate diplomas and was employed in the field of personnel management for 20 years. Like many others I could not believe that if one wanted a job, one could not find one. Having failed to get a single offer, I now know what it is like to be on the scrap heap of the unwanted.

We heard evidence very similar to that right across Australia. In regions like the Hunter and the north coast of New South Wales, youth unemployment rates are a disgrace at 38-plus per cent. My previous quote related to a long-term unemployed person who is mature age, but the other side of that coin is the long-term unemployed who are young. One expert witness dealing with long-term unemployed youth said this:
. . . young people are slipping between the cracks of society . . . spending days and weeks watching TV, sleeping and withdrawing from society.
Children are also growing up in families where no-one works. At page 36 of our report, there is this quote:
By the middle of 1994 there were 703,900 children aged 0-14 years growing up in families where no parent is employed.

This was the social landscape of the Great Depression in the 1930s. In many areas of this country we are still in that sort of great depression still. Many areas of Australia have not recovered from the recession that Mr Keating gave us in 1990. He talks about economic growth on an overall average across Australia. There are some hot spots of growth in Australia—central Sydney, central Melbourne and some of the mining areas. But across the vast landscape of Australia most areas are still back in the last recession. We heard the voice of despair from the people in those areas as we moved across the regions of Australia over the time of preparing this report.

PARA.TAB: This voice of despair for the long-term unemployed comes out in not only affecting their social situation and their employment situation but also their personal situation, particularly as it relates to health. In the area of children's health, page 38 of the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The area of health shows clearly the intergenerational effects of long-term unemployment. Children of unemployed parents had 25 per cent more serious chronic illnesses, were injured more often and were more likely to suffer deafness than the children of employed parents—
Long-term unemployment has a devastating impact on men in our community. The report states:
For males aged 25 to 54 mortality rates for the period 1985 to 1987 were 17 per cent higher than for employed males.
In Aboriginal communities, which have an average unemployment rate of 30 per cent (though for some it is as high as 80 per cent), the suffering from health problems is extreme.
The scope of the despair felt by so many classified as long-term unemployed was presented by a witness from a welfare action group to the committee. He said:
The majority of the long-term unemployed have basically given up.

What I have presented today is a window on the level of despair presented by the long-term unemployed. The ALP's answers to these that they have developed over 13 years are not working, as evidenced by what we heard in every area of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I want to take up other matters relating to the long-term unemployed in future matters of public interest debates, in particular the failure of the Working Nation programs, the problems that still exist with the case management system and the destruction of jobs in the small business community. After 13 years of driving policy, this window on long-term unemployed despair should stand as a disgrace to the ALP—a government that has really given up on this problem. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) is on duty in the chamber today. During my speech outlining and quoting those heart-rending cases, he continues to read the paper. I think this just shows the attitude of this government and the reason why in this next election they should be thrown out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond to an attack that was made upon me by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), an independent member from Western Australia, in the House of Representatives a day or two ago. I assume it was an attack designed to cast him into the role of martyr again and, therefore, attract martyr votes. I do not intend that Mr Filing put a statement down in the House of Representatives relating to me which is without truth and have it go unanswered.

PARA.TAB: Mr Filing refers to a meeting held earlier this year between John Howard, myself, Eoin Cameron and Paul Filing. Mr Howard had asked me to attend that meeting because Mr Filing and Mr Cameron were very concerned and vocal about their preselections and much of their unhappiness could be alleviated by discussing their preselection with them. That was at least Mr Howard's hope. Mr Howard began the meeting with a short introduction. I got straight to the point by asking Mr Cameron which branches and which delegates had I directed or indirectly influenced to vote against him. I asked him also which branches had changed preselection delegates in the last 12 months, except his own branch at Doubleview, where he, his family and his employees had rolled the president.

Of course, he was unable to name one person or one branch. He then began babbling about the leader's representative in Western Australia at state executive and state council. In the end, when he continued to obfuscate about the issue which caused the meeting, I had to remind him of the purpose of the meeting and I used the words, `You are now only using up oxygen and the leader's time.' `We are here to hear your concerns about your preselections,' I went on to say. I then turned to Mr Filing, after despairing at getting any sensible answer from Mr Cameron, and I asked Mr Filing the same question.

He began by saying that he could not discuss it because he had received legal advice, and then he lost me in some talk about his expulsion or some such thing of which I had no knowledge. I then pressed him on the subject at hand, and the best he could finally come up with was that I had some influence with the Young Liberals. I responded that no-one, least of all me, was capable of controlling the Young Liberals in Western Australia. The meeting finally ran into the sand and, when Mr Cameron and Mr Filing left, I said to Mr Howard, `Do you now see what I've been saying?' He responded that, yes, he had noted the response of one of them in particular, and I took that to be a particular reference to Mr Cameron.

Within 24 hours, a bodgie and untrue story was reported in the West Australian by Mr Tom Salem, which is alleging to reflect the accounts of the meeting. But of course it did not. I am most certain that that story did not come from Mr Howard's office. I reminded Mr Filing during the meeting that the state president of Western Australia had spoken to every branch president within his division, including all his own supporters, and all had denied any lobbying or communication by me. It seems to me that Mr Filing has sought to transfer the branch's and the division's disapproval and unhappiness with him onto me. Of course, he is the sort of person who cannot carry his own responsibility.

There are two other matters Mr Filing canvassed. I have not got the time to read out what he had to say in detail, but perhaps my response will make sense to those who have an interest in this matter. Mr Filing also claimed that at the meeting he raised the fact that he had received a copy of the minutes of the state executive of the Western Australia Liberal Party, and there was mention in them of an expulsion or suspension motion against him, and that that particular document was an effort to undermine his standing in the Western Australian Liberal Party immediately preceding the Moore preselection.

He claims that he pressed me at the meeting about those minutes and that that was a blatant attempt, as he calls it, to undermine his standing in the party. He said that the senator—referring to me—who had been at the meeting which these minutes came from said that he had no knowledge of the particular matter in question because he must have been distracted. As it turns out, I certainly had no knowledge of them because the matter that he is referring to did not take place at the state executive. I could only imagine that at that stage, because he was so certain of what he was saying, in fact I had missed part of the meeting. But I certainly had no memory because that matter to which he referred did not take place.

Let me say this now that Mr Filing has raised the matter: the matter in fact arose, as I recall, from the party's constitutional and drafting committee because of their inquiries about Mr Filing's conduct. The essence of that inquiry was that Mr Filing had scrutineered an internal party ballot in which he had a vested interest because the results included delegates to be elected for his preselection. I have always thought it was pretty dubious practice, scrutineering your own results, but, be that as it may, he did. He took the results from the returning officer, the then state director, Mr Hook, who was quite new at the task, and Mr Hook, in his innocence, asked Mr Filing to pass the results on to the divisional secretary.

I make no judgment about it except to say that by the time the results had got to the divisional secretary, they had significantly changed, much to the benefit of Mr Filing. That caused a member of the constitutional drafting committee—I assume, as a result of a complaint—to make inquiries and prepare a report, which he did. The report was of so much concern to me, given that Mr Howard had previously raised the question of the prospect of a motion of the nature outlined—that is, a notion of censure, suspension or expulsion of Mr Filing—that I did undertake to keep an eye on things. I was so concerned about that document that I rang a member of the leadership group, together with forwarding him a document, to say that I was very concerned, I did not want to find myself compromised nor the party compromised by my efforts to smooth the waters. I also conveyed my concern in a more general way to the leader, but I did not want him drawn unnecessarily into a matter which might cause embarrassment to the party in due course.

However, be that as it may, I accepted the request of Mr Howard to have the matter resolved and the state executive proceeded to accept Mr Filing's explanation, much to my concern, although I make no secret of the fact that I was one of those people who was instrumental in accepting his explanation. That did not satisfy some of the executive, including the lawyer who had prepared the document. He asked that his vote of dissent and his disapproval of our accepting the explanation be recorded.

That is the substance of the matter to which Mr Filing refers. I would have thought he was very unwise to have raised it and to have suggested that, in some way, I had some responsibility for the matter appearing in the minutes. I understand that the drafting and constitutional committee of the party prepared, or were contemplating preparing, a set of words. Under our constitution, the words to be used for disciplinary proceedings are `censor', `suspension' or `expulsion'.

I raise one other matter. Mr Filing refers to a telephone call apparently held between me and Mr Wade Smith, who is presently the member for Wanneroo in the state of Western Australia in the Legislative Assembly. Mr Filing claims that Mr Smith told him that he, Mr Smith, had received a telephone call from Senator Crichton-Browne in which Senator Crichton-Browne said that he, Mr Filing, had been getting far too much influence in the branches of Moore division and that he, Smith, ought to sort it out or get a kick up the backside from me.

In fact, that was the first time that I had heard of this conversation. I took the liberty of ringing Mr Smith yesterday. He said that this was not the case at all. He said that the conversation had occurred as a result of a phone call from Mr Smith to me. Mr Smith reminded me that I had said that he, Mr Smith, ought to make sure that his branches were well looked after and in place because it was his preselection on the line. I said that, if a member of parliament, whichever House he was in, did not look after his branches, he did not deserve to be re-endorsed. There was no reference to Mr Filing at all, although Mr Smith told me that he gratuitously offered advice to Mr Filing that I was in no way active in the federal seat of Moore and in no way was I seeking to influence any of the branches. As I said earlier on, at my request, the state president of the party had contacted all the branch presidents within that division. They had assured him that I, either directly or indirectly, was seeking to have no influence on the preselection.

I do not think it does Mr Filing's cause any good to present a story which does not in any way coincide with the facts. It seems to me that he has been invited to do so because of the document which was tabled by me on 15 November, which he says makes false, misleading or just plain wrong assertions. In particular, he refers to the meeting with Mr Howard. To the extent that it is suggested that that document incorporated by me is incorrect, I felt obliged to respond to Mr Filing and I have done so in a very gentle, pleasant and fair way. If I disclosed the details in more robust and detailed circumstances, there would be a great deal of embarrassment for Mr Filing and it would seriously jeopardise the goodwill of any reasonable voter in the federal seat of Moore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise again today to speak on a matter that I first mentioned in the adjournment debate the other night, to the amusement of some senators, I believe. I spoke about the problems associated with the use of gambling by governments as an increasing source of revenue. I hope that, as I spoke of some of the issues which have been raised in many quarters, those people who were amused began to understand some of my concern.

PARA.TAB: What I want to do today is to place on the record some more of the evidence, which I think is important, and to underline the fact that, when governments use gambling as a means of revenue—increasingly state governments have been doing that—they ought to take account of the fact that there is a very real social cost involved with the gambling industry. If governments were more prepared to allocate some of the tax revenue gained from gambling in areas such as education about the risks involved, counselling of those who get caught up in the abuse of gambling and rehabilitation, then I do not think I would be as critical as I am, for at least that would be a recognition of those costs. Unfortunately, governments are quite happy to take the revenue gained without at all recognising the costs involved.

Let me quote from a friend of mine whom I have supported for many years, the Reverend John Tully, who runs a counselling and support centre on the Gold Coast for street people and particularly for gambling and other addicts. His organisation is called New Life Ministry at Street Level. Mr Tully has for many years worked in this area, with some support from the church and individuals like me but often with very meagre resources. Despite the fact that he has worked for years and years in this area, he has never been about to get from government any support in financial terms for the work that he does, despite the amount of revenue which is raised.

In a press release which he put out a little while ago he speaks about the need of the pathological gambler. He says that gambling addiction is a recognised mental illness like the condition described in psychiatric literature since 1980. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that the Political groups represented in Queensland become more aware of the plight of otherwise scrupulously honest individuals, business people, and family people who have:
.Lost their entire savings because of Gambling;
.Lost their employment and profession because of Gambling;
.Have a criminal record because of their uncontrollable gambling;
.Have gone to prison because of uncontrollable gambling.

They have been, he says, the victims of families broken by the gambling of a parent or friend. A real understanding of the potential of gambling to damage some individuals was recognised by Commissioner E.G. Fitzgerald in his report to the Queensland government, in which he said:

Law reform in respect of gambling needs to be approached in a comprehensive considered way. It is inherently difficult. Until a comprehensive review is undertaken, narrowly focused piecemeal action including expanding the legal means of gambling, is inadvisable.
The Reverend Tully comments:

If the Fitzgerald recommendations had been taken seriously, I believe that more money would have been directed into crime prevention prior to the passing of Legislation to expand the gambling/gaming industries.
The gambling/gaming industry, as it is linked to Casinos on the Gold Coast has funded a Community Benefit Fund—
he recognises this and certainly commends it—
which allowed some $14,200,000 to 60 community groups, between 1986 and 1995.
However, he underlines the fact that, quite deliberately:
No money from this fund was provided for:
.Community Education concerning Problem or Pathological Gambling or;
.Intervention by families of problem gamblers or;
.Crime Prevention programs in the Community—
or advertising of existing services for problem gamblers.

PARA.TAB: He gives details from newspaper cuttings from the Gold Coast of some of the associated crimes. This is not his analysis. The information has simply been culled from newspaper cuttings on the Gold Coast. According to these newspapers, crimes associated with Jupiters Casino include fraud, armed robbery, stealing, cheating, drug use and trading by some patrons. The articles mention the fact that losing gamblers may be depressed, angry and more accident prone and the fact that children had been left alone at home and at the casino while parents and guardians are gambling. The articles also mention the growth of the moneylending or pawnbroking industry. He also cites gambling related suicide; marriage breakdown because of gambling addiction; and the presence of known criminals at the casino.

An article in the Sunday Mail of 12 November struck me because it concerned students at the university where I was chaplain for 5 1/2 years before coming into the Senate. The background of this is that recently another casino opened in Brisbane just a couple of blocks away from the Queensland University of Technology. The counselling services at the university have indicated that they are now seeing students who have been attending the new casino. The headline for this article says, `Students seek gambling help'. The article says:
Most QUT students attending the Gardens Point campus walked past the Conrad Casino and many, it appeared, took advantage of the 24-hour opening.
"The opportunity and the temptation has been very great. It is more than a coincidence."
Dr Whitelaw said

SPEECH.PARA: university staff first had an inkling of gambling problems when students applying for financial aid stated they needed help because they had lost their savings at the casino.

PARA.TAB: The most recent example came to light last week when two students asked for medical certificates.
"They said they were too tired to attend lectures or to attend their examinations because they had been gambling (at the casino) all night.
"This is very serious and the feeling is that this is going to be a growing problem.
"Our concern is that the majority of students do not have a great deal of disposable income. Every penny they have is spent.
"Some see it (gambling) as an investment, but that investment does not come home very often.
"They will not be able to pay the rent. They will not be able to meet their education needs. Their education will undoubtedly suffer."
Dr Whitelaw said the university hoped that for most students, the casino would be a "new toy" that would be played with for a while and then put into the background.

SPEECH.PARA: Having a great respect and concern for students with whom I have worked in the past, I hope that his prediction does come true and that they do put that `new toy' away.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I quote from the Uniting Church Victorian Synod's statement on the Crown Casino in Victoria:

SPEECH.PARA: The development of the casino has been seen fait accompli. There has been no opportunity for the public to debate the matter and indeed there has been speculation raised as to the justice of the tendering process for the rights to build which were eventually won by the Crown Casino group. In controversial circumstances Crown has already been granted permission to make extensive changes to the permanent casino and they now wish to extend the temporary casino. These processes have been consistent with other Victorian Government activities such as the Grand Prix acquisition, the changes to the health and welfare systems and the introduction of regressive industrial legislation. In a climate of minimal consultation the public feels powerless to affect the outcome of Government decision making. The government has moved to silence the voices of opposition by limiting the power of independent authorities to which it has been traditionally accountable—

If governments are going to increasingly use gambling as a means of raising revenue, they must be responsible and use some of that revenue to rehabilitate, counsel and support those who are caught up in the abuse of gambling. Of course, I recognise that not everybody is. However, the Victorian Synod of the Uniting Church has reported in recent months that welfare agencies and financial counsellors have reported a rise in the number of problem gamblers and the problem gambler telephone counselling service is being inundated. I close with words from the synod, which are as follows:
Rather than being a purely economic mechanism, the `gambling led recovery' will be at the expense of many on low incomes in our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has made much of various programs to encourage the arts. Its big statement earlier this year about what it was doing about the arts, and in particular encouraging arts education, seems to have not been entirely successful. That is a polite way of putting that some areas, quite frankly, have had a raw deal. I am particularly concerned about those areas of arts education which, under the government's program, were to receive particular and special attention. Unfortunately, in some areas the special attention has been to downgrade the government's contribution.

PARA.TAB: I have here a letter dated 18 September 1995 from Mr Simon Crean, Minister for Employment, Education and Training, to Mr F.S. Hambly, Executive Director of the Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee, which establishes a weighting of publication data for the 1996 composite index, which significantly downgrades the creative works in the area of the arts in terms of what kind of weighting they should get for funding and other purposes. This is, I believe, an indication of the government's lack of concern for an area in which it claims to have real concern. When it comes to handing out the money, and when it comes to providing the real support, we find out what the facts really are.

The Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee has recommended to the minister that these weightings follow a regimen. To me, that seems to unfairly advantage some written research as against creative works. For example, it has recommended that a book with authored research should get a weighting of five but that a major written or recorded work should get a weighting of only one. I think that is bad enough. That suggests that poor old Beethoven would get a rating of one whereas someone who writes a book about him would get a rating of five. That strikes me as fairly absurd but the Vice-Chancellor's Committee has in fact recommended that. However, the minister thought poor old Beethoven was worth even less so he changed it so that a major written or recorded work has a weighting of 0.4, as against a weighting of five for an authored research book on Beethoven.

I must say that it is extraordinary when one looks at the definitions to see that my whimsical reference to Beethoven is not unreasonable. This is what a major written or recorded work is described as. The definition refers to:

SPEECH.PARA: A substantial creative or scholarly work such as a novel, long musical work or play separately bound and offered for sale under the imprint of a recognised commercial press or publisher or recorded on CD, video, et cetera, for commercial distribution. Musical works in this category would normally have a duration of at least 20 minutes in playing time and dramatic works a duration of at least one hour. Also includes scholarly, analytical and descriptive catalogues such as for major international art exhibition catalogues.

But here we have artists clearly set up as second-class citizens in terms of weighting for research purposes as against authored research into a book. I do not know on what basis the minister decided further to downgrade the weighting for other creative works, but it does seem to me to be extraordinary. Not only do we have an authored research book weighted at five, we also have articles in a scholarly refereed journal. Just an article rates one as against 0.4 for a symphony or a play—which has to be at least an hour—or, in fact, a novel.

PARA.TAB: I suppose it can be argued that there are other areas of funding for these matters. There may well be, but what disturbs me is the clear, uncomplicated discrimination against creative work in the weighting of publication data for the universities. This seems to me to be absolutely absurd. Even an article—in other words, something far less than an article—to a scholarly refereed journal gets a weighting more than writing a symphony does. You can put out computer software—this also has been downgraded, by the way, from one to 0.4—but computer software rates the same sort of weighting as does writing a symphony or a play.

As I say, this whole thing disturbs me, particularly in the context of the evidence given in the Senate's excellent Arts education report—a report by the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communication and the Arts References Committee which was presented to the Senate last month. I modestly say that I am a member of this committee and that I am quite proud of the report. The report deals with the relative funding model for university teaching costs, which, once again, represent, in my view, a downgrading of the arts and discrimination against the creative arts which is grossly unsatisfactory.

As the report says, the relative funding model was devised in 1990 with the purpose of discovering whether any universities were significantly underfunded or overfunded in their Commonwealth operating grants. The university subsidies were divided into 21 disciplines and the cost of teaching the various disciplines was assessed by means of three teaching cost studies. The disciplines were grouped into five clusters, the members of each cluster having similar costs, and the clusters were given different weightings. The weightings were multiplied by the student numbers in the various clusters in each university to give a notional teaching cost for each university that could be compared with the university's actual grant.

In other words, this was done for a specific purpose but the consequences were significant because the universities have tended to use them as the basis for splitting up their money internally. The sets of weights were calculated. Some examples of the undergraduate weightings are: accounting, economics and the law, one; education and maths, 1.3; computer, nursing and visual performing arts, 1.6; engineering science, 2.2; agriculture and medicine, 2.7; and so on.

The arts educators who have appeared before our committee are unanimous in condemning this model. They say that there is a serious imbalance in the allocation of resources within universities between science and the humanities, that is, arts and culture disciplines. This imbalance has its origins in the arbitrary DEET decision regarding the weightings of different disciplines for the purpose of funding allocations for universities. This different weighting flows through to departments within universities.

One of the real problems is that in the arts there is a much more direct relationship between teacher and student in the creative arts. In music, for example, you may have a situation where there is a one on one relationship between the teacher and the student, whereas in a lecture room dealing, for example, with history there may well be one lecturer to 200 or so students. Certainly when I was at Sydney university that was the situation. So it is unfair and discriminatory against those performing arts or plastic arts that are now a part of the university system as a result of the Dawkins arrangements. It is now grossly unfair that they are relatively—in my view—underfunded in relation to the specific needs they do have of a much tighter student-teacher ratio.

I stress that so far the government's great objectives which, in its great statements about the arts, it said it was supporting in the area of arts education seem to me not to have been carried out in the actual activities, in what the government is actually doing. I believe the minister has an obligation to explain why on earth creative work such as a major written or recorded work is worth a weighting of 0.4, when a book that is written about that creative work can get a weighting of five. Clearly the government is prepared to talk about supporting arts education. It is a pity it does not do something more about actually funding it appropriately.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to refer to two matters, if I get the opportunity in the time available. The first matter is forests. The government will next week announce the results of the deferred forests assessment process—a process which forms part of the flawed national forest policy. It is likely that the outcome of this DFA process will be another disaster, in the long litany of disasters for Australia's forests, for the timber workers and for the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: The processes that the federal government has established to deal with the forest debate are incapable of reaching a solution because they are fundamentally flawed in the principles they work from and their approach. The Greens have always been critical of the national forest policy and we are also critical of the deferred forest assessment process that has been born out of that policy. The national forest policy does little to protect our magnificent native forests and it is little wonder that the DFA process emanating from it will not provide any solution to the problem.

The first problem with the deferred forest assessment process is, as I mentioned, that it is part of the national forest policy. In that policy what we are looking at is the preservation of forest type museums or exhibits, because we are looking at what is called the CAR reserve system: areas that are found to be comprehensive, adequate and representative of the original forest of the south-west of Western Australia will be preserved in reserves. That `representative' nature is a big trap, as is the word `adequate'. If we really value the qualities of our forests we ought to be preserving all of those we have left before their inevitable destruction and disappearance.

The deferred forest assessment process is exactly that: it is deferred rather than protected. That means that, even though the assessment is being deferred for a fuller assessment, there is no protection for those areas from the eventual possibility of logging and from use by the woodchip industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on the outcome.

—Yes, it does depend on the outcome, as you interject, Senator Sherry, but the government should not be pretending here that it is actually protecting our precious old-growth native forests or our high conservation value forests under this process. It is simply deferring the capacity for it to be protected. It is an ongoing battle for those who already believe those last remaining forests have to be protected, so it should not ever be a pretence that it is being protected. When the government actually protects some forests then we will be able to feel that it is addressing the dilemma we have.
—Twenty-seven per cent of my state is locked up.

—It is not locked up at all; it is simply temporarily kept from the ravages of the industry. In fact, what we have to look at is the values that are being retained. They are not locked up for anybody else; they are kept for the community and for the future. They are only locking out those who would want to log it and destroy it. So, in that sense, it is being preserved for the public rather than being locked up for any particular section of the community.

PARA.TAB: The situation in Western Australia is extremely bad in relation to the state Department of Conservation and Land Management. CALM has been obstructionist and uncooperative in terms of actually setting aside areas that need to be protected from the intrusions of the woodchip industry and from logging. It has tried to interfere with the independence of the scientific advisory panel and to coerce the Commonwealth forest task force into including at least parts of some of the non-statutory zones in the reserve system. CALM has consistently withheld essential information from the Commonwealth, in relation to the process in Western Australia, except where it suits them.

There are a myriad of other examples, but I will just cite one in a letter that has been transmitted to the forest task force by the Bridgetown-Greenbushes Friends of the Forest. The letter points out that there has been a rapid deterioration in the integrity of the deferred forest assessment process, and that the concerns regarding CALM's involvement in that process have not been able to be addressed. I will seek leave at a later point to table this letter because it vividly illustrates some of the problems that have been experienced. I will table it at the end because I am running a little short of time.

Basically, we also are aware in Western Australia that the submissions from that side of the country are not fully understood by people on the east coast because the species that we have are unique to that part of Western Australia. We started off, at the time of colonisation and European settlement, with two per cent of Western Australia as forest—we now have one per cent. Any attempt to try to set up a reserve system of 15 per cent of what is left, of what was there at the time of colonisation, is going to require the protection of significant areas of karri and jarrah and other mixed forest types. That is not being addressed by the current reserve system that is being developed.

Until we develop a process which is based on a set of clear and agreed principles, operating in the best interests of the community, then we will not reach a solution to the acrimonious forest debate. The government needs to bring all the pieces together. It needs to listen to all the interested parties in the debate, including the depth of feeling in the general community. The government must act to protect the forests, and not simply keep deferring their protection; to protect the timber workers, by setting up transition strategies so that they can phase in plantations which are already there as a feasible alternative; and to protect the future forests for our children.

The current process will not do that and I challenge the government to look seriously at adopting one that will. I seek leave to table the two documents that I have referred to. One is the submission of the Western Australian Forest Alliance (WAFA) of October 1995 entitled WA's deferred forest assessment: the real report card. I simply put on the record some of the concerns that have been expressed by WAFA, the Conservation Council and others in Western Australia, regarding the crucial needs of the forests of the south-west. The second document is the letter of the Bridgetown-Greenbushes Friends of the Forest.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now go on, quite appropriately, Mr Acting Deputy President, to discuss a matter that you have raised constantly in the chamber. In recent months, Senator McKiernan has, on a number of occasions during the adjournment debate, commented on the issue of asylum seekers in Australia. I am seeking to respond to some of those comments. It is an issue that has occupied a great deal of Senator McKiernan's attention, particularly since he became the chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. It has also occupied a great deal of my time. As is so often the case in this place, senators may spend time on the same issue but they may have utterly different perspectives on the issue, as is the case with Senator McKiernan and myself on this matter.

PARA.TAB: The recent history of boat people in Australia has been one of tragedy and is likely to bring shame on Australia in international fora. We have certainly not lived up to the humanitarian ideals which we espouse as a nation. We have not even lived up to the standards we set during the late 1970s when another wave of boat people came to our shores seeking our assistance after the fall of Saigon.

I have commented many times on the extraordinary difference between the climate of welcome nurtured and created by the then Fraser government and the hostility which has been the hallmark of the current government. Australia is presently maintaining a double standard where we allow bridging visas to the extremely high numbers of visa overstayers, over 60,000, but we penalise the relatively smaller number who seek the asylum of our shores by imprisoning them. At the moment, I think we have about 800 people in detention.

I am not arguing, and I do not think anyone would argue, that Australia has to accept each and every person who comes here seeking refugee status. My own position has been that the assessment process should take its course. However, when the course taken detains young children and families who could, after a brief assessment process, be held in the community, we have to wonder whether what we are doing is humane or very punitive.

The government seems to me to have created a climate of punitiveness. When its own processes have failed, it has sought to imprison people and to validate or justify that position. When that has failed, it has again tried to use the parliament to achieve what it has not been able to achieve through its own assessment processes and through the legal processes. I am sure that we can all recall the shameful legislation brought in to declare the illegal detention to which some of the boat people were subjected as being legal after the fact. Similarly the $1 per day compensation legislation, which is not likely to pass from peoples' memories quickly.

The case of the Ngep brothers was also referred to in this place. I believe that Senator McKiernan criticised the brothers because, in spite of the fact that they had been rejected four times, they still wanted to appeal the decisions that had been made to deny them their stay in this place. Of course, that has taken an interesting turn and I hope that Senator McKiernan has noted it. He may well want to comment on it in the future. The brothers have now been granted bridging visas to allow them to live and work in the community while they seek to go to the United States to be reunited with their family who were able to gain residential status there much earlier.

Interestingly, I am led to believe that this was an out of court settlement agreed to by the government. I can only speculate about what advice the government received to encourage it to short-circuit the legal process, but I am delighted on their behalf. Mind you, to spend five years of their teenage life in custody, with the consequent damage that that will cause, is not something that they will be able to get over quickly.

The legal and legislative processes are only one part of the saga. More important is the human story. Senator McKiernan, like Senator Bolkus, makes a great deal of the fact that the people being held in detention centres could go home at any time. We are told time and time again that these people are only being held because they will not take up the option to be free. I suppose that makes good copy for media and helps to foster the image in the community which the government wants—that these people are simply here out of greed or opportunism or perhaps because they thought it would be a good idea or a way of getting free food and board. If only it were so simple.

The reality is that people do not leave their ancestral homes without good reason. They do not embark on a hazardous journey in dodgy boats without reason. They do not subject their children to danger without good reason. People flee danger. They flee situations in which they believe they are in danger, and they are prepared to subject their children to the rigours involved in such an escape bid only if they believe that the situation they are leaving is too perilous for them.

Senator McKiernan criticised people in the detention centre for putting their children through the trauma of being locked up. I do not believe we can do that unless we also criticise the government. The policy of the government to release children only if it is in their best interests and not to allow their parents to be released into the community with them is a policy that contributes to the trauma of any children who are locked up in this country. I herald with great joy the commission of inquiry that is going to be held by the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Chris Sidoti, into the detention of children at Port Hedland.

I will conclude my remarks by saying that I commend Senator McKiernan on his willingness to go to China with some of the people who were repatriated and for his staying with the issue. I just wish that he would refrain from denigrating anyone who does not share his view and I hope that our different perspectives can be reconciled at some point.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I commend you on the great restraint you have shown from the chair. The matter that I wish to raise today as a matter of public interest is the plight of the apple industry in my home state of Tasmania and also right around Australia. Indeed, at this very moment, even as I am on my feet, there is a delegation from Tasmania meeting with the federal Treasurer, Ralph Willis, to see if he will change his mind concerning the announcement he made, on 2 November l995, of the imposition of an excise tax on apple cider. The announcement, ironically, was made in Hobart, which is the capital city of the state that grows the most apples. He had been in Tasmania but had not bothered to consult with the community. He did say when he was in Hobart that he was not likely to change his mind about that issue. I hope that those people from the apple and pear growers and also Cascade Beverage Co. who are meeting with the minister at this very moment will have an impact on him to make him change his mind.

PARA.TAB: The history of this is that the federal government held an inquiry into the wine industry, whether an excise tax ought be applied to the industry, and decided that an excise tax would not be applied. But out of left field comes the announcement by the federal government that it will, instead, impose an excise tax on the cider industry. There has been no consultation with the growers, no consultation with the industry and, might I add, no consultation with the ACTU. I have a letter dated 16 November 1995 from Max Ogden, the industrial officer for the ACTU, to Mr Quinn, General Manager of the Cascade Brewery Co., which says:

SPEECH.PARA: You can quote us as being in support of our position and I will draft a letter for Martin Ferguson to send to the Treasurer expressing our concern.

Basically, these are the actions of a tired, stale, completely arrogant government. It does not think it has to consult with the trade union movement, with the growers or with the industry. It just decides to tax the apple industry, hoping that it will not affect too many people.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that there are 3,600 apple growers around Australia. Sure, a large part of those are within my home state of Tasmania, but the industry that is affected starts off with 3,600 apple growers around this nation. These growers are the epitome of small business. They are virtually all family enterprises where people have worked very hard to make a living. It not only impacts on farmers; it also impacts on the beverage companies such as Cascade in Tasmania, which makes apple cider. It has an ongoing effect for companies such as ACI, the glass manufacturer in Moonah—a northern suburb of Hobart—which would have increased its glass production and its bottle production in the event that the cider industry got a better deal and was able to expand as had been planned.

In fact, all the government is likely to get in extra revenue, as an absolute maximum, is $3 million. I would suggest that it is more likely to be $1 million or $2 million. However, if that is the benefit, let us look at the impact on 3,600 apple growers and all the beverage companies around Australia that had been operating on the basis of no excise. Why impose an excise tax on apple wine but not on grape wine? Is there some health reason or social policy reason that says that the alcohol in grape wine is more dangerous and more potent than it is in apple wine or apple cider? Of course, there is not. It is once again a cheap political move by the government as it tries to raise more money for itself because it knows that its budget forecasts are way out of kilter. The forecasts were shonky from the beginning and now, in the run-up to the election, which is being deferred and deferred, the figures are looking sicker every day and worse by the week. The government is trying to get some extra revenue, but what is the cost going to be?

It is important to realise that the impact of the decision will be substantial job losses in the Tasmanian apple industry and, more specifically, in the Huon Valley. I compliment the Liberal candidate for Franklin, Les Glover, on the stand he had at the Huon Show last weekend. I know that Senator Sherry saw it because he was down there and took a large walk around it so as not to be confronted by it. Of course, a lot of the residents there signed a petition opposing the cider tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was hardly going to come and visit you, Eric.

—Senator Sherry does not like the harsh facts of life. I can let Senator Sherry know that Harry Quick, at least, signed the petition. I do not know that he realised who he was signing with but at least he signed the petition. But, Senator Sherry, as parliamentary secretary, could not, of course, afford to stand up for the people of Tasmania by doing that!

PARA.TAB: Research undertaken in the last week by independent market research and economic analysts show that the price increase of about 28 per cent due to the imposition of excise will result in a sales decrease of cider in excess of 33 per cent. Another 45 per cent will modify their buying habits. This huge reduction in cider purchases would have an equiproportional effect on the manufacturers' demands for apples, with a net reduction in revenue for the Tasmanian apple industry. Of course, there are then the flow-on effects.

The Tasmanian apple industry has, over the past decade, re-emerged as a major horticultural export industry for Tasmania. Investment amounting to more than $50 million in new apple plantings, cool storage and packing equipment has ensured further substantial growth over the next five years. Production is set to exceed 80,000 tonnes by the year 2000. This re-emergence of the Tasmanian apple industry has been strongly supported by other federal government initiatives. On the one hand the government is spending taxpayers' money in trying to assist the industry, and on the other hand the government is trying to cut it off at the knees by imposing a tax which will have the exact opposite effect. One really has to wonder how well coordinated this government is in determining its policy. The government helps and assists the industry on the one hand and then tries to tax it out of existence on the other.

Whilst the government talks a lot about the need for export earnings, especially from South-East Asia, I remind the government that the resurgence of the Tasmanian apple industry means that the new export markets which have been established in Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and other Asian countries now account for over 90 per cent of the exported apples. The Tasmanian apple industry accounts for 70 per cent of Australia's export tonnage and one particular area—the Huon Valley in the electorate that Mr Glover will be representing after the next election—is responsible for 55 per cent of all Australian exports. This development has seen unemployment in the region decrease from a huge 16.7 per cent under Labor's stewardship to 10.6 per cent this June, so the apple industry is of vital importance to this area.

To underpin this successful export program there needs to be a viable secondary market for non-export grade apples. This market is estimated at 20 per cent of the fresh fruit crop and it is heavily dependent on the cider industry. If one takes away the monetary returns from the second grade apples that can be achieved through the cider industry, then you really do gut the whole apple industry. The net return to growers from cider apples plays an integral role in their ability to compete in international markets.

In conjunction with the investment in the apple industry, a parallel investment program by manufacturers has been undertaken. The excise on cider is a tax on the export apple industry of Tasmania and will result in substantial job losses. I urge the federal government and the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to listen carefully to the calls by the Liberal candidate for Franklin, Les Glover, to reverse this decision. If the Treasurer does not want to listen to Mr Glover, he should at least listen to Max Ogden from the ACTU, the Cascade Brewery Co., the growers and the 3,600 apple growers around this nation. I recommend to the government that it change its policy in this very important area and I urge it to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order, I call on questions without notice.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Yesterday Jennie George said that collectivism in industrial relations was too good to be put at risk by conservative ideologues. Doesn't this statement reflect a tragic harking back to the bad old days of them and us when militant shop stewards constantly opposed change, resulting in abysmally low productivity and national economic stagnation? Why won't the government distance itself from these hopeless romantics of a bygone era who, in their desperation to hang on to power, have failed to come to grips with a much more intelligent and performance orientated work force? Hasn't yesterday's statement by the ACTU leader simply exposed her as one of Labor's major obstacles in its fight for political survival? Doesn't your own uncritical support simply demonstrate why, after 13 years in government, Labor is universally viewed as tired and on the wrong track?

—The so-called ideologues of the ACTU have delivered, in cooperation with this government, more advances on the industrial relations front and more capacity to advance on the economic front generally than has ever been the case in the history of this nation. The well-deserved reputation that we had a decade or more ago for industrial strife has utterly dissipated, utterly disappeared, as would be readily apparent to anyone who travels around the region and talks to business people and others who have been so assiduously conscious of that status in the past and have been promoting their concerns about it.

PARA.TAB: It has been an extraordinary performance of responsibility by the trade union movement over that period, and it is one that should be recognised for what it is and not assaulted. Of course, the price of that responsibility, so far as the union movement is concerned, is a willingness on its part and a determination on its part to continue to fight for the right of the trade union movement to properly represent ordinary working men and women and not to see the capacity of the trade union movement to do that and the capacity of people to collectively bargain be eroded. There is no doubt that what was going on with CRA was a very deliberate attempt—a sophisticated attempt but a very deliberate attempt nonetheless—to undermine that particular whole structure of the trade union movement and the system of wage justice in this country.

There is no doubt about where the opposition stands on all this. It has been made abundantly clear on many occasions over many years. You want to abolish compulsory arbitration. You said it in 1992; you said it on multiple other occasions. You want to stab the IRC in the stomach, according to Mr Howard in 1992. You want to tackle it head on, remove absolutely its capacity to perform the kind of dispute settling role that the IRC, the commission, played last week and also undermine the capacity of that system to deliver wage justice.

The principle of equal pay for equal work has been enshrined in the law and the practice of this country this entire century. It is one of the most basic, fundamental, well-understood and universally accepted principles of them all. It was that particular principle that was being undermined, was at risk and was being attacked by you as well as by the corporate sector that you were supporting in this particular respect. That was the nature of the battle last week; that was the fight before the commission; that is what the ACTU was pledging itself to uphold—not some harkening back to the ideology of yesteryear, outdated and irrelevant. It is absolutely central to the decency of the wage system as it operates in this country and absolutely essential if we are to ensure decent wage outcomes for ordinary working men and women.

There is a fundamental gap all right in this country, as there is a fundamental ideological divide. That fundamental gap or ideological divide is between us, the trade union movement and men and women of goodwill in this country who understand what these basic principles are about and you on the other side who are absolutely pledged to assault those principles in a way that is absolutely unacceptable and absolutely counterproductive in terms of the outcome it would have and its capacity to produce the kinds of economic gains we have seen over the last decade.

Nobody has anything to be ashamed of in their performance in this matter, except you, the opposition, for the way in which you opportunistically took advantage of what you hoped would be a major industrial crisis in this country. It did not become that. It was over within a week because a bit of decency, a bit of justice, a bit of good sense and a bit of good industrial relations system applied. If you had your way—you have made it absolutely clear—you would abolish that system. You would abolish the capacity for compulsory arbitration and you would abolish the principle of equal pay for equal work.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins. Has the minister's attention been drawn to media reports following a speech by the federal opposition leader, Mr Howard, to the National Farmers Federation yesterday about the future of the single desk export powers of the Australian Wheat Board as they relate to national competition policy?
