Can the minister advise whether there is any difference between Mr Howard's stated position and the government's?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did obtain a copy of Mr Howard's speech this morning. It makes very interesting reading, I can assure you. Mr Howard made a point—and I hope you are listening to this, Senator Boswell—
—We are getting it on tape.

—Good. You tape it, Ron. Mr Howard made a point of beginning his speech to the National Farmers Federation by saying—and he emphasised this—that he spoke to the NFF as leader of the Liberal Party and also as leader of the coalition between the Liberal Party and the National Party. He said that he was convinced that the Hilmer competition reforms would deliver significant benefits for all Australians.
—Is that factually wrong?
—I have a copy of the speech. This is what he said.
—Is it wrong?
—You make your own judgment. He said he understood—this is quoting him—`some rural groups were concerned about the impact of Hilmer on country areas'. He then said this:

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the wheat industry I specifically reaffirm coalition policy to retain the single desk export powers of the Australian Wheat Board . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Hooray.
—Wait for it, Ron:

ANSWER.PARA: while they continue to serve the best interests of growers and the broader interests of the Australian community.

If imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, I am prepared to be flattered, because that is word for word what the government's policy has been since April this year. It is exactly the same position, Senator Childs, that I have stated publicly again and again.

PARA.TAB: You asked what the difference is, therefore, between our position and the position of Mr Howard. I will tell you. When I make that statement—I have been making it since April—I speak on behalf of a united government. Mr Howard, however, speaks on behalf of a divided coalition.

I will tell you what Mr Howard did not tell the National Farmers Federation yesterday. It was a very duplicitous performance. What he did not tell the NFF yesterday, nor its constituency at large, is that his major coalition partner, the National Party, whom he told the NFF he spoke on behalf of, discussed at their federal conference in Canberra in September the question of Hilmer and debated two motions. I have the minutes of the National Party conference in front of me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get them?
—Where? They fell off the back of a National Party member in Queensland, Ron. That is where I got them. These are the motions on Hilmer from the National Party, and very interesting reading they are.
—So what?

—I will tell you so what. The first motion, which was drafted by the South Australian branch, called on the party to urge extensive debate on the Competition Reform Bill—I will table this—in 1995 in terms of its likely effect on small and medium sized businesses and rural products. The motion was withdrawn in favour of a second motion, from New South Wales, which called on the party to take into account the net effect the Hilmer report recommendations will have on rural and regional areas, as well as people who live—

—On a point of order: this is well outside the portfolio area of the minister. If he wants, we will table all the motions that are put at Labor Party conferences. This is not within the portfolio of the minister. It is a party political answer. He does not say whether the motions were carried or not carried.
—It would be hard to rule out anything in this place on the basis that it was party political, but it is relevant to the question asked.

—I will read the final motion: that all of these things have to be taken into account `before the National Party takes a firm policy position on Hilmer'. So in fact the jury is still out as far as the National Party is concerned, except that Senator Boswell was kind enough—

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator Sherry. Senator Boswell yesterday, in response to a question from me, was kind enough to say that he `did not support the national competition policy of Hilmer'. Therefore it was utterly false for Mr Howard to state, as he did to the National Farmers Federation yesterday, that he spoke on behalf of the coalition in supporting the—

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He did, Senator Boswell. As the minutes of the National Party conference indicate only too clearly, they do not have a position of support. (Time expired)

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister would be aware that Mr Howard also told the National Farmers Federation that the coalition's primary industry and environment policies make `special emphasis on rehabilitation of our environment, particularly our degraded farmlands and waterways'. Can the minister advise how that accords with government policy?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The first question was about the selling of wheat. This question cannot possibly be a supplementary to the first question. As I heard it, it had something to do with the environment. But it is a supplementary to the previous question, and if the previous question was on the selling of wheat and single desk selling, how can this possibly be a supplementary question? I ask you to rule the question out of order.

—On the point of order: the question in fact was much broader than that. It referred to the speech that Mr Howard delivered to the NFF yesterday and asked whether there were differences between the government's position and the position enunciated by Mr Howard. The supplementary question is directed to the same speech.

—On the point of order: standing order 73(1)(i) says that a question should not ask `for a statement of the government's policy.' That is exactly what Senator Childs has just done. It is out of order.

—On the point of order: I want to clarify that. It may be on Mr Howard's speech, but Mr Howard's speech is not in this minister's portfolio. The only thing in this minister's portfolio is single desk wheat selling. He is not, as I understand it, the minister for the environment. Therefore, on that ground as well, Mr President, you should rule the supplementary out of order.

—On the point of order: I just want to clarify that I referred to degraded farmlands and waterways, which I believe are perfectly in the policy portfolio of the minister. I draw attention to that. I also asked how this accords with government policy.

—On the point of order: it seems from what has been read that the first question at best could be said to relate to wheat and matters surrounding Hilmer. That second question has nothing to do with either. So the mere fact that somehow you are able to pick out a couple of different issues from the same speech has nothing to do with the fact that the first question was on wheat and Hilmer and that the second question is on the environment. It is an open and shut case.

—Order! Senator O'Chee's point is clearly not a point of order because, as Senator Childs pointed out, he did refer to government policy in the matter. On the question of whether it is a supplementary or not, I rule that it is a valid supplementary because it deals with the broad issue in the first place, which was a speech. Both points are in the minister's area of responsibility.
—Could I just ask you to rule on the third point—that if it is out of the same speech, the environment is not this minister's portfolio. Could you rule on that?
—I said that both matters are in this minister's portfolio. I made that quite clear.

—Have you heard of landcare, you dolt? That is me: Captain Landcare. Mr Howard either does not know the implications of the coalition's drought policy—in my portfolio—or is deliberately misleading his rural constituents in claiming that it is environmentally friendly. It is not. The drought policies of this government and the opposition are poles apart.

PARA.TAB: Towards the end of the 1982-83 drought the Commonwealth and state governments initiated an examination of policy responses to the then drought. A report prepared by a Commonwealth-state working group of officials was subsequently released in 1983. The report recommended against almost every drought initiative that was introduced in 1982. Senator Brownhill will confirm this: it strongly opposed the use of fodder subsidies. Mr Howard in fact repeated the coalition's support, he said, for fodder subsidies for drought affected farmers. Senator Brownhill was a leading member of a Senate committee that recommended against this very measure. That indicates again that the divisions on these issues between the coalition parties are very deep indeed. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Gareth Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, representing the Prime Minister. I ask Senator Evans: does the government support individual employment contracts?

—Yes, of course we do, in the context of the industrial relations legislation and the underlying policy of that legislation, which is that such contracts not be used in a way that will undermine the capacity of workers to bargain collectively if they so choose, and to create an environment in which the principle is maintained of a capacity to bargain collectively and to ensure the union maintains its presence and effectiveness on the work site. It has never been any part of our industrial relations policy to enable a situation to be created where the reduction of union capacity to exist or to be effective on a particular site is put at risk.

PARA.TAB: That is exactly the context in which this issue unravelled and produced a dispute at CRA, because what was involved there was nothing less than an unashamed and blatant attempt—initially through the offering of large sized carrots to the workers in question to get them to sever their relationship with the trade union—to make it impossible for the unions to operate in that environment. The likely result a year or two down the track, with that capacity for effective bargaining having been totally removed, denuded, on that particular site, is that the company will move into exactly the more parsimonious mode that was referred to in the Financial Review editorial—giving the game away, as it did so clearly—a couple of days ago.

That is the reason we have adopted the policy that we have. It is not because we want to rule out absolutely the capacity of people to enter into such contracts but we want them to do that in the context of a functioning, effective collective bargaining system—a collective bargaining system reinforced by compulsory arbitration, which is exactly what you want to get rid of.

You are at odds with what has been a successfully working system for this country, not only for most of this century, but certainly unequivocally successfully for the duration of our period in government. It creates an environment of confidence between working men and women and the corporate environment in which they exist. It creates a climate of confidence between the ACTU and the government. It creates a capacity for us to deliver major micro-economic reform, which we have been delivering all this decade and beyond, and it delivers a capacity to us to produce the kind of economic growth that we have been enjoying through this last decade and, in particular, uninterrupted through the last 4 1/4 years.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of your answer, Minister, particularly the first three or four words—`Yes, of course we do'—I ask: how do you reconcile your answer with Tim Pallas of the ACTU who said today that there was now no point in workers going on individual contracts? Bob Hawke, Jennie George, a series of union leaders, government members—including yourself—have vigorously defended collective bargaining at the expense of any alternative. In fact, just last Monday you said:

QUESTION.PARA: That is a basic endorsement of the government's and unions' position on the centrality—
of collective bargaining in the Australian industrial relations system . . .
I ask you, Minister: how do you reconcile the answer you have just given with your position on Monday and with what others have been saying and with what Tim Pallas said today?

TALK.START.PARA: —He is entitled to present his own view. He is entitled to present a view on behalf of, perhaps, a segment of the trade union movement. There is no problem about that. The problem is: what about the government's view on this particular matter? We have made that view perfectly clear, and the view is exactly as I have described it.

—My question is directed to Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs. After nearly four years of tragic bloodshed and weeks of protracted negotiations, an overall settlement concerning the former Yugoslavia appears finally to have been reached. I ask the Minister if he could tell the Senate and inform the people of Australia how comprehensive this settlement is and the government's assessment of its chances of succeeding.

—As I hope honourable senators will be aware, if they can raise their eyes above partisan squabbles for the time being, last night our time in Dayton, Ohio, the presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia initialled an agreement for a comprehensive peace settlement which promises to bring peace to Bosnia and to end the crisis at last in the former Yugoslavia. Obviously, we all welcome—certainly, we do on this side; I don't know about Senator Alston—this very encouraging news that we all hope will bring down the curtain on a bitter conflict that has dragged on for over four years, with many of its worst excesses played out on our television screens in a comprehensively appalling way.

PARA.TAB: While all the details of the settlement are not yet available, the agreement reached will see Bosnia-Herzegovina preserved as a single state with a united Sarajevo as its capital. The federal state will comprise two entities: the Bosnian—that is, the Muslim-Croat federation—with control over 51 per cent of the territory, and a Bosnian-Serb republic with authority over the remaining 49 per cent of the territory.

The agreement also provides for the return to their homes of all refugees and displaced people, for free movement throughout the country, and for the full cooperation of all three countries with the international investigation and prosecution of war crimes and violations of humanitarian law—an extraordinarily important element in the agreement. It provides equally for the prohibition of indicted war criminals who refuse the orders of the War Crimes Tribunal holding appointed or elected office, and provides for human rights monitoring by an independent commission.

The peace package also contains the agreement reached between Croatia and local Serbs on 12 November for the peaceful reintegration of Eastern Slovenia, which has been a part of Croatia that has been under separatist Serb control since 1991. The overall agreement is scheduled to be signed in Paris in early December and then it has to be put into effect on the ground. An important element of the settlement in this respect is its provision for the deployment of a NATO-led peace implementation force, which is to be sufficiently strong to deter attacks against it and any conflict between the parties on the ground.

I simply say in this respect that I hope very much—and I think I represent the views of all senators here—that the United States government will be able to persuade the US Congress and the US public about the extremely important necessity of US military participation in that particular peace implementation force if it is to be effective.

The UN Security Council is now to meet urgently to put in train the suspension of sanctions imposed against Serbia and Montenegro and the lifting of the arms embargo imposed against all of the states of the former Yugoslavia. The US, working in close cooperation with the other members of the contact group—that is, Britain, France, Germany and Russia—whose representatives witnessed the initialling ceremony, I believe really deserves very great credit for facilitating this historic breakthrough for peace after so many previously failed attempts.

It was very heartening to see the commitment to make the settlement work demonstrated by all the three presidents at the initialling ceremony today. No-one, of course, underestimates the degree of difficulty in getting that implementation to work.

The most important thing of all—and this is of particular significance for those in the Australian community who have roots or relationships back in the former Yugoslavia—is that, for the first time in just on four years, the civilian populations of the relevant areas who have suffered so much as a result of this terrible conflict can now look forward to an end to the suffering and to a resumption of normal life.

That prospect brought about by compromises—overdue compromises, but very welcome ones—on the part of all the parties to the conflict in the interests of peace is really to be applauded by the world community, particularly by us, being, as we are, home for so many people from the region and for whose families we have felt and, indeed, often grieved so deeply.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Cook, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Over 12 months ago you announced that you intended to make an innovation statement. We are still waiting. In May last year you announced $60 million for as yet unspecified national science facilities. Eighteen months later we are still waiting. The computer bounty is about to expire, but you still have not announced whether you intend to extend it. Industry is still waiting. You have moved against syndicated R&D, but offered no alternative. Now CSIRO staff are going out on strike and you offer no national leadership. Do you think you should stand aside for someone more able?
—No.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question.
—You have a second innings now.

—You have given me the chance, thank you. Minister, will you explain to us why you have been unable to meet your promise in relation to an innovation statement; why, after 18 months, we still have not had announcements on the national facilities, even though your department said they would be announced in August; why you have been unable to make an announcement on the computer bounty; why you have moved against syndicated R&D without offering an alternative; and why there is a strike in CSIRO without you taking any apparent action to bring it to a resolution?

—We announced a policy initiative and innovation statement and it will be delivered—just wait your turn and you will get it. As far as all the other things are concerned, you should dare to ask a question about the computer bounty! You are proposing to abolish it; you are proposing to knock it off.
—You have a go.

—We will announce that in the innovation statement, as I said yesterday and as you know full well. As far as syndicated R&D is concerned, we have not moved against that. That is again an effort to mislead. What we have done is publish guidelines for public comment, and we are obtaining public comment on those guidelines.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the last question, the dispute in the CSIRO is a natural wage negotiation that is being undertaken. I believe the CSIRO this morning made an offer to the union in settlement to that dispute. I am waiting on the outcome of the consideration of that offer, but I expect that this matter will be dealt with by the CSIRO and the union without the government interfering.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Does the government see the last remaining areas of rainforest as a resource to be logged by the timber industry for export woodchips?
—No.

—I therefore ask the minister whether he is aware that 50 to 60 per cent of the proposed logging areas in East Gippsland are rainforest, include rainforest or are immediately adjacent to rainforest. Is your government committed to protecting what little remains of our rainforests and the endangered species that rely on them to survive?

—What this government is committed to—and we have enunciated it many times and we are working on it, as difficult a task as it is—is providing a world best protection for Australian forests, and that is what it will be in terms of the reserve criteria that have been established and, at the same time, providing a sustainable base for a viable Australian timber industry. The two are not mutually exclusive.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. In an attempt to halt the maritime strike last week, did the Prime Minister or any member of the government provide the Maritime Union of Australia or the Australian Council of Trade Unions with any explicit or implicit agreement to withdraw the sale of ANL in return for peace on the waterfront in the run-up to the next federal election? If the ANL is withdrawn from sale, is the government prepared to pay P&O compensation for the costs it has incurred in the sale process? Is it prepared to make redundant up to 400 workers both at sea and on land, or will it continue to meet, from taxpayers' money, any and all losses incurred by ANL?

—The answer is no, but I do point out that you have directed the question to the wrong minister. The sale of ANL is the responsibility of the Minister for Finance and the assets sale task force, but I have no doubt that the Minister representing the Minister for Finance in this chamber would also have answered no.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Can the minister advise the Senate about progress with the national child-care strategy in Western Australia?

—Very often it is good news that I am prepared to announce in this place. But telling about progress in Western Australia in child care is a very disappointing story indeed. In fact, the national child-care strategy was signed by both the Western Australian and Commonwealth governments in 1992. Since then, and certainly since the Liberal government has come into office in Western Australia, there has been absolutely no progress at all of the national child-care strategy—absolutely none.

PARA.TAB: A good case could be made for there being delay in New South Wales and Victoria, however, because both of those states did not sign this strategy until very much later. But as for Western Australia, Minister Roger Nicholls has taken over a portfolio with a strategy having been signed between the Commonwealth and the state for him to proceed with. Since then, he has portrayed very little enthusiasm at all for proceeding with the building and establishing of child-care places of whatever sort. The Western Australian government stands out for its total failure to participate.

What has been happening is that Minister Nicholls has requested some variations on that strategy and the agreement between the Commonwealth and the state, and I have been very prepared to agree to that. Indeed, I suggested that we could meet his needs for a variation in their contract and at the same time get on with the business of planning and getting ready to establish those child-care places. But what happens is that, when we pass back to Minister Nicholls our concessions regarding his request, he then makes another one. So I am pleased to say to the Senate that today I have forwarded to Minister Nicholls variation to the agreement for his signature, with the request and the urgent hope that we should now be able to proceed with the establishment of child-care places in Western Australia.

In fact, families in Western Australia have been missing out very significantly. The Commonwealth has gone ahead and fully implemented and funded all the 940 day care places; they have been fully Commonwealth funded, and we have been able to do that. But there are also 940 long day care places outstanding; that is about 20 new child-care centres. There is a desperate shortage of them. There certainly have been many requests for child-care places from Western Australia, including 1,200 places for care outside school hours. Families, communities, local government—all sorts of people—are desperate for child-care places to be established in Western Australia. But nothing is happening because of Minister Nicholls's refusal to participate.

The really interesting thing is that I have received letters from Minister Nicholls himself pleading for child care in the state of Western Australia. `Would we mind,' he asks, `assisting with the needs for child care by establishing family day care places?' Yes, Minister Nicholls, we are very prepared to do our bit. But it is about time that the Western Australian government played ball on a strategy that is in place but which is short at the moment of providing 940 child-care places to families in Western Australia. The pleas, as I say, come from everywhere. There are requests over and over for those child-care places. Yet Minister Nicholls is not prepared to go ahead with them.

I know and feel very concerned that, every time the minister raises an objection and we meet it, he then finds another one. I have sent him an agreement to sign. I urge him to participate and to get on with the business of getting those child-care places up and running. The Commonwealth officers stand ready, with the sites, the places; they have just about everything ready to get those places built as soon as possible. Put aside your prejudices, Minister Nicholls, and get those child-care places up.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in his capacity of representing the Prime Minister.
—You got sent up in Rolling Stone.
—Thank you. I'm glad you still read it, Nick.
—We've all read it now.

—I will give you an autographed copy, John. The youth unemployment rate in Australia is now 29 per cent, which is a higher rate than that existing when your government brought in the Working Nation statement. Under your government the youth suicide rate has more than doubled, and yet only eight per cent of the money that your government committed to it in the budget has been spent in this financial year. In the Age newspaper, on 7 September, your Prime Minister, Mr Keating, promised that, in reaction to the mounting crisis in youth affairs, he would announce a policy within one month. That was 2 1/2 months ago. Minister, would you please tell us whether this is an example of Mr Keating breaking yet another promise, an example of his arrogance, or evidence that there has been a failure in national leadership on youth affairs by the Prime Minister and he is out of touch with youth? (Time expired)
—I am sorry, I do not have a brief on the status of the consideration of that particular matter, but I will get an instant answer, I hope, and get back to you as soon as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I draw the minister's attention to a report in the Australian today about `clouds of radioactive gas drifting over the New South Wales towns of Wagga Wagga and Ladysmith'. Has the minister read this report and, if so, is he concerned about health risks associated with this production of radon gas? Does he agree with CSIRO scientist Dr John Dighton's assessment that `the point to make is that this is the result of land degradation and tree clearing'? What is the Commonwealth government going to do to monitor the build-up of these gases and to reverse the detrimental effects of land degradation and tree clearing?

—I have seen the report in the Australian that Senator Woodley refers to. In relation to your question about the health risks, I cannot say to you that I have been briefed about the health impacts of this reported concentration of radon gas, but I do think it would be unfortunate in this circumstance if unnecessary community alarm were generated over this particular matter. I might ask my own portfolio agencies or, if appropriate, some agencies in either Senator Collins's or Senator Cook's portfolio to perhaps provide more information on that at a later stage.

PARA.TAB: As you say in your question, according to the report, land degradation is the suspected cause of the radon gas. I can say that the Commonwealth, as well as all state and territory governments, has agreed on the need for action to discourage land clearing and to promote vegetation establishment and retention. There is a strong recognition from governments that we will need to work closely together if we are to achieve this objective. As we know, the problem of land clearing does not respect state boundaries and solutions really have to be developed for this issue at a regional level. Although the Commonwealth has a leadership and a coordination role to play, the fact is that responsibility for land management lies with the states.

I ought to say that I do believe that progress is being made. I particularly welcome announcements made by the New South Wales government, the Queensland government and the Western Australian government of measures to better regulate land clearing. There has also been positive action in most other states in relation to support for programs to assist protection of remnant vegetation, including covenanting programs. For example, New South Wales has recently decided to direct more resources, including additional staff, to voluntary nature conservation on private land.

That is not to say the Commonwealth does not take its own responsibilities in this matter very seriously. We have a major and a continuing investment in dealing with the problems of the Murray-Darling Basin through the Murray-Darling Basin initiative. In 1995, the Murray-Darling Basin Commission will spend over $88 million on a series of programs to manage the basin's river health and water quality.

The Commonwealth has also taken action through the national landcare program that Senator Collins spoke of earlier, and we are targeting vegetation conservation and enhancement through the save the bush program and the one billion trees program. We will be contributing a very substantial amount to these programs over the year ahead. I must say that we will be continuing to press the states on this issue. I have raised land clearing as a high priority at ANZECC discussions and council did endorse the need for accelerated action on this issue. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. It follows on from the answer you gave yesterday on the Coastwatch contract. I ask: in relation to payload/range performance and in relation to operations under the Instrument Flight Rules, what performance specification differences are there between the RFP and the contract signed with Surveillance Australia in relation to the Britten-Norman Islander? Will you please release the contract for public scrutiny, an obligation you have as minister to account for the appropriation of public funds?
—Obviously, I do not have those specifications with me. I will take your question on notice.
—You had all the details yesterday.
—Not the specifications that Senator MacGibbon asked for. I will take that on notice and see what I can provide to you.
—Minister, you will not forget to provide a copy of the contract, too, will you?
—No, he didn't agree to that; he will forget that.

—He has an obligation to do so. If I have to give you a lecture on ministerial responsibilities, I am quite happy to do that. I ask: is the contractor fully meeting all the contracted performance standards now that all his equipment is on line?
—I am advised that all the equipment that has been supplied and is now in operation is meeting the expectations.
—Not the expectations.

—The expectations and the criteria laid down in the discussions with the successful bidder, which was National Jet Systems. I do not think all the equipment may actually be on line yet but I think most of it is. I am advised it is all being provided in the time scale according to the contract that was signed. I point out to Senator MacGibbon that the Department of Administrative Services and the Customs Service went to great lengths to ensure that this contract process was done in great detail, in view of the controversy that occurred some years ago when a previous contract for Coastwatch was let.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Is it a fact that the government is proposing to reduce family allowances for 100,000 Australian families?
—No, it is not, Senator. Unless you can give me some further detail of any specific example, no, we are not planning to cut family allowances.

—I have in my hand the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995 which does precisely that. I ask the minister: has she not seen this bill? Has she not focused on the fact that family payments for families of 16 and 17-year-old students will have a reduction in their family payments? The annual rate, which is now $564 and in some cases $741, payable per fortnight, will be abolished and the amount of $250 will be paid each six months—that is $500. I point out that $564 minus $500 is a loss of $64 and $741 minus $500 is a loss of $241. (Time expired)

—I do have some information about this matter. To the extent that I can assist you with the details, it is important to say that I am advised the press release you put out claiming that people will lose $741 is incorrect. At the moment we have two sets of payments that people can decide to take for children over 16. They can go under Austudy or the Department of Social Security. We are now bringing those two payments under DEET to make it easier and simpler for families. It is important that you remember that in most cases those who will lose, will lose about $32 each six months. Very few will, but some will. The most important thing to know is that if families are not eligible for Austudy, they will continue to be eligible for the family payment. There seems to be a misunderstanding on that point. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to Mr Keating's gratuitous advice to the Japanese people in Osaka this week in which he advised them to clean up their capital gains tax rules. Rather than telling the Japanese government what it should be doing with its tax policies, should Mr Keating not focus more on the results of the latest Yellow Pages survey on small business which indicated that key areas of concern were government taxation, too much bureaucracy and lack of incentives? Is this not another example of Mr Keating's ability to give gratuitous advice overseas when he is incapable and unwilling to confront the changes needed back home?

—I do not think Mr Keating's advice to the Japanese government on that or any other matter is gratuitous or regarded or seen as such by the Japanese. They are a bit enraptured with the Prime Minister at the moment, frankly. They think he is a very classy performer indeed. They think that with absolutely ample justification because what we have seen from Mr Keating in the run-up to the Osaka summit has been a performance of great brilliance and great finesse and one that has been very important to the Japanese because nothing mattered to them more this year than bringing that Osaka conference to a successful conclusion.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that Australia has been one of the real policy engines driving the APEC process from the outset and particularly over the period since the Bogor declaration was conceived and passed and in the last 12 months. The willingness of Mr Keating to engage in very frank dialogue with his interlocutors, to talk in a very effective fashion about the economic problems of the—

TALK.START.PARA: —So why did you call him a rubber stamp?

—I did not call him anything of the kind. I just engaged in a bit of clearing away the dust from the arena in which he could properly do the real stuff that mattered. I was playing a mere sweeper role with Senator McMullan.

PARA.TAB: It is in that environment that what Mr Keating has to say to the Japanese or anyone else on issues like capital gains tax, tax administration, macro-economic policy or micro-economic policy is taken immensely seriously. You are talking about someone who has an enormous degree of credibility internationally, an enormous degree of credibility in the region, not least with the Japanese, just as he continues to have an enormous degree of credibility at home, not least with the business community.

I know what the business communities say about our side of politics and I know what they say about your side of politics when they get away from the airwaves and away from the microphones and cameras and have an opportunity to give an honest assessment of what they think of you. You would not want to read it, I can tell you. You would not want to print it. You would need asbestos gloves to hold it. The top end of town is very impressed with the quality of the economic management that they have been getting out of this particular government and they continue to be impressed. They are deeply underwhelmed with what they see confronting them across this particular chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I understand that this morning in Melbourne you addressed the second international forum on aluminium ships. Do you believe that the Australian shipbuilding industry's target of $1 billion in exports by the year 2000 is achievable?
—Mr President—
—Is this small business—aluminium ships?

—As minister for construction, I am responsible for shipbuilding policy in Australia's private sector. It is a very enjoyable task to deal with an industry that has grown so rapidly in the last decade as a result of the very strong encouragement from the Australian government and the policies that we have helped them with. If you had said 15 years ago that the Australian shipbuilding industry would be an export oriented industry employing 6,000 people with nearly $2 billion worth of turnover—last year exports in fast ferries amounted to around $200 million; a third of the world's market for fast ferries comes from ferries produced in Australia—people would have suggested to you that that was an impossible achievement.

PARA.TAB: The industry has grown rapidly. It is an industry of which all Australians should be very proud. I think some of those on the other side would have noticed that in Tasmania, in Hobart with Incat and in Western Australia near Kwinana there are quite substantial shipbuilding facilities. There are also facilities in South Australia, Queensland and New South Wales.

The Australian Shipbuilding Association brought this forum together which people from all around the world have come to to discuss the latest innovation and technological developments in using aluminium in shipbuilding. It is interesting to note that people are coming from around the world to develop partnerships with Australia, because we do have the technological edge in these fast ferries. That is a great credit to Australian companies, the managers and the workers for the way they have developed this industry in recent times.

The government, of course, has provided substantial assistance through the tax concession program, through the R&D grants and through the cooperative research program to assist this industry. For the future, the industry is looking at developing the fast ferry concept into a fast cargo ship on the same design that would be able to take our value added manufactures from Australia, for example, to South-East Asia within two or three days sailing time compared with 15 to 21 days sailing time, which would be a great advantage for our industry.

I would also say that there are a couple of issues that the industry will deal with and discuss with us, one of which is whether we accede to the OECD agreement amongst shipbuilders whereby they want to eliminate all subsidies, grants and supports for shipbuilding so that there is proper free trade in that industry. I have indicated that, unless the Americans in particular accede to that OECD agreement, Australia will maintain a waiting position. We do not believe that we should accede to the agreement unless it is going to be one which all the major shipbuilding countries accede to and accept its rules. Of course, this will affect any discussion when the present ship bounty, which has been very successful, is due to expire in mid-1997.

Congratulations should be given to the shipbuilding industry in Australia. The shipbuilders and their employees should be congratulated for building a first-class, world-class industry. They have a target to say that they want to be to fast ferry building in the world's market what Boeing is to the aircraft industry. It is one in which the Australian government gives them full support.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Gareth Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to last Monday's question time and your enthusiasm for quoting editorials on the CRA dispute. Why is today's Hobart Mercury editorial not right when it says:

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister's most noteworthy comments on the dispute are memorable not for achieving an end to the row, but because they saw him with his feet in his mouth.

QUESTION.PARA: . . .. the Prime Minister's misplaced optimism revealed a complete lack of touch.

PARA.TAB: This row has been nothing short of a political disaster for Mr Keating.

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that your government has completely mishandled this dispute from start to finish by abdicating its responsibilities and allowing the trade union movement to dictate terms to the detriment of both the workers and the nation?

TALK.START.PARA: —I know the quality of analysis in Hobart Mercury editorials is usually pretty sophisticated, but I think on this occasion it is not an analysis that I would share.
—It is puerile.
—It is puerile. That is not a bad word, Senator Panizza—one with which you are very familiar, indeed; and so you should be.

PARA.TAB: The role that has been played by the Prime Minister in settling this dispute is clear and unequivocal, and it is on the record. I spoke about it earlier this week. He made a number of phone calls, not only before he left the country but while he was away, and they were absolutely crucial in getting that initial agreement together and in getting the company together with the ACTU, which had not been the case before the Prime Minister's intervention and which was frankly acknowledged by the company spokesman, Mr Davis, and others as being a crucial element in the movement forward of the particular issue.

The particular agreement that was reached, and described by Mr Pallas as constituting a basis for the settlement, in the discussion between the two sides on the Wednesday night was absolutely crucial in laying out the basic foundations for what subsequently happened. Later on, that temporarily broke down on the basis of a further disagreement between the ACTU and the CRA, but the basic strategy of getting the matter before the commission to resolve the basic issue of equal pay for equal work was one that was very much the product of the initiative of the Prime Minister.

We are all delighted—I know you are not delighted—that this matter has been resolved as expeditiously as it has, and in such a principled fashion as it has, and in such a way that reinforces the system as we know it, as it has. I know you are not thrilled with any of those things, but we are pleased with that because this goes to the heart and soul of what has kept this nation together for so long and what has created such a productive environment, particularly over this last 10 years of very sustained economic reform.

The Prime Minister's role in all of this was wholly constructive, recognised as such by the CRA as extremely helpful in getting the parties together, getting the basic parameters of the dispute in shape and, in particular, marking out this strategy of getting the matter before the commission where it has been so successfully brought to a conclusion as a result of the decision of the commission and the ongoing negotiations that are flowing from that.

Let us have no more of this churlishness and self-evident disappointment on your side that you did not find yourselves confronting a bigger blue than you did. The blue was a significant one because it involved basic issues of principle. It has been resolved in a way that reasserts and reaffirms those basic issues of principle and has left egg on the face of your side of politics for the approach that you adopted from the outset, which has been wholly discredited by the outcome from the commission.

We have had a reassertion of the principle of equal pay for equal work, which is something you are obviously deeply uncomfortable with and deeply hostile to. It reasserted the value and utility of compulsory arbitration which you are directly and unequivocally opposed to. It reasserted the notion of a proper role in the system for collective bargaining and the trade union movement, something you are also deeply unhappy with. So it has been an excellent week for the Prime Minister in all those respects.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Minister, would you also agree that the Mercury was wrong when it said:

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the dispute occurred under a Labor government, not its conservative foes. It was not a taste of what would happen if John Howard became prime minister; it was the reality of what was occurring with Mr Keating in The Lodge.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may have occurred under a Labor government but it was also resolved very quickly under a Labor government, and it would not have been resolved—could not have been resolved—under your government because you would have had no system of compulsory arbitration to bring the matter to fruition. You would have created an environment where it was absolutely impossible to get an amicable settlement of this. That is the kind of prospect and vision that opens up for the Australian society if you lot get into government—a vision of an absolutely empty landscape so far as industrial harmony is concerned. It is a very proud record of this government in that respect and we would see nothing like it if we had the misfortune to have you running the place.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I ask the minister: Isn't it true that the recent funding crisis of the Australian Federal Police and the National Crime Authority has resulted in reduced efficiency in crime fighting? What is the government's plan to remedy this situation, which is having a drastic effect on law and order?

—Mr President, you can see that they are running out of questions if they had to beat this one up very quickly. The answer is no. For the details of the answer, I refer you to Senate estimates of the other night where the NCA and the AFP responded to your series of questions.
—Does the minister deny that there has been a cutback in overtime by the Australian Federal Police? In particular, I refer him to the situation in Western Australia.
—I think I answered that part of your question in respect of your first question. The relevant officers traversed all these issues and I will stick with my answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer the minister to the coalition's commitment yesterday to provide all Australians with access to fast digital computer quality services that will lay the foundation for a vibrant and internationally competitive communications service industry into the 21st century. Will your so-called innovation statement, which we still have not seen, address the availability and current prohibitive price structure of high speed data transfer technology or ISDN in order to stimulate Australia's online service industry and provide all Australians with access to the information superhighway?

—This comes from a senator who is a member of a party that wants to abolish the computer bounty and then spend the money that is not in the budget elsewhere in doing little tricky and slippery things as the John Howard science prize. I know how the information technology industry sees the coalition.

PARA.TAB: This question may be an effort, as a late clawback, to try to gain some credibility, but the essence of it is: what will the innovation statement contain? I know you are getting nervous, because you know it is going to be a good statement. Therefore, you want to try to prise out some of the details from the statement in advance. I note that Mr Howard said that his next headland speech would be an innovation statement, but then he brought down a headland speech on defence. That was to sort of cringe to Asia again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you see what Maggie Thatcher said about that?
—In fact, I did not.
—Fascinating.

—She said `fascinating', did she? I do not quite know what `fascinating' means, but at least Mr Howard knew that the old anti-Asian cringe would characterise your defence policy. I also note that the innovation statement that he was going to bring down has been delayed.

PARA.TAB: All I can say is that this is a bit like Senator Hill at the ANZAAS conference in Geelong last year, when he ran around and asked journalists, `Have you got the minister's speech? I want to see if he's got any good ideas in it that I can copy in the speech that I'll be delivering after him.' In other words, typical opposition policy is to see what Labor is doing and see whether you can match it. Let me give just one example of the most spectacular somersault I have seen from the opposition in some time: Mr Costello said, `We will do exactly what Labor does on superannuation.' That is what you did—great policy performance! You changed completely.

As far as the innovation statement is concerned, I am not going to give any previews in this chamber. You will see it soon enough. When you do, stand aside in the rush for applause and approval by the Australian science and technology sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, now that you have seen, by the announcement yesterday, what we are going to do in providing all Australians with access to faster digital computer services, what are you going to do to match it or better it?

—The answer is the same: we are going to bring down a comprehensive statement on science and technology. It will not be a little bit here and a little bit there but it will be a fully comprehensive statement which shows true vision as to a direction. It will not just buy off this little group or that little group but it will be a comprehensive interface of all of the policy settings. The opposition, as I said, will have to wait and see what that is. It will be here soon enough.

PARA.TAB: One of my colleagues suggested to me that the only sort of science prize that the opposition is capable of awarding is to kids in a kindergarten for meccano displays, because the opposition's level of science and technology understanding, as exemplified—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Could you please direct this minister, the one who received a bronze medallion from his own backbench for the first draft of the innovation statement, to actually answer the question and stop digressing?
—Order! Your point of order again is facetious, and I will not take any notice. I think the minister has finished.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Supply of Munitions to Papua New Guinea

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts asked me a convoluted question yesterday, but essentially it boiled down to: what was the origin of the piece of ordnance that was supposed to have been discovered in Bougainville? Our deciphering of the numbers on it suggest the origin was South Korea.

—I was asked a question by Senator Brownhill relating to the government's response to the House of Representatives report Driving the road dollar further: inquiry into the efficiency of road construction and maintenance. The government's response to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure report on driving the road dollar further has now been finalised and is expected to be tabled in the current parliamentary session. Many of the recommendations in that report have in fact now been implemented. The details of the implementation will be set out in the government's response.

—In response to a question by Senator Reid on 16 November about sealing the hard stand area at Canberra airport, I have been advised by the Federal Airports Corporation that neither the corporation nor the Royal Australian Air Force has a current program of works to reseal the hard stand area at Canberra airport.
—I want to make clear that I understood Senator Harradine's question.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —In case it should be misunderstood, Senator Hill, I want to make it absolutely clear that Senator Harradine is quite right in terms of the basic family payment for those transferred from family payment under DSS to DEET. I misunderstood your question. I admit that there will be a reduction for some families.

PARA.TAB: I am quite clear that your figures of up to $751 are incorrect. For the majority of those families the loss will be $64 a year; that is, $32 twice a year. If you do have a larger number of children and you do not become eligible for the higher rate of basic family payment there will be a drop of some $250.
I think they are the figures you gave, but they are different from what I understood was in your press release. To the extent that I was in error, I apologise to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Harradine this day, relating to family allowances.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important issue. My question was: will the government be reducing family allowances for 100,000 Australian families? The minister responded no. Then I asked—

TALK.START.PARA: —She represents Carmen Lawrence.
—I hope you listen to this because you might be voting for the measure. Like the minister, you do not know anything about it. You do not know what is happening.

PARA.TAB: There will be a reduction in family allowances for 100,000 Australian families. The figure of 100,000 comes from answers to questions I put on notice at the estimates committee. That is the government's estimate. It estimates that 100,000 families will be affected. I put out a press release indicating that that would occur. Now you have confirmed it will.

The Student and Youth Assistance (Budget Measures) Amendment Bill will replace existing family payments for 16- and 17-year-olds with a new so-called basic student payment. As the bill says, 15-year-olds can get it, but 16- and 17-year-olds will not get the family payment if they are in secondary school.

Many parents will be outraged to discover that instead of getting family payments at the rate of $564 or $741 for a larger family, which is payable fortnightly now, their student child will get only $500 per annum in two six-month payments. The loss in the latter case is $241 a year. The loss in the former case is $64 a year. There will be those reductions.

Furthermore, when I said that there will be $741 lost in family allowances, that is by reading the legislation. If you have a look at the legislation you will see it means that, instead of the parents getting family allowances, not only will it be reduced but the reduced payment would go to students 16 and 17 years of age. I believe there has been a bit of a fix-up since this press release came out. The government is in a panic and saying, `We can now, by regulation, make sure that it goes to the parents.' The legislation says:
Subject to this Part and the regulations, the Secretary must, on receipt of a person's application—

SPEECH.PARA: that is a 16-year-old or a 17-year-old; they are getting into the welfare state and filling in forms pretty early these days—
. . . grant basic . . . payment to the person in respect of a year or a part of a year, if satisfied that in that year, or part of the year, the person is, was or will be:

PARA.TAB: (a) at least 16 but under 18; and
(b) an Australian citizen or a permanent resident of Australia; and
(c) a secondary student.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation which we are going to discuss says, `He must pay it.' I understand that the minister's office is now turning handstands because of the horror that this will cause about 100,000 families, maybe up to 180,000 parents, who receive the family payment. There is some concern. The government is saying that it can do it by regulation.

PARA.TAB: I will give you a bet—I am sorry; I do not think we are permitted to bet in this chamber. I will say right here and now that I will guarantee the government will have to bring in an amendment to its bill. Even if that occurs, there is still a rip-off under way. The rip-off is as I stated in the chamber and was not denied by the minister.

She did not know that family allowances were going to be reduced. How many in the government know that allowances are going to be reduced? What about the opposition? How many of you know that you are probably going to vote—or are you going to vote—for a proposition that is going to reduce family allowances? Stand up and say whether you are or not.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Patterson, and under the order of the Senate of 28 September 1988, I ask Senator Crowley—which is now a bit late—why question No. 2370, put on notice on 23 August 1995, has remained unanswered for more than 30 days and what is the answer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 74(4), I seek leave to read a question which I placed on notice and have the answer that I received read in the Senate. I will not insist that the answer be read for reasons that I will give if I am given leave.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question concerned is question on notice No. 2422. On 20 September I asked the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan):

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the value, quantity, source country and species of any timber imported to Australia, on a State-by-State basis, for the 1990-91, 1991-92, 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.
(2) For what purpose is each species imported.
(3) Is it a fact that white beech has been imported from Germany for use in Queensland tourist resorts; if so, what quantity and value.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer could well be one of the longest answers ever given. It occupies over 200 pages and includes the full description of the quantities, species and value of timber imports from such countries as Malaysia, Indonesia, Bolivia, Fiji, Honduras, Vietnam, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu et cetera. The quantities are enormous and the species include many which could be grown here.

PARA.TAB: The 200 pages of information would require, if I insisted that the answer be read into Hansard, a considerable number of trees to be harvested to provide the paper. That is ironic, since I believe the answer should not be set out in 200 pages of incredible amounts of information and value of money but could and should be zero. Therefore, I will not insist that the answer be read. But I point out to senators that those 200 pages of Hansard of Tuesday 21 November make very interesting reading indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Prime Minister (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Crane this day, relating to industrial relations and individual employment contracts.

SPEECH.PARA: My question to Senator Evans was a very simple one: does this government support individual contracts? Senator Evans, at the beginning of his answer, said, `Of course, we do.' He then started to put up all sorts of fences and umbrellas around that particular answer.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to make about the Weipa dispute—the strikes in the coal mines, the strikes on the wharves and all the other interference flowing from this case which has just gone through the Industrial Relations Commission—is that everything that was done to disrupt business and individuals in this country was absolutely and totally unnecessary under the existing law. It is crystal clear that the law does not in any way interfere with the rights of individuals who wish to accept the offer of a contract from a company.

Under the legislation, all that was required with the dispute at Weipa was a notification to the commission. That could have been done by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton—it could even have been done by Senator Evans under the government's own legislation. Yet we had this reckless, stupid, costly—

TALK.START.PARA: —It could have been done by CRA.

—You know this, Senator Forshaw. This was reckless, stupid, costly action by the ACTU. We also discover with this dispute that there is no remedy for innocent parties, either through the neutered secondary boycott provisions in the legislation or through a mechanism for civil action. Under the legislation, all people have to do is stop the strike action within 72 hours after notification to the commission. There is no effective way of dealing with it.

PARA.TAB: The central theme of my question is the division developing between certain members of the government and the unions. The Prime Minister returned to the country yesterday saying that the federal government was not anti-contract. There has been a number of statements on the matter from ministers in this place, including Senator Evans, and from Tim Pallas, the ACTU advocate. Also causing much heartburn to the Labor Party, we have seen the re-entry of Bob Hawke, former Prime Minister and former President of the ACTU, into the role of industrial advocate.
We had a statement today from Tim Pallas, who said that the IRC had a role in protecting collective bargaining and unionism from attempts to undermine them. That is true. But he went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Commission doesn't do it, what we have been able to demonstrate through this dispute is that the trade union movement is capable of doing it.

In other words, he is saying that every time there is a dispute we can expect to see such action being taken. Jennie George describes it as `Mexican waves', there to overcome the 72-hour clause in the act. I suggest that we will see a continuation of that sort of activity with all its attendant costs.

PARA.TAB: As far as this dispute is concerned, the reaction of the government and the trade union leadership is, unfortunately, a return to the bad old days of the 1970s and 1980s and the way things were done at that time. I would have thought that the responsible thing for a Prime Minister or any other minister to have done in relation to this dispute would have been to quickly notify the commission and have it dealt with in the proper way without the unnecessary damage that was inflicted on industry, individuals and families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane's comments demonstrate that he thinks this dispute started only a week or two ago. He demonstrates that by his quite spurious proposition that all that needed to be done to get this matter into the commission was for the minister or some other party to simply notify the commission of the dispute.
—Read section 99 of the act, my friend.

—Senator Crane, you know and I know that the system is a little more complex than that. What you have to remember is that this dispute started well over two years ago. It started when the company, CRA, set out on a deliberate course of discriminating against employees who wished to remain under the award system by coercing, enticing and bribing them to abandon the union and the award system for a considerable wage increase. That is when this dispute started. There has been a clear policy by CRA across its sites throughout the mining industry to drive the union off its sites using the ultimate power of if you offer enough money, you can eventually buy anyone out.

PARA.TAB: What transpired after CRA had embarked upon that course—and in a speech last week to the Senate I gave an instance of that at another one of its mine sites, the Peak Hill goldmine—was a series of proceedings in the Industrial Relations Commission. On quite a number of occasions, the union and the ACTU were in the commission pursuing this issue, seeking to have the discriminatory tactics of CRA stopped and seeking to protect the position of people under the award. There were proceedings in respect of Bell Bay and in respect of Boyne Island smelter. They have been going on for quite some time, and this has been acknowledged.

Hundreds of thousands of dollars were spent in legal costs by the union movement in trying to have this issue dealt with. Even though they obtained some favourable decisions from the commission, CRA's basic approach was to thumb its nose at that and continue on its merry way, until it reached the point when the award employees at Weipa went on strike. When they went on strike, what was CRA's reaction? To endeavour to bring down the full force of tort law upon them by seeking to sue them for massive damages.

CRA's approach was once again to seek to impose economic ruin upon a number of individual workers who were there simply seeking to protect their rights and to prevent being discriminated against. That is what led to the widening of this dispute. When all else had failed, because CRA refused to recognise its actions were contrary to the spirit and the intent of the industrial relations legislation, it then widened to a national dispute.

Whilst we do regret that it had to come to that situation—no government likes to see that happen, and I can assure you, Senator Crane, that union officials do not welcome having to recommend that course of action—it reached that stage in order to bring this matter finally to a head. It has now been resolved within a week. Within a matter of a few days we have seen the greatest backdown by a company hell-bent on destroying unions in this country for a long time.

Hopefully, companies like CRA and others will now recognise that they can't discriminate against workers and that there is a system in place which not only recognises individual contracts and enterprise bargaining but also recognises the right of workers to have collective bargaining and not to be discriminated against. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on what has been said so far in this debate. I think the result of the CRA dispute calls for congratulations to the Industrial Relations Commission. The commission has a very proud and long history in this community, and it has shown the benefits that come from the Industrial Relations Act. That act depends upon the existence of registered organisations for its operation, and it has operated very well in this case.

PARA.TAB: I notice that much criticism has been made of the various parties in this matter—whether it be people from the unions, from government or from the company itself. I think at this stage the wise course is to praise everybody who has made a contribution to the settlement of this matter. Clearly, very high principles were at stake in this issue and it seems that those principles have been vindicated.

It is proper that people who do an equal amount of work equally well over an equal amount of time should, as a matter of equity, be rewarded in the same way. That is one principle that has been vindicated. I think it proper that a company should be given loyal and proper service. At the same time, I believe future industrial peace and future productivity in Australia will be best preserved if these registered organisations which are at the heart of the way our industrial relations system operates are preserved. The union movement is a fundamental example of what registered organisations are supposed to be.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to the government's innovation statement.

He has been talking about the innovation statement for the last 12 months. In that period he has made a lot of definitive statements about what he is going to say in his innovation statement. We now know that it is not going to be his innovation statement but that of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: On 9 May this year, in answer to Senator Chris Evans, Senator Cook said:

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone else is pulling their weight in terms of developing an innovation culture in Australia in the lead-up to the innovation statement . . .
In a supplementary answer, he said:

The government has indicated it will bring down a formal statement on innovation in around August this year. As a consequence of setting ourselves that task, which is directed to making Australia the premier location for science, technology, engineering and innovation in the Asia-Pacific region, we have been in consultation with all of Australian industry on a sectoral basis. Each industry sector has been consulted. Over a thousand people have been spoken to directly. Our science community, many of our primary researchers, institutes and the CSIRO have been consulted.
He goes on to say:

I released a report which contains all of the recommendations the Australian community has made about inventing an innovation culture for Australia. This will be important feedstock for the innovation statement when we bring it down in August.
Then in June, Senator Cook again said:
I can say quite categorically to you, Senator—
in response to Senator Hill—
that industry confidence in the innovation statement rides quite high.

He again talks about his thousand consultations with leading companies, organisations and individuals around Australia in all capital cities and major provincial centres. Again, on 8 June, he talks about interested individuals putting in submissions so that they can respond to his final report. In all of these instances, Senator Cook talks about the famous innovation statement which will be delivered in August.

However, today Senator Hill, after asking Senator Cook about the innovation statement we are still waiting for, also asked about some syndicated research and development. Senator Cook, in response to that question on syndicated research and development, claimed that consultations had taken place within the industry—and I ask you to remember all that he said in last May and June about the thousand people he had seen and all of the consultations which had taken place all around Australia.

Let me say: this process has been a complete farce. On October 25, which is some four or five months after Senator Cook spoke earlier in the year, letters were sent by Ausindustry to the Macquarie Bank and other syndicate providers. An advertisement appeared in the Financial Review of October 26 announcing a series of consultative meetings—this is in October—the first of which was held on October 30 at the Sheraton Hotel in Mascot.

The deadline for receipt of submissions was November 15. The IR&D board meets to rubberstamp the changes to the finance scheme guideline today. The consultative process described by Senator Cook gave the industry little more than three weeks to respond. Indeed, if a submission did not arrive until the deadline, Ausindustry would have had only seven days to consider it.

So much for all of Senator Cook's previous statements regarding his innovation statement being put down in August. Obviously, he is not in control of his portfolio—not that he ever has been. He continues to be very long on speech making about what he is going to do but, in effect, does absolutely nothing.

In conclusion, let me say once again that the economics committee on 15 December 1994, I think, put down a report on the CSIRO in connection with the case for revitalisation. It is now 22 November 1995 and the government still has not responded to that Senate report on CSIRO. If anything is indicative of the minister's irresponsibility and his inability to handle his portfolio, it is the fact that, even after 11 months, his department and he, on behalf of the government, cannot respond to a Senate inquiry which was held over 12 months ago and whose conclusions were brought down 11 months ago. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Yesterday at the National Farmers Federation conference, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, made a statement on the same subject. I will quote him correctly, because I think the biggest problem is that Senator Collins hustles and bustles and goes on with bluster and bluff and then does not tell the full story but only ever tells half of it. Telling the full story and telling it exactly, yesterday Mr Howard said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am convinced that the Hilmer reforms will deliver significant benefits to all Australians.
We will ensure that these benefits are passed on to customers through achieving competitive markets and monitoring prices in areas of national monopoly.
The reform of public utilities and non-traded goods and services will have a major impact on the cost structure of the rural sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to take the opportunity to take note of the answer given by Senator Collins to a question from Senator Childs concerning the export power of the Australian Wheat Board. I think Senator Collins should realise that using the single desk as a possible wedge between the Liberal Party and the National Party will fail. He is wasting his time on a petty little game.

PARA.TAB: Last Friday the shadow minister for primary industry, John Anderson, and the Leader of the National Party, Tim Fischer, restated the National Party's clear-cut support for single desk selling for the wheat industry. On Tuesday this was reaffirmed in a formal joint statement, which included the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition reaffirms its commitment to the single desk as a fundamental plank to ensuring stability and confidence for growth and investment in the industry as it restructures itself for the twenty-first century.

Senator Brownhill said the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, yesterday confirmed that view. When speaking to the National Farmers Federation annual meeting in Canberra, Mr Howard said that the coalition would back the board's powers while it continues to serve the best interests of both growers and the community. Clearly it does.

PARA.TAB: Before I point out why the board does, I just want to say the vesting powers of the Australian Wheat Board are entrenched in Commonwealth legislation. The powers would have to be changed by legislation passed through this federal parliament.

Clearly, the single desk is in the national interest and of benefit to both growers and the community. The single desk is estimated to be worth a considerable sum to the price received by the Australian Wheat Board on export prices—the original Booz Allen report said between $2 and $4 a tonne; the United States Department of Agriculture has said up to $26 a tonne; and other observers and commentators have said it has been worth up to $40 per tonne.

Hilmer deals with the extension of micro-economic reform in Australia. The single desk is about preserving Australian wheat growers' interests, trading internationally not domestically. The red herring of Hilmer is just not appropriate at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add weight to my colleagues' comments in regard to the Australian Wheat Board and the support the coalition gives it.
