TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I refer to an undertaking given to the Senate by the government during the debate on the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1995 on Monday to incorporate in Hansard the response to a facsimile sent by the ACT Ngunnawal Education Aboriginal Corporation by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free). I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the minister's reply.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The reply read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon. Ross Free MP
Minister for Schools. Vocational Education and Training
22 November 1995
Ms Lynne Holten
Chairperson
ACT Ngunnawal AECG
P0 Box 286
WODEN ACT 2806
Dear Ms Holten

I refer to your facsimiles of 25 October 1995 to myself and a number of other Members of Parliament and Senators concerning the possible impact of the restructured Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program (AESIP). I am replying as Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, including responsibility for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education.

You raised a number of issues about the possible effects of AESIP funds being allocated through per capita arrangements from 1997. The restructure of AESIP into two elements—Supplementary Assistance to be paid on a per capita basis and Strategic Results Projects for time-limited strategic projects to accelerate progress to achieving `National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy' (AEP) goals—has been put in place as part of the Commonwealth Government's response to the `National Review of Education for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples'. The Review identified that some 80 per cent of funding under AESIP is for recurrent purposes, rather than strategic initiatives. It also identified that, as a submission based program, AESIP has not resulted in those States and Territories with the highest numbers of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students necessarily receiving the highest levels of AESIP funding.

In response to Recommendation 37 of the Review, the per capita element of AESIP will be introduced from I January 1997. By replacing annual applications for funding with demand-driven per capita funding, education providers will be able to plan their educational services in the same way as they do with mainstream funding, that is, the number of students enrolled will determine the level of services required. Apart from a small number of exceptions, this restructuring of AESIP has been welcomed as a more transparent and more equitable way of allocating supplementary funds.

In addition to per capita arrangements, State and Territory Governments which increase their commitment to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education will be able to bid for additional Commonwealth funding under the Strategic Results Projects element of AESIP. This means that the level of AESIP funding provided by the Commonwealth in 1997 in those States and Territories may total more than 100 per cent of 1995 AESIP funding levels. I ask you to note that the Australian Capital Territory Department of Education and Training, and Canberra Institute of Technology are currently generously funded under AESIP in comparison with many other States and Territories.

It will not be known exactly what level of funding education providers in the Australian Capital Territory will be entitled to under AESIP per capita until the 1996 enrolment data can be used to determine the allocation in the first instance. 1997 enrolment data will determine the level to which, if at all, each education provider's allocation will need to be adjusted.

As States and Territories have the constitutional responsibility for the education of all students, including Indigenous students, the vast bulk of funding for preschool, school and vocational education and training comes from the State and Territory Governments, not the Commonwealth. AESIP, as the Commonwealth's principal supplementary funding source, provides additional educational services for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students to accelerate the goals of the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy (AEP); basic education services for Indigenous students have been, and remain, the domain of mainstream funding.

You were concerned about the capacity of the Australian Capital Territory's Department of Education and Training to respond to the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs (MCEETYA) Taskforce's National Strategy for Education for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders unless they had access to additional Commonwealth funding under AESIP. Primarily the National Review's recommendations that were directed to MCEETYA are those recommendations which require State and Territory government, not Commonwealth, action for their implementation. However, the Commonwealth has provided additional AESIP funds as a major contribution to sharing the responsibility and the commitment with State and Territory Governments for implementing some of the areas of need identified in the National Review through the Strategic Results Projects element of AESIP.

You were also concerned that the introduction of per capita AESIP would provide some incentive for systems and sectors to compete for enrolments. Mainstream funding is also enrolment driven so if student numbers increase so do resource allocations. Conversely, if student numbers decrease so do resource allocations. Additional enrolments, however, require additional services to be provided which is why per capita funding is the only sure way to achieve equity between education providers. I recognise that education providers both within and between systems and sectors do compete for students and will continue to do so. The Commonwealth would not wish, however, to deny the right of Indigenous or any other students (or their parents) to make choices about which system or which sector would be the most appropriate for their education.

Please contact and arrange a meeting with Mr Peter Buckskin, Assistant Secretary, Aboriginal Education Branch of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Mr Buckskin's telephone number is (06) 240 7722. Not only is Mr Buckskin the head of the Branch which administers AESIP, he is also one of the senior Departmental officials who will continue to be involved in bilateral negotiations.
Thank you for writing to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
ROSS FREE

DEBATE.TITLE: APEC LEADERS MEETING IN OSAKA, JAPAN

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I table the statement made today in the House of Representatives by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on the APEC leaders meeting held in Osaka last week.
—I present the 18th report of 1995 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following report: No. 25 of 1995—Commonwealth Law Courts Building, Melbourne. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee's 25th report for 1995 relates to the proposed construction of a purpose-built Commonwealth law courts facility in Melbourne. The building will provide accommodation for the High Court, the Federal Court, the Industrial Relations Court and the Family Court. The site for the proposed development is located on the corner of William and Latrobe Streets, Melbourne, directly opposite Flagstaff Gardens. The estimated total cost of the building, including fit-out costs and rise and fall, has been agreed at $108.4 million.

PARA.TAB: In 1987 the government decided to provide clearly identifiable and purpose-designed Commonwealth law courts buildings in each capital city to accommodate the courts and associated staff and facilities. The Attorney-General's Department aims to provide the judiciary, legal practitioners, court staff and the public with court facilities which meet the requirements of security and access and have a positive impact on the social and physical environment.

The four jurisdictions currently occupy space in Melbourne at four separate city locations. At all locations the accommodation does not provide adequately for the operational and growth requirements of the courts. In addition, the level of security achievable in these buildings does not provide acceptable protection for judges, staff and the public. That was very evident when we visited the buildings before we had our public hearings.

During the development of this proposal the Attorney-General's Department advised that several options were investigated. These included: refurbishment of the existing accommodation, fit out of leased premises, acquisition of an existing building and converting it to a courts building and building a purpose designed facility. The comparison of the options provided to the committee indicates clearly that the construction of a new court complex on the Flagstaff site represents the best value for the Commonwealth.

In agreeing to the project proceeding, the committee has recommended that the Attorney-General's Department consult with the Victorian government regarding a number of issues, including the possible sharing of library and child-care facilities. The committee has also recommended that the Attorney-General's Department continue consultations with the Community and Public Sector Union to resolve issues such as space allocation, building facilities and amenities.

I was very impressed with the proposed building. I am pleased to see that Senator Cooney is in the chamber because he has traversed me through some of those old buildings on more than one occasion. I hope that the beautiful old existing building is preserved. I believe it will be. The whole concept will provide a very impressive entrance to the legal precinct in Melbourne. I do not think anybody will be upset about that.

The committee had a few minor concerns about this development, particularly in relation to parking at the parking station which is adjacent to the site. All in all we were very impressed with the proposal and, as I said, it will provide quite a spectacular entrance to the legal precinct of Melbourne which Senator Cooney knows so well. In commending the committee's 25th report for 1995 to the Senate—we have been working very hard this year—I point out that to date in 1995 the committee has reported on projects valued in excess of $1.2 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Calvert for presenting the report of the Public Works Committee which announces the very timely construction of this building in Melbourne. I know that this proposal has been discussed for some years by a number of attorneys-general, including Mr Lionel Bowen, Mr Michael Duffy—he pressed very hard for this building—and Mr Lavarch.

PARA.TAB: I commend the foresight of Chief Justice Michael Black who has done outstanding work to get this building up. He was a magnificent advocate and is an outstanding chief justice. I am glad to see that the Family Law Court will go into that building also. That would be of great joy to Chief Justice Alistair Nicholson who is also an outstanding chief justice. He has had battles over the years with all sorts of people and all sorts of authorities. It is good to see that he is now about to go into a building that is worthy of the jurisdiction that he presides over.

The courts building will be in the legal precinct of Melbourne as Senator Kemp would know. The county court, the supreme court and the magistrates court are all situated at the corner of Lonsdale Street and William Street. This site is one block up towards Flagstaff Gardens, which is a magnificent place for the courts to be. It is close to Owen Dixon Chambers where perhaps the greatest legal minds in this nation are housed. The bar has consisted of outstanding people such as Chief Justice Owen Dixon. His quality of advocacy has not failed or diminished over the years. It is good news you bring to us, Senator Calvert. Keep the good work going.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1995HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the amendment moved by Senator Margetts on behalf of the Greens, the government opposes the amendment. This government introduced HECS in 1989 to ensure that those who gain a higher education make a contribution to that education. On average, the contribution is only about one-fifth of the cost of the study.

PARA.TAB: But HECS is more than that. Repayment of the contribution is income contingent, and students do not have to pay any contribution up front. They only have to make repayments when they can afford to do so. Also, contributions from HECS are forwarded directly to universities when paid up front or to the HECS trust fund, which in turn is spent on higher education.

The package of initiatives the government is seeking does not breach these principles. The savings gained are spent on higher education. The measure only impacts on those who can afford to repay their debt. The savings are achieved without an increase in the HECS debt of any Australian student. Without the savings, expenditure on new places and research cannot go ahead. Australia will be worse off for that.
This comprehensive budget-neutral package has the support of the AVCC. Yesterday in a press release, Frank Hambly, the Executive Director of the AVCC, said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the bill is rejected there will be reduced opportunities and access for new students, and reduced funding for research infrastructure.

The impact of the budget initiatives for additional places in Queensland is dramatic. With the additional places provided in the budget, the participation rate in Queensland will reach the national average over the next four years. Without the additional places, Queensland will remain a full percentage point behind the average for the 17- to 34-year-old population.

PARA.TAB: I also want to comment on proposed amendment No. 2 from Senator Margetts. It deals with the question of proof of citizenship. I just want to make the following comment. An Australian birth certificate will be accepted as proof of citizenship. Universities will not be required to check documentation for all students. Students will be required to declare their citizenship status on enrolment. Over their course of study, the declaration will be verified on a sample basis. The AVCC has endorsed this approach.

I have a comment to make about Senator Bell's amendment; a question on the savings from the citizenship measure. Savings from the government's proposed changes to HECS for non-citizens are only one component of the total savings in the government's higher education package. The estimate of savings is based in part on survey research by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on migrants' intention to take out citizenship. The government has taken into account, in estimating savings, the likely behaviour of permanent residents in response to the amendments to the act. That concludes the government's response at the second reading stage, and we commend the bill to the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I amend my second reading amendment to read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:

PARA.TAB: "but the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)notes that HECS thresholds and repayment levels have been changed by the Government for the third time since the inception of HECS; and

(b)further notes that although students have undertaken degrees with the understanding that they will be liable for a certain amount of debt, payable at certain rates, the Government has changed the circumstances of this arrangement many times; and

(c)therefore calls on the Government to give an undertaking that, in view of the proposed amendments in items 17 to 20 of Part 5 of the Schedule of the bill, neither the HECS thresholds will be decreased, nor the repayment levels increased, for the next triennium, ie at least until June 30 1999, to give students certainty in their financial commitments with the Government".
I would like to thank the sharp student groups who were listening to the debate, which does prove that some people do listen to these debates.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond briefly to Senator Margetts's amendment, which is really slapping this government with a feather. In effect, she is saying that because this government has misled so many students on so many previous occasions in relation to HECS thresholds and rates of repayment, she now wants an undertaking from the government that they will not again mislead them. That is a very generous approach. But the real question is: what faith can students now have in this government in circumstances in which they have been misled so often? This government will, no doubt, give the undertaking, premised on them being successful in the next election.

PARA.TAB: It would be interesting to hear Senator Schacht's response. The government has not hesitated to promise the world in the past, so I presume that it will do it again. It will promise Australian students that it will not decrease the threshold and it will not increase the repayments over the next three years. Come an election victory, it will take no notice of that promise. This is the government that has promised the students before that there would be no up-front fees, there would be no increases in HECS and the thresholds would not be reduced. That is against a background of so many other broken promises in so many other areas.

This is the government of the l-a-w tax promises; it is not a promise, it is law. The tax cuts will be implemented by a new government, Mr Keating said before the next election. Come the election victory, the promise was forgotten. This is the government that promised that there would be no new taxes or increased taxes. I do not have to remind people of the wine tax attempt and the building taxes and the increases in other sales taxes. This government takes no notice of its promises at all. It promised pensioners that all pensioners would be taken out of the tax system. It was inconvenient after the election, so it was abandoned. One can go on. There are so many instances of promises made and promises forgotten as soon as an election victory has been achieved.

What is the point of asking this government to promise again? They had their opportunity and they failed. They have been put to the test and they have lost. I would be much more comforted if I knew that an undertaking given by the minister now to students would be meaningful, but I have no basis at all on which to believe that.

Having said that, I guess it is rather hard to vote against Senator Margetts's amendment because at least it does put on paper the fact that the government has previously misled students and that HECS thresholds and repayment levels have been changed—that is, the threshold reduced and the repayment level increased—on three different occasions since the inception of HECS under this government. As I said in the second reading stage, it is so unfair on students who have in effect entered into a compact with this government in relation to the cost of provision of their education that the government would pay so much and they would pay a share to be repaid on a certain basis. But unilaterally time and again the government changes the rules on Australian students.

I will not oppose Senator Margetts's amendment, but I certainly do not have the confidence that she apparently has and I do not think there is any reason at all why a student should believe a word that this government says in relation to HECS. I have no doubt at all that if they are successful they will do what they have done in the past and HECS will increase, repayments will be accelerated, as they are trying to accelerate them here today, and the threshold will again be reduced. Australian students would be much smarter to learn from having been misled before and not allow this government the opportunity to do it again.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to put on the record that we reject the amendment moved by Senator Margetts. However, to save the Senate's time, if we lose the vote on the voices we will not call a division, but we do strongly oppose the amendment. This government has a very proud record of a substantial increase in the number of people going to tertiary education, which has been one of the most significant achievements of this government in 13 years. We are very proud of it. We think this is an unnecessary and mean-spirited amendment, but to save the time of the Senate we will not call a division if the vote goes against us.

—Of course the government will lose on the voices because the entire rest of the Senate will be supporting this and the entire rest of the Senate wants these words to be included in the act of parliament. This amendment may be described by Senator Hill as a slap with a feather, but I ask those listening and also members of the coalition to recognise that, by including these words in the act of parliament, we are helping those who take the trouble to read the legislation to notice what the government has done.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill rightly described the litany of broken promises. Senator Hill rightly attributed to the government some actions which should make members of the Labor Party hang their heads in shame and also encourage people to treat very carefully any promises.
But having this written down in an act of parliament is so much stronger and we are so much more able to remind people of what it is that is happening here.

I do not treat this matter as lightly as that. I treat this matter seriously indeed, and it is very important that it be included. The Australian Democrats will not be not opposing the amendment, as Senator Hill put it; we will actually be strongly supporting it. There is a difference, and I think it is important to make that distinction. There is nothing more to be said by way of supporting the actual content of what is said here as it is accurate. It is important that it be recorded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that Senator Margetts's (a) and (b) are statements of facts—I do not think anybody in the chamber would deny that—and (c) appears to be a natural corollary, as it seems to flow from (a) and (b). For that reason and although it is a most unusual proposition, I am rather attracted to the amendment, to be quite frank.

PARA.TAB: I must say in relation to this amendment that the government is uncertain as to where it is going. In answer to questions that I placed on notice in estimates committee hearings the government admitted that they just did not know how many Australian residents were, for example, British subjects not required to apply for permanent resident status. I do not propose to go into the government's answer as it is on page 208 of volume 1 of additional information received by the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee from DEET.

Whilst on my feet I might say that I am grateful, as I am sure the whole Senate is, for the department's diligence in the way it attends to the questions that are raised and the responses. That has been my experience. They can only say what is the actual situation. I am not suggesting at all that they are involved in actual policy decisions. Naturally they are involved in developing policy. I feel they should be commended for the way they handle requests.

Be that as it may, I think what we are facing here is the old salami tactic. What concerns me about the proposals concerning payment of up-front HECS is that people who are resident non-citizens will be treated in a different manner from those who are entitled to HECS. They will be treated in a different manner so far as that is concerned, but obviously they are not going to be treated in a different manner in the area of taxation—and nor will their parents. I know of resident non-citizens whose families have been paying tax for years. That tax would have gone into the pool of government receipts for expenditure in areas such as health, education and the like. The government appears to have a different and unequal attitude now.

As has been said by other speakers, it is ironic that we are now being asked by the government to accept a principle which is inherently contradictory. You can deal with some students in a discriminatory fashion when it comes to HECS, but you make them tow the line when it comes to taxation. I know taxation is not the responsibility of DEET. DEET, and the minister particularly, should have an overall picture.

The people I am referring to are very, very unhappy because of the fact that the income earners in those families have been paying tax for many years—in a particular case, for 18 years—at the same rate as resident citizens. Now you will make the students in that family pay up-front HECS but you will not lessen the taxation burden on their parents.

It is a salami trick. Under those circumstances, it is desirable to call on the government to give an undertaking that, in view of the proposed amendments to items 17 to 20 in part 5 of the schedule to the bill, neither the HECS thresholds nor the repayment levels will increase for the next triennium to 30 June 1999, to give students certainty in their financial commitments to the government.

It is a nicely worded amendment, particularly paragraphs (a) and (b), which flow and which are facts. Therefore, I support it. I am certainly opposed to the proposed amendments that discriminate against resident non-citizens.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: 1.Schedule, page 8, item 15, proposed subsection 106PB(2), omit "at any time before" substitute ", at any time before or after".

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this amendment is to amend the bill so that voluntary repayments can still be made by persons earning from $20,000 per annum to the compulsory threshold of $27,674 per annum but allows those persons to stop making payments, if they want to. Once they have started making payments, they are locked in under the present system. The rationale of why it is called a compulsory payment is beyond me if, at some stage in one's life, one feels one could make these payments and accelerate the payments; but then circumstances change. That makes it extremely difficult. There does not seem to be an understanding that circumstances can change. For various reasons, not necessarily to do with income, persons are unable to continue those payments.

PARA.TAB: There are two matters associated with the amendment. It is about the threshold and about the ability of a person to pay accelerated payments voluntarily.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Regarding this amendment from the Greens (WA), the government is introducing an additional flexibility for HECS debtors by offering them the option to begin making repayments against their debt before they are required to do so. In return, debtors who take up this option will receive a 10 per cent reduction in the level of their HECS debt.

PARA.TAB: The amendment proposed by the Greens will enable the HECS debtors to make only one repayment instead of ongoing repayments in exchange for a 10 per cent debt reduction, effectively devaluing the government's HECS asset. The cost of this proposed amendment would be up to $50 million over four years. That is not an insignificant impact. We oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The cost of their amendment is $50 million?
—That is what I am advised.
—You must be kidding.
—You never know in this game. You want to be very cautious. Fiscal conservatism is now needed by you, Senator Hill.

—Here again the government introduces a figure plucked from underneath its armpit—$50 million; it is just laughable—on the assumption that, if this amendment passes, all those who enter a voluntary repayment will make one repayment and then nick off. That is what the minister is saying. How stupidly clumsy can you be in your assessment of values—$50 million, just like that, on the assumption that everybody is going to make one repayment and then run away? That is what you said. That is the only way you can come up with a number.

PARA.TAB: You do not know how many repayments they will make. They might make 19 repayments. As Senator Margetts rightly said, life is life and they may not want to continue the voluntary repayment. To come in with another one of these threats—to wave $50 million in front of us and say, `That's going to be the cost'—is so misleading as to be tantamount to criminal. It is silly to expect us to believe that number and it is silly to oppose an amendment on the basis of a number such as that. If that is your only opposition, Minister, I suggest that it is baseless.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The impact of Senator Margetts's amendment would be as follows: if you made one part-payment of a dollar, you would then be eligible for the 10 per cent reduction. That would be it. You would get the 10 per cent off your HECS.
—Is that how you calculated it?
—Yes, because if everybody—
—But you are inviting people to do that, to take the $50 million off.

—No, we are anticipating—and with some anticipation of student organisations—that if the Greens' amendment went through there would be an immediate campaign run by student organisations, nevertheless Greens or Democrats or anyone else, saying, `This is how you save yourself some money: pay a dollar now as a part-payment up front, get your 10 per cent knocked off your HECS and do not pay any more until a much later time.'

PARA.TAB: The committee would have to be a bit naive not to expect the various student organisations—which are always looking for ways of saving the funds of students they represent, quite rightly from their perspective—to organise that. It would spread very rapidly through the system. We have made a calculation that that would probably occur and that we would therefore lose $50 million over four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that on some of these questions it might be better to wait until each of us has made a comment. That might save the committee time because you will be able to answer them all at the same time. I thank the minister for that response. However, I would think there are a lot of things that have occurred by regulation in the Senate. It is probably quite feasible that there can be phrased—either as an amendment to this amendment, if it is necessary, or as a regulation, the like of which we see on a constant basis—the means by which a rational basis can be made for a pro rata adjustment to the discount that is available to students taking up this threshold.
—But you would disallow the regulation.

—The minister claims that we would disallow the regulation. The fact that some instruments—a la regulation—are disallowable is very important. That means that we can take a watching brief on what occurs. Sometimes, unfortunately, it is by accident that we do find these things. But in the case of the ability to make a rationale so that the government is not immediately going to put itself up for the liability of $50 million, I am sure it is within the capability of the government to actually phrase such a regulation. I do not think it will be too difficult—
—But you would disallow it, because you don't want to pay HECS. That's the fundamental philosophical difference.

—I think the rest of the community has greater belief in the system than that and I believe that none of these problems is insurmountable. If that is the way you believe decisions are made, I guess you might be relating things to the way you think yourself. But I can guarantee from the Greens' point of view that, if you were to so put a well-framed regulation which dealt with this issue, we would not oppose it. Therefore it is not beyond the realms of a semi-intelligent government to be able to deal with this in such a way that there would not be a $50 million liability by assuming every student who is unable to continue making payments is immediately going to rort the system.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been advised that this act has no structure to make regulations. We would have to further amend the act to give it the power to make regulations. There is no amendment before us to give it the power to do that. This is a typical example of where, if you try to do things on the run, you will end up with some pretty big loopholes and difficulties. Because we do not have an amendment before us to enable this legislation to establish regulations, the point you raised, Senator Margetts—and I accept your integrity in doing so—in this case is impossible.

—I thank the minister. If we are now ready for any of the other amendments, maybe we could defer the vote on this amendment to give a chance to frame a possible amendment to the amendment which will deal with the minister's concern. We are happy to be of assistance here.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Reynolds)—Are you moving that way, Senator Margetts?

TALK.START.PARA: —If it so suits the committee I would be happy, if it is possible, to adjourn the vote on this amendment until we have a chance to frame a possible outcome. If the government has some wordings that it feels would be suitable, I would be happy to hear the wording that it feels would be suitable to deal with this issue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a little more faith in students than the government has. It is sad to hear Senator Schacht demonstrate so little confidence in students. We do not think students would deliberately abuse the system in the way that you say they would. We would like to think that student organisations also have a little more public morality than what you apparently give them credit for.

PARA.TAB: However, it seems to me that the flaw in Senator Margetts's amendment is in fact that the student who makes the decision to make early voluntary repayment on the basis of the lower threshold does get a substantial advantage for having done so. Therefore, to have the right to sort of opt in and opt out after taking that advantage would seem to be unfair to the community as a whole. The community as a whole is basically funding higher education.

It seems to me that the only way to draft it fairly would be if you had a formula that somehow allowed for recovery of a proportion of the 10 per cent discount if the student opted out of the arrangement that they had entered into. That would obviously be extremely complicated. I do not know at what rate you would set it out and what repayment mechanisms you would include in legislation. I certainly do not think it is the type of amendment that it would be possible to draft on the run—not to draft effectively.

There would also be a quite difficult debate on principle—what would be the appropriate level of repayment? In other words, if students had taken the 10 per cent benefit and had been making repayments for 12 months, will there be a formula that takes into account the length of repayment under the voluntary system? It strikes me as a complex and difficult issue and not one that would be benefited by delaying this amendment for a few minutes.

A better solution, I would suggest to Senator Margetts, would be to watch this amendment go by. I recognise that she makes a fair point: students' circumstances may change and there could be difficulty for them subsequently in continuing their repayments. Therefore, perhaps some provision of fairness should be inserted that would recognise that occurrence.

I would leave that task to an incoming government. If I am right, it will be one that is a bit more sympathetic to students than the Labor government has been. If that is so, this matter can be addressed after the March election which, in all the circumstances, might be the best approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you are voting against it?
—As it stands, yes.

—Before we consign this particular proposition to history, which seems to be the way Senator Hill is suggesting we should go, we really ought to look carefully at what is suggested here. The opportunity to begin voluntary repayments is an opportunity which should not be denied anybody. It is an opportunity that the government is offering but, as is usual in the history of the HECS saga, it is not a simple offer.

PARA.TAB: There are strings attached, it seems, once you have entered the arrangement. Unlike the situation with HECS overall, where the government can unilaterally change things at a whim to suit itself, students entering this voluntary repayment system are locked in. That is the way the deal has been done so many times before: students are expected to consistently obey while the government has the opportunity to change the rules. I wonder why that is.

The HECS debt is not like other debts. It does not come into operation, as far as repayments go, until a certain threshold of income is reached. The government is also introducing a discount for this voluntary repayment opportunity. The government invented this mess. The government has changed it on the run—unilaterally—several times already and the changes have all been the government's way. Yet the minister representing the government in the chamber today, Senator Schacht, tells us that further changes, equitable though they may be, should not be made on the basis that changes should not be made on the run.

Minister, this whole thing has been changed on the run. Year after year we come here and see further changes proposed by the government. This time we are told, `No, we cannot look at these matters because it is all a bit hard.' I want to know why, in designing a voluntary repayment opportunity, you designed something which locks people in and does not recognise what life is all about—that situations and circumstances change for people as well as for governments.

One-off repayments should be possible. That is the way the rest of the world works with debts incurred in other situations. Why has the government designed something which is so complicated, which is capable of being changed to benefit the government but not the students? It is not a truly voluntary repayment system because, once a person enters into it, it seems to become a different version of a compulsory system.

Senator Margetts's amendment should be accommodated in some way by the government. With the entire resources of the government at the disposal of the minister, I cannot understand why it is all a bit too hard to consider and accept. I accept the minister's invention that $50 million could be lost to the government overnight if all these students repaid $1 and got out of it that way. It was an evil mind that recognised that possibility so quickly. It was certainly beyond me; I did not predict it. But if that problem has been identified, surely something could be done reasonably equitably if this amendment were delayed sufficiently long to find the way.

If it took the minister 30 seconds to think of a way to knock off $50 million, surely he could think of a way to stop it equally as quickly. I know it is a bit of a challenge, but if the purpose of this amendment is to bring about a voluntary repayment system which does not penalise the volunteer, surely the minister could direct some of his imagination to that problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might have an idea that could assist here. Page 8 of the bill mentions the additional amount. There is no actual payment to the student; it is a matter of the liability being reduced in relation to the debt. You do not have to extract it from the student.

PARA.TAB: This is not a matter of whether you have to continue to force a student to make payments; it is a matter of the liability being reduced only if a student continues to make the payments. I suggest that one way of dealing with that comes from page 8, part 4, section 15.2, where it says that on a person first becoming liable to pay an amount to the Commonwealth under subsection 1, an additional amount equal to 10 per cent of a person's relevant debt is taken to have been paid in reduction of that debt providing those payments continue.

You do not have to make up any complex tables. This is not a matter of whether you have to retrieve money from people. Perhaps you could just indicate that the discount is available to people who continue payments. The ability to withdraw from the payments if circumstances change does not create a problem for students whose circumstances do change. Maybe that is the answer to it.

Instead of inventing complexities, there might be a means of amending that section to make sure it is clearly understood that it is not a payment, it is a reduction in the debt. Providing those payments continue, that might be the answer to the problem. Can I formally put that as an amendment to my amendment?

TALK.START.PARA: —Has it been circulated? Do you have it written out?

—You asked for a proposal; I am putting a proposal. I would be happy to write it out. You said that this was all too difficult. I have put a proposal but now you are saying, `We don't want to look at it.'
—I am not saying that at all.
—I am happy to put it in writing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, the opposition has indicated it is not willing to support your amendment; neither is the government, so I think it is reasonably clear. I am not trying to be arrogant in saying, `We don't want to consider your amendment because it is an indication that the numbers are not here for whatever your amendment is.' But it is very difficult to say, `Well, consider this. Perhaps this can be an amendment you can look at.' When we are at the committee stage it is a bit loose to suggest that we ought to now `consider this' or say `perhaps this may work'.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that philosophically now neither the government nor the coalition support the amendment you are proposing in whatever form you are trying to suggest. I will leave it at that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think the minister is quite accurate in saying that I am philosophically opposed to what Senator Margetts is doing. I think she has got some merit in her argument. That is why I said that at a future time it ought to be looked at again.

PARA.TAB: I am not sure, from listening to her amendment on the run, whether that amendment is going to work effectively either. At what point does it cease to have effect when she says, `If it is not provided that payments continue'? If people take the penalty, in effect, of coming forward to the voluntary arrangement and do that for some years and then circumstances change through no fault of their own and they have to opt out, should they get no benefit for having made that earlier prepayment? I think they probably should.

Senator Margetts, that is why I think to try to draft on the run an amendment to an obviously complex issue is somewhat unwise. I think the course I have suggested is probably, in all the circumstances, a better course.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Reynolds)—Senator Margetts, you did earlier indicate that this issue might be deferred. If you want to press that, I will put the question, but otherwise we must deal with the amendment now.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am happy to deal with the amendment now. It is quite clear where the sides stand on this issue. It is quite clear that the government is perhaps not wanting the amendment to go through and has found a difficulty, which was a reasonable difficulty, and a reason not to support it, which perhaps could have been remedied. But I understand that the numbers are against me. I will go by the outcome of the committee's vote.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —My amendment is in relation to schedule, part 5, which I, in a shorthand way, refer to as the accelerated repayment provisions. My amendment might be interpreted as something of a compromise—
—Excuse me, Senator Hill. Are you moving that amendment?

—I am just going to suggest that one of the more total or extreme amendments should be debated first just in case that is lost. The minority parties might then come back to my position, which I don't want to lose without having a fair chance. I am suggesting that I do not move my amendment and defer to Senator Bell to move his amendments, which seem to go the furthest, and see how we go. If he is unsuccessful, he might like to support my amendment.
—Senator Bell, you have amendments Nos 1 to 9. Do you see any merit in taking any of them together?
—If Senator Hill wants to depict our position as an extreme one, I am quite happy to toss that up for an opportunity.
—Perhaps `extreme' is not quite the right word. It is the purest form.

—We do have a difficulty here. I remember that, when we actually started this, I wondered what path would be best to follow. The purpose of the Democrat amendments is to oppose the introduction of this accelerated repayment opportunity. If we look at Democrat amendments Nos 3 to 9 together, am I right in thinking that would suit everybody's purpose best?

PARA.TAB: I like Senator Hill's suggestion that this is the purest form. That is most appealing. I think students would see these amendments as retaining the status quo as far as repayments are concerned, and that is what we would hope to achieve.

At the front of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 we have now agreed to include the second reading amendment, which reminds people that the HECS thresholds and repayment levels have been changed by the government for the third time since the inception of HECS. I must remind people that that is against vociferous and consistent opposition, certainly from the Democrats and from other groups, parties and individuals. I think it is only consistent with that statement and with that observation that we oppose any further change.

The further change might on the surface of it be depicted as not requiring people to pay any more money but simply requiring them to pay money faster. Well, remember, please, that this is the government which at one stage, not so long ago, ran a campaign to depict these people as bad debtors. I think the mistake the government made on that occasion was to not recognise that the people who owed the government money were people who had not yet gained full-time employment at a sufficient salary to be able to repay the money.

This was the deal that they had entered into. When you think about it, these people had upheld their side of the bargain. They had entered university. They had forgone other income whilst studying. They had forgone the opportunities which other people obtain when they enter the work force at an earlier age. They had lived through those years at university.

At the other end, not through their own fault—having done everything properly, having qualified and applied for positions—they had found they were in a work force for which there was insufficient employment in those areas. If they had achieved employment, they would be repaying their HECS debt. But it was only a short time ago that the government was running a campaign which depicted those people in a bad light, classing them as bad debtors. I think the government soon learnt a lesson there.

Not to be discouraged, the same government comes back and devises yet another way of getting that money out of people. So when there are finally successes achieved and these, mostly young, people are starting off on a life of employment, trying to establish a family and a new job, this government wants them to pay more and faster. So we are opposing schedule, parts 5 and 6, which implement that faster repayment.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most amazing things that has occurred as a result of this Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) being considered and prior to this bill being considered is some of the phone calls we were receiving. The amazing thing is—and we have heard already from the Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee and also from some other groups—that they have been asked by the government to deliver the minor parties on these issues on the basis that `it will be their responsibility if they don't deliver us and oppose the government's money-raising schemes via the students' disadvantages, because they then will be responsible for other cuts in education'.

PARA.TAB: I think this approach is atrocious, and it is absolutely indicative of the lack of commitment to higher education, self-funding, user-pays, industry rules and so on that we have heard about. It should be made totally clear that the government is using the representatives of some bodies—representatives who are supposedly representing the interests of their groups—to try to push its line. It is divide and rule, which I think is disgraceful.

I would like to put on the record the fact that some senators in this chamber will go down kicking and screaming if the government tries to use this as a slimy excuse to pull funding out of other areas of tertiary education. It is not good enough that the government would try to raise money from students and ex-students who are suffering hardship and then say that that is what is needed to fund proper higher education. It is not good enough, and we will support the Democrats' amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the government did promise to fund some further places—I think it was about 2,000 places Australia-wide—in areas where there was population growth and greater demand, particularly in Queensland, with some in Western Australia and a few in Tasmania. In some of those areas, students traditionally have not been well served and have not had the opportunities students elsewhere in Australia have had. We have actually been calling for those additional places for some time. When the government made an announcement that finally it would meet that public obligation, we recognised that and commended the government.

PARA.TAB: However, it is also true that the government subsequently sought to link the provision of those places with the passage of these new provisions in the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2). It has not sought to extract funding for its public commitments from any other sector in the community. Instead, it has sought to take advantage of students, presumably believing that they do not have the political clout people in other sectors of the community have.

The government has disgracefully gone on to campuses—particularly in Queensland—and told students that, unless they roll over and accept this plan of an accelerated repayment of HECS, they will be depriving other students of the opportunity for higher education. That is appalling. I said that as I was looking at you, Temporary Chairman Reynolds, and you are a Queenslander. I think that level of political blackmail against the interests of Australian students is disgraceful and demonstrates how a government can lose its public standing as a result of staying in office for too long.

It goes beyond what Senator Margetts has said—that this is an attempt to apply pressure to minor parties or even to us by telling us that we will have to suffer the burden of the missed opportunities of Australian students. It goes beyond us politicians who participate in the political arena: it goes to the students themselves, the people to whom the government has made this threat. As I said, I think this is one of the worst exercises of political blackmail that I have seen for a long time. The issues are unrelated, and the government should recognise that and cease this campaign of threatening students in order to fund a commitment that it should have funded in the first place.

Apart from that, there is the issue of merit in relation to this particular provision. The government has not made out any case for accelerated repayment. It must accept that, in practice, it entered into what I refer to as a compact and what I think Senator Bell referred to as an agreement with students; that is, students would accept an obligation to pay for part of their higher education costs and would make that payment on certain terms and conditions. Then, unilaterally, without any reference to students, the government has sought to change the rules. We say that is a breach of faith to students.

On the question of HECS repayment, we believe there are two issues involved. The first issue is what is an appropriate HECS repayment for future students. We think that is a separate debate from unilaterally changing the rules on existing or past students. We are prepared to have that debate for the future, but that is not what has been attempted here. What has been attempted has been to impose this new obligation on past students as well as future students. On that basis we have a compromise, and that is to exclude existing or past students from this obligation.

That said, it logically follows that we will oppose the Democrats' amendment. We will then put our amendment, which will exclude current students and past students. The government will then not be permitted by this legislation to impose upon them new obligations contrary to the undertakings given to them at the time they undertook their higher education.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to place on the record the government's response to the Democrat amendments. In terms of amendments Nos 3, 4 and 5, the government's higher education package announced in the budget was deliberately made cost neutral: that is, the savings made in the higher education system are being spent on new higher education initiatives. In this way, the government has demonstrated its commitment to address priorities in higher education in a fiscally responsible way.

PARA.TAB: The benefits to flow from the initiatives are an additional 11,000 undergraduate places and increased expenditure on research. The Democrat amendments, in effect, seek to protect those on incomes above average weekly earnings at the expense of new places and newcomers to higher education. I think that is the nub. We want more people in higher education, whereas some of these amendments seem to be more about preserving the existing number. We want to increase the number. Amendments Nos 3, 4 and 5 would cost $85 million over four years—funding that would be sufficient to create about 8,500 new student places in higher education; a good sized university anywhere in Australia.

Regarding Democrat amendments Nos 6, 7, 8 and 9, under HECS students who pay the contribution up-front at enrolment receive a discount of 25 per cent on their payment. This discount is an incentive to increase the number of students who pay up-front. As this bill inserts the provision that non-citizens and New Zealanders are required to pay up-front, it is not appropriate for those students to receive the discount. In total, the Democrat amendments would cost $95 million over four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which ones are you talking about now?
—Democrat amendments 6, 7, 8 and 9, because they have all been taken together. I think Senator Bell said that you were putting them all together.
—Yes.
—Finally, I think the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) used words like `blackmail of students'—
—I used those.

—I am sorry. Thank you, Senator Margetts, for self-incrimination. We reject that completely. We have put to the education community, particularly the tertiary sector, that with these changes we are able to provide, in a budget neutral way, more funds so that more people can get tertiary education places. This is a great achievement by this government. Over the period of a decade, we have substantially increased by hundreds of thousands the number of people going to tertiary institutions—and that would not have been achieved without the implementation of HECS.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) has deliberately misled the Senate—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Reynolds)—Senator, you cannot say `deliberately'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot say `deliberately misled'?
—I was not going to complain about that.

—If I cannot say `deliberately', I certainly will not say then that he lied. He is obviously confused—which is giving him the benefit of a great doubt—when he says that the provision we are debating now is designed to create savings that will fund new places at universities.

PARA.TAB: This is not savings; this is the equivalent of a new tax. This is forcing students to repay a debt earlier so that the government can gain revenue. It is not an issue of savings at all. It is just the same as the government going out and imposing a new tax on the public at large to pay for these extra places. But you chose not to do that. You chose to slug the students; you chose to break your deal with the students and, with the power of legislative purpose, to force them to produce the revenue for you. You did this without consultation and in breach of your agreement with the students. That is what we are opposing. For you to come in here and attempt to mislead students in that regard is disgraceful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not attempting to mislead. You are by—

—No, you have to face up to what you are doing in this regard to students: you are compulsorily requiring earlier repayment of their HECS debt. That is the first thing that you are doing to them. Secondly, you are engaging in—and this also might be ruled out of order—political blackmail of students by going into the campuses and telling them that, unless they are prepared to fork out this money earlier, it will result in their fellow students of the future suffering. That is what I say is disgraceful. By your attempting to mislead students today in the way in which you have, you have not contributed to this debate in any sound way.

—I also was rising to speak, as Senator Hill rose just then. I had worked out the same thing: accelerated repayment does not affect the overall revenue; it just affects the time at which that revenue is gained. `In the future revenue neutral' means for this budget. But what you will miss out on is the income that would come from the normal rate of payment in the future budgets. Then who will you blame it on? This seems to be the Laurie Potter version of balancing budgets: pretend that you are richer by getting payments up-front; get them earlier rather than later.

PARA.TAB: In that sense, you may well be inadvertently, or advertently, not giving accurate information to the Senate. In relation to the outcome of this measure, it will not cost $85 million. It simply will rearrange the schedule of payments so that that possible maximum $85 million will come in at a time when, if we continue to go the way we are going, we will need it—and that is, later on, when there will continue to be payments made by students. Of course, with the discounts being offered to those students who are able to pay back earlier, you may get more revenue by allowing them to pay back at a later date.

I think it is really necessary that we make this point: it is funding by rearrangement of payments. You are fiddling the books to make it look as though you have raised the payments. But, in fact, all you are doing is making sure that that payment is not coming in later in future years rather than the current year. As I say, in the future who will you blame it on when those payments, which otherwise would have been coming in in future years, have already been paid?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank both Senator Hill and Senator Margetts for pursuing this argument so strongly. I think students of Australia will appreciate the efforts of those two senators also. This proposition, which has been put forward by the government, in opposition to it, deserves to be pursued strongly.

PARA.TAB: Let us recognise what the government is proposing. It is proposing to link in this area, and this area only, a repayment—which now effectively is a tax, an obligation which is exercised through the Australian Taxation Office on people who have been students and who have incurred a HECS debt—to provision of extra tertiary and university education places.

I presume that the government did not do what the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) has been doing a little here, this afternoon—and that is, plucking figures from the air. I presume that there is a basis for the need that those extra places be provided. If there is a need for those extra places to be provided, surely the government is not proposing that they will not be provided if the HECS repayments are insufficient.

As I said earlier, and I remind the government again: the deal, the compact which was entered into with the student was that those repayments would be made when the student's income, subsequent to graduation, or whenever, reached a certain level. The fact that the income has not yet reached that certain level is not the student's fault in particular. It is, as Andrew Denton says, society who is to blame. It is how society is at the moment. With the level of unemployment that we have, more students than were predicted are unable to commence repayment.

If the government wants to introduce a bit of hurry-up into this, that is one thing. But to link it to the provision of other places is an entirely different matter. This is the difficulty that we have. As I mentioned before, we have a Queensland minister here who is terribly excited about successful negotiations which took place earlier this year between the Goss and Keating governments. I think that minister must have entered into those negotiations very blindly indeed.

It seems to me that the negotiating team would have realised, if its members had asked the questions that I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate, how frail the basis was upon which the promises had been made by the federal government. If those negotiators from the Queensland government realised that those extra places were based upon the idea that certain people would repay their HECS debts faster, I hope they were intelligent enough to laugh at such a proposition. It seems as though at least 1,750 students and their state government have been sold a beauty by this government in that they have been told that there will be that number of additional places—`It's alright; we'll meet this obligation; we recognise the obligation and will meet it.' But the federal government has not informed those people of how shaky the funding for that would be.

I am extremely pleased that this has been highlighted here this afternoon. It really does need to be highlighted. It is a matter which not only is of great concern now but also will be in the future when the money which the government proposes to rake in now, of course, will not be available for whatever future purposes it has in mind. Perhaps the government just wants it all in the bag while it can control it—and the future be damned!

It really seems to me to be a very strange way to base these promises, especially to Queensland, but also to Tasmania and, I understand, Western Australia. It is a very poor way that the government has chosen to meet an obligation which it has recognised. I think it may well have to reap the disadvantages that accrue from starting off on such a very shaky proposition.
Question put:
That items 18 to 24 of the schedule be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—Senator Bell, would you like to clarify your position?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, we have unsuccessfully moved Democrat amendments Nos 3 to 9 inclusively. The situation now is that we have Democrat amendments Nos 1 and 2 remaining. I wonder whether it is appropriate for me to move those first or for other amendments such as Senator Hill's to be moved first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the next logical step is for me to move my first amendment, which is in relation to the same part that provided a slightly different solution—
—Less pure.

—Less pure rather than impure, anyway. This is to protect the interests of existing and past students from this extra burden which the government is seeking to impose on them. I have put the argument for the case; I do not think it is necessary to repeat it. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Schedule, at end of Part 5, page 13, insert the following item:
The amendments made by an item of this Part apply only in relation to a person who commences a course of study to which those amendments relate on or after 1 January 1996.".

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the rationale for the opposition's amendment. Obviously, both the Greens and the Democrats would have preferred a stronger line in relation to the creeping extra commitments which students are being asked to make. I recall being in the United Kingdom and trying to pay my way through university. Halfway through the fees were changed radically to full economic cost, which was amazing because when I arrived in Britain it was not the case. I was absolutely panic stricken. I had to appeal and I was in a very difficult position. I can just imagine how it would be for those people who would suddenly find themselves in this position.

PARA.TAB: It is not the best solution, as I would see it, but it is better than what the government is proposing in relation to increasing the repayments requirements of students. It at least gives people who currently have obligations some idea so that they know roughly what their obligations are, and the status quo, for them at least, will be maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will support this amendment on the basis that it is marginally better than that which is proposed by the government.

—I will also support this amendment. Senator Hill in his second reading contribution said this may be the best outcome of a bad lot, or words to that effect; no doubt his words were more polished than that. I support the amendment under those circumstances.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's proposed change to HECS introducing additional income thresholds for compulsory HECS debt repayments will mean that some HECS debtors repay their debt more quickly. This will only affect some HECS debtors with incomes in excess of average weekly earnings and will not increase the amount of HECS debt for any student. Again, to grandfather this change to HECS, as the coalition amendment seeks to do, would be to set up an arbitrary and inequitable distinction between present and future HECS debtors and between present and future students. The aim of the coalition amendment is a populist one—
—A populist one! It is just.

—We know what you are about. Why don't you admit that you are really about full-time fees coming back? The coalition amendment aims to win the support of current students but it ignores the students of tomorrow and especially those potential students who face the prospect of missing out on a place at university which the government would otherwise create for them from savings generated by the change to HECS.

PARA.TAB: There is no inequity in adjusting the income thresholds for compulsory repayments from both present and future HECS debtors on above average incomes—it is equivalent to adjusting income tax thresholds for all taxpayers. In both cases grandfathering is inappropriate and unnecessary.

The coalition accepts the principles underlying the government's proposed changes to HECS. It accepts the introduction of additional income thresholds for compulsory HECS debt repayments and it accepts that those students who choose not to become Australian citizens should pay their HECS contribution up front. But, of course, for short-term political gain, it would exempt past and present students from these changes at the expense of future students.

The coalition's amendment would mean forgone savings to the higher education budget package amounting to $50 million over the period 1996-98—funding sufficient to create about 5,000 new student places. That is the nub of this debate. We are putting forward these proposals so that, overall, there will be many thousands of new places. If this amendment is carried, 5,000 of those places go out the window and 5,000 fewer young people in particular will have an opportunity to be at university. Although it has been clearly indicated that the vote is against us, the government feels strongly on this matter and will call for a division.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I say in response to Senator Schacht that I sense it is about to happen again—the government is about to break another promise. Until today the figure mentioned was 2,000 places, but the government announced it would provide additional places, as I indicated earlier in the debate. They committed themselves to providing those places, sought the public benefit from committing themselves to those places, and now they are clearly setting themselves up to break that promise to Australian students and Australian families. Of course, they want to blame someone else for it. They are now claiming they will not fund those places in the normal way; they will fund those places from money extracted from existing students.

PARA.TAB: Let the damage be worn by those who deserve it, which is this government. This government made a promise to Australian students to provide extra places. I think what Senator Schacht is now saying—he can confirm it, if he likes—is, `We are now going to renege on that promise; we are no longer going to provide places. We will not provide additional places in Queensland, up the Queensland coast, in Central Queensland, although we have promised otherwise. We are not going to provide the extra places in Western Australia and we are not going to provide the extra places in northern Tasmania.'

If that is the government's decision, so be it. But what the Australian people will know—and they will have a chance to vote on this—is that we will provide those places and fund them in the same way that all other university places are funded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Full fees, you will be on.

—On the basis of the existing funding formula. That is what will happen. This government wants to break the rule by, in effect, charging existing and past students for the provision of those extra places. So they should stand doubly condemned, firstly, for seeking to charge existing and past students for a burden that should be shared by the community as a whole and, secondly, for what is apparently going to be the breaking of yet another promise—in this instance, a promise to the young people of this country.

PARA.TAB: It is not surprising because they have turned breaking promises into an art form. So it is not surprising that they are going to let down Australian students yet again. The minister will acknowledge, if he was prepared to approach this honestly, that they have broken their promise to students in relation to HECS. They have reduced the threshold. They have lifted the repayments. On three separate occasions they have broken their promises in relation to HECS. They are seeking to do it again today.

This government is on the record as breaking promises to students, yet they will do it again today not only in relation to this bill, in the terms of the bill, but in the terms that they say that the consequences of a failure of this bill legitimises them in breaking the promise to provide the extra places. It is as simple as that. If they want to say, `We will not provide those places, we will break our promise,' let them do it and let them suffer the political costs of doing so. There is an alternative and the alternative is that we will meet that wider public responsibility. We will fund the places in the same way as this country funds every other undergraduate place. So the choice will be clear—a government of broken promises continuing to abuse students for their own political benefit or an alternative that will give greater credit to students than they are given at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have actually been dealing with amendments that relate to two issues. We have been dealing with the amendments relating to accelerated repayments and HECS payments for students who are not Australian citizens. If I do get a chance to move my amendment No. 2, and if the Senate by some magical means decides to give majority support to my amendment, then it is possible to revisit this amendment because it will no longer be necessary to have a grandfather clause if those students are no longer treated unfairly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good point, Senator Margetts.
—That is in support of your argument.

—That is right. The government has in the conduct of this debate trotted out a number of figures in a desperate attempt to somehow vindicate its decision. The numbers have varied. In what could be described as the first public skirmish in this debate, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Crean, is quoted in an article in the South Australian Advertiser on 21 September as saying:

PARA.TAB: Up to 2000 university places could be at risk because of Opposition moves to block changes to Higher Education Contribution Scheme rules, the Education Minister, Mr Crean, said yesterday.
It would cost $20 million if the changes were dumped, making it impossible for the Government to deliver promised extra places.

SPEECH.PARA: In an article on page 3 of the Australian of 21 September, the Executive Director of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, Frank Hambly, was quoted as saying:
. . . the Opposition amendments would jeopardise the 6000 extra university places and the research funding outlined in the Budget.
In an undated press release—I believe it was issued around 28 September—the Queensland Minister for Education, David Hamill, is quoted as saying:
The changes are part of a Higher Education package raising an extra $20 million to help defray the costs of 12,000 extra territory places in Queensland . . .

We have just heard from the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) that the package involves $50 million and 5,000 places. It seems any number is good enough provided it is big and threatening and provided it is all somebody else's fault.

PARA.TAB: If the government recognised that Queensland needed 1,750 extra university places, then it is its obligation to actually pay for them—not to threaten students and the Democrats, Greens and coalition that, if the students do not pay their debts faster and if we in this place do not pass this, the government is not going to fund these places and will walk away and ignore that obligation. If that is what this government is proposing, then let us recognise that.

Do not come in here throwing figures around such as $20 million, $50 million, $60 million, and 12,000, 5,000, 6,000, 2,000 places. Let us see a basis for the assessment of the cost. Let us recognise that 1,750 extra places in Queensland are necessary and that several hundred extra places around the rest of Australia need to be found and must be funded by proper government funding.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will point out very briefly—
—Which figures do you want this time?

—I am going to give you one figure now right between the eyes. Since this government has been in office it has increased student places at tertiary institutions by 68 per cent—that is, from 350,000 places to nearly 600,000 places. That has been our achievement. HECS has been about making sure that students who want to go to university get there. It is the biggest growth in the history of the federation.

PARA.TAB: That has been our policy. That is an achievement which the coalition will never be able to match. Senator Hill challenges us and asks about our policy when at the last election you were offering only one policy—full up-front fees. We have not seen what your other policy is. That is what you were on about at the last election. You challenge us on what we will do with the positions. You are asking whether we will go around blackmailing Queensland. We have indicated that, through revenue neutral measures in the budget and these changes, we are able to provide the extra places.

About half a year ago most other states were worried that with a reassessment because of population growth in Queensland they would lose positions and have them transferred to Queensland. There was a particular problem in South Australia—Senator Hill's state and my state—that if we had applied the rules evenly across the country on a per capita basis South Australia would have lost a lot of university places. What the government did was keep the numbers in South Australia and provide extra funds with these changes to ensure that Queensland could match the demand that has resulted from its population growth. That is what this government is about and that is what this bill is about. It is not a matter of blackmail. It is a matter of giving as many students as possible a chance to go to university or a tertiary institution.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) does not mind misleading people constantly. We do not have an up-front full fees policy as the minister says. I thought I made that absolutely clear. He sees political benefit in not telling the truth and I think that is rather regrettable.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
