Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like now to say that the Greens will be opposing the schedule, part 9, pages 18 to 20, items 32 to 37 inclusive. The purpose of this action is to delete all references to certain persons not entitled to deferred contributions. The purpose of this is to stop the government from forcing—unfairly, in our belief—New Zealand citizens and Australian permanent residents with three years residency to pay up-front HECS.

PARA.TAB: The argument that both Senator Harradine and I have given is that there is no discrimination on behalf of people who have paid tax all those years on the basis of whether they are a citizen or not, and it has been pointed out on occasions that this provision may well be in breach of our international obligations in relation to discrimination. It certainly is something that we would oppose as strongly as possible. We feel it is a cynical exercise in terms of trying to raise revenue on the basis of some unproven statement of commitment to Australia. There is no indication at all that this can be or is proven and, even if it were, it would probably still not be valid in terms of the discrimination that it implies. Therefore, I urge that the chamber support our move to oppose these items of the schedule.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support this amendment on the basis that it opposes what we think is a misguided government attempt to increase its revenue by using financial inducements to push people to make a decision about their citizenship—a decision which, I would hope, people would be able to make on the basis of their commitment to the country and their belief in their future in this country. By using these financial inducements, the government is entering into an area which I do not think is either morally or ethically sustainable.

PARA.TAB: What will we have next? Where is the logical extension of this proposition by the government? Do we pay people in terms of attracting them? Do we actually pay them cash to sign the chitty? Do we continue the discrimination down other paths and deny residents of Australia the advantages of citizenship? Do we establish a two-tiered Australian society, where we have the citizens and the other people? Where does this lead us?

The logical extension is beyond my capacity to imagine. I would rather not try to think where this extension would result. I would rather support this proposal to oppose that particular part. If this opposition is not successful, then I have other amendments to put on behalf of the Democrats in the very near future which will seek to ameliorate the effects of this government proposition. In the second reading debate, we heard several different versions of why the government is wrong in this area, and we will not take lightly the proposition that the government has before us.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Bell just indicated, there are a number of varied responses to the government's provision before the committee at the moment. The response that we are debating first is that of the Greens, which in this instance could be said to be the pure response—that is, to wipe the provision out altogether. Senator Bell has circulated the amendments of the Australian Democrats, which look to address specific instances of hardship and to protect people from those instances. Our amendment is drafted rather to protect those who have entered Australia on the basis of what they understand are the rules in relation to obtaining the benefits of a HECS education and who find that they lose the benefits again as a result of unilateral action of this government.

PARA.TAB: As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, I have to concede that I am not totally comfortable with what the government is doing here because we have not really heard any argument for changing the test from permanent residency to citizenship other than the revenue raising argument. We have not heard the government seriously address the social and multicultural consequences that might flow from it. But we are always conscious of the need to protect the revenue. That is why our proposal is something of a compromise and is drafted in terms of protecting those who have understood the rules and entered this country upon the existing set of rules. Therefore, our position is not to go as far as that of the amendment put by the Greens, which the Democrats have said they would support. Thus, we will vote against the amendment of Senator Margetts.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment. The government is introducing additional flexibility for HECS debtors by offering them the option to begin making repayments against their debt before they were required to do so. In return, debtors who take up this option will receive a 10 per cent reduction in the level of the HECS debt. I have just realised that this is already on the record, but I will put it forward again.

PARA.TAB: The amendment proposed by the Greens will enable HECS debtors to make only one repayment instead of ongoing repayments in exchange for a 10 per cent debt reduction, effectively devaluing the government HECS asset. The cost of this proposed amendment would be up to $50 million over four years.

On the question of citizenship and this amendment that Senator Margetts has moved, the government believes that, if the Greens' proposals were accepted to completely remove the government's changes to HECS for non-citizens, savings to the budget would be forgone, amounting to some $17 million over the period 1996-99.

The change here is quite reasonable in that at the moment a person who comes into Australia and gets residency status immediately has access to our higher education system. We are saying that, if you are going to be a resident, after three years you have the opportunity to become a citizen and apply for citizenship. That means that you are committed to being active in the Australian community and contributing to the Australian community. That is fair enough and, therefore, you are eligible for the HECS arrangements. We believe that is a reasonable proposition to put to people—that after three years they make their minds up as to whether they are going to become an Australian citizen and participate in a full way in our Australian community. We do not think that is an unreasonable measure to put on people, particularly as we will raise revenue from those who do not and that revenue will be used to create more places.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the minister has just come to the nub of the argument: `we will raise revenue from those who do not.' What do we tell those people who have been ringing us over the last few weeks—the people who have been paying tax for years—except that the government said, `You're right for a bit of revenue raising on some arbitrary basis'? That is the only thing we can say. There is no ethical or moral justification.

PARA.TAB: If there is some reason why it is not feasible for those people who have been paying tax for years to get Australian citizenship on the basis that dual citizenship in their country is difficult, you are saying, `You have paid tax for years, we will discriminate against you and the only justification for this is that we want to raise some revenue.' I do not think people will forgive the government for that kind of logic. It is not fair, it is not right and it does not abide, as far as I can see, with Australia's international commitments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of what Senator Margetts has just said, I would like to make a couple more comments. On the issue of non-citizens, no other country is as generous as Australia. We are certainly miles in front of what they offer. No Australian citizen could go to any other country in the world and enter university under the conditions that we have in Australia. British, US and New Zealand citizens cannot even get back into their own country's universities under the same conditions. It is nonsense to imply that this measure is the beginning of up-front fees for Australian higher education, which apparently some people have suggested.

PARA.TAB: Our proposal does not require non-citizens to pay full fees for their university education. They will pay only up-front HECS, equivalent to one-fifth of the average course cost. The Australian taxpayer is paying the other four-fifths through HECS funds or it is returned to the higher education system for the provision of additional places for Australian students. Why shouldn't we make sure non-citizens do the same? Clearly, they could avoid any payment if they leave before earning sufficiently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, terrific!

—They could leave the country before they earn. They could be here for three years, get a degree and leave. This is a value judgment about what is an equitable contribution to the country that is providing the system. We believe that this is not an unreasonable thing to request. We believe that this country has a very generous system to residents coming in. As I said, it is the most generous in the world from what we can ascertain. We believe that no-one can criticise us at any level—internationally or even domestically—and say that we are being unreasonable when we are already the most generous in this area amongst comparable countries.

—I want to pick up the minister on one point. The minister separates taxpayers out as if they may not be one and the same people, as either students or the families of students. That is a very important point. You are forgetting about the contribution that these students or the families of these students may have been making for years. You are saying that they are not eligible to have that contribution used towards their education. You are saying that education is not a right; education is a commodity and the government can simply—
—I didn't say that at all, Dee.

—Well, that is the reality. You said that the taxpayer funds. Yes, the taxpayers funds university education. The taxpayer may well have been that student or the families of those students. You are saying that they must pay tax but they are not eligible to utilise their tax in their education.

—The minister again exposed the real purpose of the government in bringing about this proposition and emphasised the reason for its opposition. If the government was truly honest about its intention to increase revenue or to defray the costs which may be associated with paying for foreigners who are not citizens, the government may have been wiser to explore the options of reciprocal arrangements, which it does so successfully with other payments such as social security payments, pensions, et cetera.

PARA.TAB: Doing it this way reveals the holes in the government's arguments. I accept and I agree it is quite demonstrable. It is a fact that other countries are not nearly so generous in their provision of education and other advantages for non-citizens. The way to resolve that surely is not to penalise those who have been, as Senator Margetts points out, paying tax and contributing in other ways to the Australian community. To suggest that those students who take up places at our universities are supported by taxpayers and then divorce the taxpayers from the students when in fact they are one and the same person and belong to families who have been paying tax and may themselves have been doing so for an incalculable amount of time—

TALK.START.PARA: —They're like every other taxpayer for all the other services the community provides.

—That is quite right, Minister—and for the other benefits for which the government has successfully negotiated reciprocal arrangements with other countries. It seems to me that that is by far the more logical, ethical and arguable way of doing it than to suddenly come in with this money-hungry attitude and make assumptions and assertions about people's behaviour—assumptions which cannot be substantiated by any empirical that you have brought in. There is none. These assumptions cannot be substantiated by anything.

PARA.TAB: As I said earlier in the debate, if you assume that the passage through this place of a law of the land is of any value at all, you should assume that everybody will comply with it. You did not. During your contribution just then you showed that the government assumes that. The information you brought to this chamber was that the people who would not comply would be the source of revenue for you. That is a strange assumption for a minister to make—that you are going to pass an act of parliament but there will be certain people who will not take any steps to comply with it so you will charge them some money. It really is not a very satisfactory way to legislate. On the basis of that, you have calculated that some—I do not have the figure as I have given my notes to Hansard—

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventeen million.
—Seventeen million? I cannot compete with that.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Reynolds)—The question is that part 9 stand as printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I ask that this chamber record the opposition of the Greens (WA)—that is, the opposition of me and Senator Chamarette—in this vote. In the interests of time and avoiding annoyance to other people, we will avoid calling for a division.
—by leave—I ask that a similar provision be made to indicate the opposition of the Australian Democrats to the inclusion of this part.
—by leave—Likewise, Madam Temporary Chairman.

PARA.TAB: Part 9 agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 3, page 2, omit "The Higher Education Funding Act 1988", substitute "Subject to section 4, the Higher Education Funding Act 1988".
2.After clause 3, page 2, add the following clause:
"4. The amendments in Part 9 of the Schedule to section 41 and 101 of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 (the Act) have no effect in the application of the Act to a person who is:
(a)under 18 years of age; or
(b)a citizen of a country which does not permit its citizens to hold dual citizenship; or
(c)a successful applicant for, and awaiting conferral of, Australian citizenship; or

(d)in the opinion of the Minister, likely to suffer extreme hardship, including such hardship as is prescribed in regulations, if the amendments were to have effect in the application of the Act to the person.".

I propose to seek leave to delete paragraph (d) and deal with it separately. We have rehearsed the debate in relation to these amendments. The minister asked whether the substance of our debate had been introduced. It has, and I will not take up the time of this chamber to revisit the debate.

PARA.TAB: Even though amendment No. 1 precedes No. 2, that amendment is necessary for amendment No. 2 to occur. I think amendment No. 2 is self-explanatory. I will outline the situation that paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of No. 2 will seek to bring about. In relation to paragraph (a), people who are under 18 years of age will not be penalised for not following through and becoming Australian citizens. Paragraph (b) will allow those citizens of a country which does not permit its citizens to hold dual citizenship to be excused. In relation to paragraph (c), I hope it would be immediately apparent to the government that we should not be penalising somebody who has shown good faith and is an applicant for and awaiting conferral of Australian citizenship but is nevertheless not an Australian citizen.

These people could well be disadvantaged in a way which could be described as being not their own fault. Surely we can readily imagine the number of tertiary students in Australia who, within their family, do not have the authority and opportunity to seek citizenship in their own right. Being under 18 years of age makes it difficult in many families, particularly those with cultural backgrounds, to embark upon that course of their own volition, and it may be difficult to obtain parental permission to do so. I think the amendments explain themselves, and we seek them for those reasons. I will not take any more time to re-run the substantive argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) will be supporting these amendments for the obvious reason that they at least deal with those people who are going to be caught out of the system even more unfairly than most in this particular proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the government claims that it has already acted to incorporate those awaiting conferral of Australian citizenship—that is, those mentioned in paragraph (c)—but the minister might like to clarify that.

PARA.TAB: I am worried about paragraph (b), which deals with `a citizen of a country which does not permit its citizens to hold dual citizenship'. I am worried not because I think there are cases of hardship that will fall within that description but rather what you are starting to do is create classifications within classifications in the determination of HECS eligibility so that there will be an extra right for some depending on the laws of their country of origin. I do not think that is particularly satisfactory legislative drafting.

It seems to me that paragraph (a), which deals with those under 18 years of age, becomes applicable in the circumstance where a parent might refuse consent of the minor to take out citizenship. I think paragraph (d) really sums up the whole situation, which is what Senator Bell is seeking to do, and that is to provide a hardship clause to cover exceptional circumstances and to give the minister a discretion to recognise and act in such circumstances of hardship.

Because of my reservations particularly about paragraph (b), because paragraph (c) is, I gather, already included, and because paragraph (a) would be incorporated within paragraph (d), I would prefer and would be prepared to support paragraph (d) if Senator Bell was prepared to put that separately and we agreed to a couple of very small drafting changes that I wish to suggest. I would change paragraph (d) to read:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a person who is:

(d) in the opinion of the Minister, likely to suffer unfairly, including experiencing hardship as is prescribed in regulations, if the amendment were to have effect in the application of the Act to the person.

With such legislative change I think that would enable the minister to address the circumstances that Senator Bell has in mind in relation to paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) and would be a better way to so proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —We accept that paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of the second amendment should be put together and that paragraph (d) should be put separately. We will accept Senator Hill's amended wording of paragraph (d).

—I want to make sure that the legislation is very clear and that, as far as possible, the discretion is very clear. I understand that paragraph (d) will require some discretionary judgments to be made by the minister. That is unavoidable, given the decision of the chamber to support the government's amendments, which I opposed.

PARA.TAB: Paragraph (b) concerns me because I know of a particular case involving a citizen of the United States. The United States does not permit its citizens to hold dual citizenship. This person is contributing substantially to the economy of Australia. The parents have been paying a substantial amount of tax. They have five children. They are paying their way.

Now you are imposing on that family a requirement that the mother and spouse, who is an American citizen and who wishes to undertake a further degree, will have to pay HECS up-front. Her children are growing up. She and her husband will have tax imposed on them in the same way as everybody else does.

It is not fair. I invite the chamber to agree with me that it is not fair. I cannot see the fairness of discriminating against that family. She will probably be here for many years to come. She will be contributing to society in Australia and to the taxation revenue of Australia. She will be discriminated against by having to pay HECS up-front. I know the person. When she finishes this degree she will repay her HECS obligations in the same way as everybody else does. To demand it up-front at the moment is unfair.
I leave it at that. For that reason, I will be supporting the amendments as moved by Senator Bell.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bell had in mind to seek to split the amendments so that, in amendment No. 2, paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) might be voted upon separately from paragraph (d). We have taken advice from a higher authority which suggests that a more appropriate way of dealing with the matter would be for me to move an amendment to remove from Senator Bell's amendments paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of amendment No. 2, which presumably would be opposed by the Democrats, Senator Harradine and the Greens, on the basis of what has been heard, but supported by the government because it would be cutting back this provision somewhat. If my amendment succeeds, I will seek to amend paragraph (d) of amendment No. 2 in the minor way I suggested. It will be supported by all except the government. That would be the part that would be carried. Therefore, I move:

PARA.TAB: Proposed paragraphs 4(a), (b) and (c), omit the paragraphs.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no objection to the procedure that Senator Hill outlined. It smooths out the processes of handling these different views at this stage. I take this opportunity to put the government's position on these amendments. They are opposed. I have specific comments to make on amendment No. 2.

PARA.TAB: Paragraph (a) is opposed for the following reasons: for those under 18, parents can make decisions for their children, as currently provided for under immigration law. Those under 18 but without parents, such as wards of the state, homeless persons and refugees, are protected under immigration law and can apply for citizenship in their own right.

We are opposed to paragraph (b). Those who are unable to take out dual citizenship but who wish to retain entitlements in other countries are simply being asked to pay HECS up-front. The government does not believe that is a harsh trade-off.
Paragraph (c) has already been commented upon. That was picked up in a government amendment introduced in the House of Representatives. It has been dealt with.

The government opposes paragraph (d). Protecting those who might suffer hardship can only be administered by setting up a bureaucratic, arbitrary decision making process. Again we are talking about people who can become citizens if they so choose. One would have to ask: to what lengths should Australian taxpayers support those who have not given a commitment to Australia? They would continue to be eligible for a university place but would not be able to defer their HECS.
For those reasons we oppose all the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to indicate that the procedure outlined by Senator Hill seems to resolve the problem and I do not object to the procedure; but, of course, I will be opposing the proposition that (a), (b) and (c) be removed. I think No. 1 must be included in whatever process. I have been led to believe that No. 1 is necessary to facilitate No. 2. Perhaps the clerks could advise us if that is not the case.

PARA.TAB: I want to address briefly the response by the minister so that it can be clear as to what I understand the reason is for my moving this. I think the minister has missed the point. Telling us that parents can make decisions on behalf of their children and that wards of the state can make decisions in their own right misses the point that we were trying, in paragraph (a) of No. 2, to address—that is, the situation where a young person wishes to make a move which is not necessarily supported by the parents.

If a young person is eligible for and has been accepted into university on an academic basis and is told that the HECS arrangements will be different, depending on whether or not you are a citizen of Australia, then the young person whose aspirations are subjected to parental consent does not have the same options as the person who is not in that situation. I am not going to stand here and describe the situations where that might arise, but I can imagine many of them. Lest I be accused of making assumptions about certain cultures, I will not give those examples, but I ask the government to understand that there will be many situations where it would be much more appropriate not to introduce conflict into the family.

I suppose I declare an interest in this in a way, having a daughter who is 18. She is old enough to make her own decisions. As a matter of fact, I think she has been making up her own mind since she was about two. Far be it for me to oppose the direction of her decisions. Luckily I am in a situation where there are no cultural pressures to be brought upon our view of the world. We are much in accord, Sally and me, on most matters.

But we know there are families in which the parents are following the cultural beliefs that are well entrenched and well respected and in which the younger generation wants to participate in the Australian culture in a different way. By doing what the government is proposing, we are emphasising those potential cultural differences. We are also requiring young people to make decisions and to change their decisions. There is a potential for young people to be put in conflict with their parents over their need—a need which has been emphasised by the government—to become citizens. I think that is a very dangerous thing for the government to be doing.

The minister's explanation does not address that at all. It does not recognise as a problem the situation where young people are put in conflict with their parents by what the government requires to be done in order to begin tertiary studies. I am sorry the minister missed that point, because it seems to me to be the fundamental point about it.

I hope, if (a), (b) and (c) are not successful, that paragraph (d) may be able to resolve that situation. It seems to me to be a little difficult to get through to the government that that is going to be a problem. Perhaps it may be a problem in only a handful of cases, but to me, when it is a problem, we are emphasising and enforcing that problem within a family. These are the sorts of things that I do not think governments should be meddling in at all. I think the government should be facilitating a resolution of them rather than causing them to happen.

Again, I think it would be most unwise of me to construct an example. I hope I have indicated sufficiently that cultural differences could lead to it; but there are other differences. There are other generational differences, religious differences and perhaps circumstantial situations which could arise where a person under 18 years of age seeks to become a citizen, is unable to without parental consent and is then in a situation of conflict. That conflict is caused by what the government is proposing to do. That is why we moved that. I hope that (d) might be able to address it, if the government recognises that it could occur and if (d) is successful.
Amendment (Senator Hill's) agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed paragraph 4(d), omit "likely to suffer extreme hardship, including such hardship as is prescribed in regulations,", substitute "likely to suffer unfairly, including experiencing hardship as is prescribed in regulations,".

I am seeking to make minor amendments to paragraph (d). Again, higher authority seems to be directing me to a more elegant drafting contribution to seek to amend paragraph (d) by omitting `extreme hardship, including such hardship' and substituting `unfairly, including experiencing hardship'. This is exactly what I thought I had suggested earlier. I thank the clerks for their assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you, Senator Hill, read out for us the paragraph as amended by you?
—Paragraph (d) would read:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the opinion of the Minister, likely to suffer unfairly, including experiencing hardship as is prescribed in regulations, if the amendments were to have effect in the application of the Act to the person.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Hill be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The government opposes this but we will not be calling a division on it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that Senator Bell's two amendments, as amended, be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—We oppose it but we will not call a division on it.

PARA.TAB: Amendments (Senator Bell's), as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule, at end of Part 9, page 20, add the following item:
(1)The amendments made by an item of this Part apply only in relation to a person who commences a course of study to which those amendments relate on or after 1 January 1996.

(2)In so far as the amendments made by an item of this Part relate to a person who is a permanent resident, the amendments apply only in relation to a person who becomes a permanent resident on or after 1 January 1996.

PARA.TAB: (3)In so far as the amendments made by an item of this Part relate to a person who is a New Zealand citizen, the amendments apply only in relation to a New Zealand citizen who commences a course of study after 1 January 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: This is to ensure that the provisions apply only to those who become permanent residents on or after 1 January 1996—in other words, that the provisions in the government's bill do not apply to those who are already permanent residents and who have gained the benefits that have historically flowed to people in that position.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition amendment seeks to grandfather the government's proposed changes to HECS which would require students who are long-term permanent residents to pay their HECS contribution up front at enrolment without a discount. This would set up an arbitrary and inequitable distinction between present and future students who, in all other respects, are equal.

PARA.TAB: The changes proposed by the government reflect its view that its policy of access to financial assistance for higher education should meet the needs first and foremost of Australian citizens. Students who choose not to become Australian citizens will be asked to make the HECS contribution towards the cost of their courses at enrolment. Nevertheless, these students will continue to receive the same Commonwealth subsidies towards the cost of their courses as are granted to Australian students who choose to defer their contributions. On average, this subsidy covers 80 per cent of course costs.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an uncirculated amendment, which can be put very simply and quickly. I apologise to the committee, because I have not circulated this amendment. But, put quite simply, we would seek to oppose part 8 of the schedule, which is on page 17. The purpose of part 8 is not to exempt certain holders of scholarships. The main effect of this, as I indicated in my speech in the second reading debate, is to deny schoolteachers in particular the opportunity to be exempt from HECS payments for staff development purposes.

PARA.TAB: We think this is misguided. The fact that I have been unable to detect a reciprocal increase in funds available in other areas for teachers to continue their professional development means that these people, who are contributing so much to the future of Australia, are being disadvantaged. So with those few comments, we oppose part 8.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not know this one was coming, Senator Bell. I said earlier in debate that the issue of professional development of teachers is vitally important. I think Senator Bell is correct in saying that this government is abolishing this benefit without substituting something else in lieu thereof.

PARA.TAB: The government claims that the professional development schemes that it otherwise funds are adequate, but the net result is a deduction in public funding contribution to professional development of teachers. I think that the government should be criticised for this. The next element of the debate is: what is now the best way to go?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is their problem.

—No. To reinstate it is one option that is open, but there may well be other options open that are better. What I am saying, I guess, in code is that some of us are addressing the forthcoming election with different proposals for the benefit of teachers in the area of professional development. Some of us think we have some better ideas than this government has in practice at the moment. That is the way some of us tend to progress this particular matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reiterate what is said in the second reading speech on part 8, which Senator Bell now wants to delete:

PARA.TAB: Another measure relates to the provision of HECS exemption scholarships for teachers. These scholarships were introduced in 1989 to support a greater degree of professional development among teachers. Since that time, the government has introduced a new, more flexible $60 million national professional development program which addresses much of the same objectives.

As a result of this initiative, and in light of the priority to provide additional undergraduate opportunities, the $4.8 million previously allocated to teacher HECS exemption scholarships will be reallocated to help create student places. In future, Commonwealth support—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha! I see.
—It is in the second reading speech. I do not know what you are laughing at, Hilly. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: In future, Commonwealth support for the professional development of teachers will be provided solely through—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are ripping funding off teachers as well.
—Hang on. I wish you would just listen. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: In future, Commonwealth support for the professional development of teachers will be provided solely through the national professional development program.
That is a $60 million program. It continues:

As the scholarship program will cease from the end of 1995, there will be no need for a provision in the act exempting scholarship holders from HECS liability, and the act will be amended accordingly.
So we oppose Senator Bell's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My education adviser is currently in the air on the way to Canberra. However, on the run, I am not convinced by the government's argument, just as I was not convinced when the government removed $1.2 million worth of funding support and closed down the 22 education centres around Australia. So I am inclined to support this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Part 8 agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the Democrats' disagreement recorded.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill reported without amendment, and Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bills (on motion by Senator Schacht) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 26 October, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Commonwealth Bank Sale Bill 1995 has been around for a while. We find ourselves in this place debating a government bill that has got more holes in it than Swiss cheese. It is so incomplete and so poorly defined that it leaves us all guessing. It not only leaves us guessing, Senator Sherry; I guess it will leave us guessing until next week to find out what the final outcome is going to be, because I haven't got long to speak.

PARA.TAB: Much of the detail associated with this bill will be dealt with by regulation, so once again as a Senate we are forced to play a guessing game in an effort to determine what is the government's real intention in relation to a number of the critical clauses. This is not good enough. The government has been forced to rush this bill through in a desperate attempt to silence the many critics from its own ranks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gee!

—I presume you would be one of them, wouldn't you? The reality is that this sale has been forced upon us because the government changed its mind midstream. It had abandoned the idea of selling Telstra and was left with a huge hole its budget. So, in order to meet this illusionary surplus and not lose face totally, the government took a bitter pill. It turned its back on the so-called true believers and put the farm back on the market.

PARA.TAB: We come here today knowing full well that this decision only narrowly scraped through caucus. We come here knowing that it is a decision which has caused a bitter and acrimonious split in Labor Party ranks.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got to be kidding!

—Oh, yes it has. That is the basic difference between the government and the coalition. This is a government that will do anything and say anything to stay in office and this is a government without principles and without any ideology. People often ask me today, `What does the Labor Party stand for?' As Piers Akerman said in that speech recently to the osteopaths, `It doesn't stand for anything.' My answer is that the Labor Party only stands for opportunism.

PARA.TAB: It is not the Labor Party of old. I am sure that a great many of the true believers regret that day in March 1993 when Paul Keating covered himself in their glory and then promptly set about turning his back on everything which they had all worked so hard for and believed in, so much so that the rank and file have now turned the clock back and recycled Bob Hawke.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done with John Howard?
—John Howard is the elected leader of the Liberal Party, not like Bob Hawke, who is the unelected leader of the Labor Party by the look of it. He is certainly the unelected leader of the ACTU.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Order! Senator Sherry! Senator Calvert has the call.

TALK.START.PARA: —The interjections have stopped my great speech midstream. I would be more than happy to recap on some of these points next week when we reconvene.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I dealt with disagreements within the union movement whereby various factions within one of the major unions—the AWU-FIME—were busy accusing each other of not being concerned about the rank and file and of basically being concerned about self-interest rather than looking after the workers in the AWU-FIME.

PARA.TAB: I raised this issue because the massive reduction in the number of union members bears some relation to the feeling that so many Australian workers now have—the feeling that these mega-unions act in a way which is irrelevant to their interests. That explains why so many workers are now keen to enter into negotiated arrangements with their employers without the `benefit' of union intervention. It also explains why the deals the employers arrange are clearly better than the deals the unions have been able to arrange.

The reason for that of course is that the employer arranged deals are linked to productivity—a concept which appeals to so many Australian workers because they rightly feel that, the harder they work, the better their reward should be. That is the essence of this matter, a matter which has threatened to disrupt so much of Australia over the question of CRA and other elements of the union movement. What I was saying yesterday—and there was an interjection along these lines by Senator Schacht—was that I understood that union elections were lively and active events.

TALK.START.PARA: —Robust.

—`Robust' I think was the word he used. They are almost as robust as some Liberal Party preselections, although not quite as robust as some Labor Party preselections. We are all aware of Mr Keating's preselection. Mr Tom Burns, who at that stage was the president of the Labor Party and is now Deputy Premier of Queensland, had an investigation into that matter. We are all aware of the extraordinary activities surrounding Laurie Brereton, who rode around with ballot boxes on the back of his motorbike. We are all aware of these robust activities.

PARA.TAB: One would assume—and it would be reasonable to assume—that there must be some element of truth to the sorts of allegations made in these union election battles which attack the credibility, the decency, the honour and a whole lot of other things of various contestants. Otherwise, I would have thought the courts would be full of defamation actions. Last night, before running out of time, I mentioned that I had a letter from a Mr T. J. Murphy dated 7 August 1995. The letter was confidential to the executive branch committee members of the New South Wales AWU-FIME federal branch.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no such entity.
—I thank Senator Forshaw for his interjection, although I am not quite certain what the burden of it is. Mr Murphy's letter reads:

PARA.TAB: Sirs,

At the N.S.W. AWU-FIME Federal Branch Executive Meeting held on Monday, 7th. August, 1995, Joint Secretary Russ Collinson, when flagging that he was ratting on another deal, cited as justification for doing so that the Mike O'Shea team (AWU) had breached an agreement that involved supporting a slate of candidates (see attached "How to Vote"). In support of his claim he cited the fact that I had nominated against the "team" to which O'Shea and he had given their imprimatur. I indicated that I had not breached any deal with Collinson, and that since I have known him he has had a poor record himself in that regard. There is no way that I would do a deal with Collinson.

I was prepared, like my fellow N.S.W. Branch Executive Members, to be blackmailed out of standing for office in the Union that I had served for over forty years to keep some semblance of AWU identity in the amalgamated N.S.W Federal Branch. This, despite the fact that it would mean that among those who would survive were AWU people who through incompetence and treachery had delivered the N.S.W AWU Federal Branch into the control of the debt-ridden, no-principled FIME.

SPEECH.PARA: They are good mates, obviously! It continues:

PARA.TAB: I tried not to think of my Fellow Branch Executive Members who had earned their positions as Executive Members through their efforts on the Union's behalf and by the votes of the rank and file members, but who would now be replaced by opportunists who had obtained their tickets in contradiction of the Rules of the Union. However, I was not prepared to support the O'Shea-Collinson "How to Vote" that would have allowed two non-eligible people, Innes and Farley, to be voted into a position that is meant to be filled by genuine members of AWU or FIME who no doubt would consider it a privilege to be elected by the rank and file members. Proof of this was that the Electoral Officer rejected their nominations which relied on AWU tickets, and they were only restored to the Ballot on the supportive evidence from either of the Joint Secretaries, or both. No doubt you people as Branch Executive Committee Members of FIME were consulted and agreed to support the Collinson and O'Shea "How to Vote" ticket, and I can only wonder how this proposition could have received your support.

Ernie Ecob's legal challenge to Innes and Farley resulted in their withdrawal from the Ballot . . . I did not have the financial resources to take legal action, and it was therefore fortunate that Ernie Ecob did so successfully, thereby upholding the Union's Rules. I was greatly distressed to see FIME employees in court supporting non-members.
I can only imagine the reaction of those Union members who have been put to the debt collectors if they knew that the Union is prepared to support non-members such as Innes and Farley.
I restate that had I no "deal" with Collinson.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, this is all relevant because of what is clearly turning out to be a struggle with the principle of whether workers should have the right to enter into agreements they regard as being in their best interests or be obliged to be, if you like, coerced into membership of a union. Quite frankly, with this union, I was intrigued to see that in a recent court action the chief judge of the New South Wales Registry of Industrial Relations Court of Australia accepted the fact that one particular worker `got inadequate advice; he got incompetent advice' provided to him by the union.

PARA.TAB: I cannot say that unions are required to give competent advice, but it does seem to me extraordinary that they can spend so much time having internecine wars and yet, when it comes to looking after their workers, they do not do the right thing. His Honour said, `He was very much dependent upon the union officers'—

TALK.START.PARA: —What's the Liberal Party been doing for the last 13 years?

—This is what the judge said: `He was very much dependent upon the union officers, and he was, I think, let down by them.' I am just stressing that there is clearly a difference when comparing the enthusiasm of various union officials in looking after their own activities and blackguarding each other, with their enthusiasm in looking after ordinary workers in industrial relations matters like this.

PARA.TAB: This may be just an isolated example, but it happens to be one with which I am closely concerned. I believe that these people have had a very rough trot and that the AWU has not, in fact, properly looked after them. But this is a matter of some significance, particularly at this time. I do not think one could say that unions necessarily look after the best interests of their workers, or necessarily that employers are not looking after the best interests of workers when their workers' interests and their own happen to coincide. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Government consider that the Government and Commonwealth officers are bound by the principle in law known as `misprision of felony' by which one is bound to report any known felony to the responsible authorities or become an accessory thereafter if one knowingly does not; if not, then by what means are obligations, if any, placed upon those in responsible authority.

(2) Have the documents supplied to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration's inquiry into banking and deregulation (the Martin Inquiry) and described by Westpac Banking Corporation lawyers, Allen Allen and Hemsley, as `devastating' ever been examined by the Government in the public interest; if not, why not.

(3) Have the missing attachments, the `devastating' documents, ever been identified, sought or examined by any Treasurer, any Attorney-General, the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), the National Crime Authority, the Australian Securities Commission, the Australian Federal Police, any State fraud squad, or by any other Minister or responsible authority.
(4) If the documents are missing, are they missing from the possession of both the bank and the lawyers; if so, by whose neglect did they go missing.

(5) Have either the bankers or their lawyers, in the spirit of co-operation assured by the former Managing Director of Westpac to the Martin Inquiry, attempted to find them or establish how they disappeared.
(6) If these documents have been examined, then: (a) by whom; and (b) did they agree with Westpac's lawyers that the documents are damning; if so, what was their recommendation; if not, why not.

(7) If, as claimed by the lawyers, the `parking accounts' are missing, have the bankers, in the spirit of co-operation with the inquiry and with their clients as assured by the former Managing Director of Westpac to the Martin Inquiry, attempted to find the suspense accounts or establish how they disappeared.

(8) If the parking accounts have been found and examined, then: (a) by whom; and (b) did they agree with Westpac's lawyers that they have extremely serious implications; if so, what is their recommendation; and (c) if they did not agree with the bank's lawyers regarding the significance of the parking accounts, why not.

(9) If the parking accounts have been found, have the bankers, in the spirit of co-operation with the inquiry and with their clients as assured by the former Managing Director of Westpac to the Martin Inquiry, allowed clients access to the accounts through discovery.

(10)(a) Is it a statutory requirement for the RBA to monitor the efficacy of the nation's bankers; if not, why not; (b) if it is a statutory requirement: (i) what criteria apply, by whom were the criteria formulated and where are they stipulated; and (ii) has the RBA monitored banking efficacy in relation to the matters raised in the above questions, has the RBA reported on these matters to the Government, and will the report be tabled.
(11) If the RBA has not so investigated and reported, will the Minister cause it to do so and advise the Senate of the terms and times of such an investigation.

(12) Does the Government accept as appropriate that the Governor and Board of the RBA should delegate any responsibilities to monitor or to investigate to competent authorities; if so, which authorities does the Government and the RBA regard as competent, and by what criteria and process does the Government and the RBA assess the competence with which this task is carried out on their behalf.

(13) Does the Government accept the assurances contained in the letter from the Governor of the RBA to Mr Paul McLean on 24 March 1993 that `most of the cases of dispute which you discuss have been or continue to be the subject of court action and have been reviewed by other competent authorities"; if so: (a) does the Government accept that such reviews have now all been completed and that the `competent authorities' have satisfied the Governor and Board of the RBA that the `Westpac letters' do not constitute prima facie evidence of corporate fraud, tax evasion, breach of fiduciary obligation or breach of statutory obligations to the RBA on the part of Partnership Pacific Limited (PPL) and Westpac; and (b) what arguments did the Governor of the RBA present to the Board and then to the Treasurer to contradict the arguments advanced by Allen Allen and Hemsley to Westpac.

(14) Which competent authorities satisfied the Governor and RBA Board and the Government that every reasonable effort had been made to establish how and with whose authority the `parking accounts' by which very substantial taxes were evaded, went missing from the bank.

(15) Which competent authorities satisfied the Governor and RBA Board and the Government that every reasonable effort had been made to establish the whereabouts of the missing and `devastating' attachments referred to in the first Westpac letter dated 26 November 1989, and that if they have been located and thoroughly examined there is no need for further action or concern.

(16) Which competent authorities convinced the Governor and RBA Board that ex-Westpac employees John McLennan, Clive Alexander, Gerhard Moser and Agnes Wong must all have independently and separately fabricated stories about malpractice within PPL and Westpac.

(17) Which competent authorities convinced the Governor and RBA Board and the Government that Clive Alexander lied to the ABC `Four Corners' program about the internal reports he was commissioned to prepare and did prepare, regarding malpractice within the PPL trading room.

(18) Which competent authority convinced the Governor and RBA Board and the Government to believe management rather than Clive Alexander when management said that these reports had been missing within Westpac for 4 years and that they had never been seen or discussed by senior management.
(19) Do the Government and the Governor and Board of RBA agree with the present position of the Martin Inquiry that the McLean evidence should remain hidden from public scrutiny.
(20) Who determines, and by what criteria who is fit to hold a banker's licence in Australia.
(21) How often are banker's licences reviewed, have any ever been revoked; if so, under what circumstances.
(22) When was Westpac's banking licence last reviewed and when will it be reviewed next.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) This question seeks a legal opinion which is outside the expertise of the Treasurer and the Treasury. The following answer is based upon advice from the Attorney-General's Department. `Misprision of felony' is a common law offence. Whether it still exists in any Australian jurisdictions is a matter for the individual jurisdictions. The Australian Code States (Queensland, WA, Tasmania and the NT), and common law States New South Wales, Victoria and SA have abolished the common law offence of misprision of felony. No equivalent offence exists under the statute law of those jurisdictions. In the ACT the offence does not appear to have been abolished, but the distinction between a misdemeanour and a felony has been abolished, and as a consequence it is unlikely that the offence misprision of felony can apply (see A v Hayden (No 2)(1984) 156 CLR 523 at 552 at 556).

In 1915, the judgments of Griffith CJ and Isaacs J in R v Kidman (1915 20 CLR 421) raised the question whether there exists any separate common law of the Commonwealth. That question has never been authoritatively resolved. The Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law, chaired by the former Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Harry Gibbs, took the view that misprision of felony might apply in relation to a Commonwealth offence that could be identified as a felony and was committed in a State where the common law offence had not been abolished. However, it considered that situation to be unlikely, since no offence under Commonwealth law is described as a felony. It noted that no instance had come to the notice of the Review Committee of a Commonwealth prosecution for misprision of a felony in relation to an offence under Commonwealth law. It recommended that no statutory offence of misprision of a felony be enacted by the Commonwealth, on the assumption that existing offences of accessory after the fact and compounding an offence would be retained, and would be sufficient to meet policy requirements.

The Government, as the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, cannot be criminally liable for a common law offence. The principle that the Crown cannot be criminally liable for a supposed wrong prevails over anything but the clearest expression of intention in a statute (Cain v Doyle (1946) 72 CLR 409; Canadian Broadcasting Corporation v Attorney-General for Ontario [1959] SCR 188).

In general, the mere fact that a Crown servant is acting in the course of his or her employment will not entitle the servant to the Crown's immunity. If a Commonwealth officer became aware of the commission of a felony in, and under the law of, a jurisdiction where the common law offence of misprision of a felony had not been abolished and failed to disclose that knowledge to the law enforcement authorities of the jurisdiction within a reasonable time and having had a reasonable opportunity to do so, he or she would, as would any person in the same position subject to the laws of the jurisdiction, be liable to prosecution for the common law offence.

(2) and (3) The Attorney-General's Department has advised that the `attachments' to the so called `Westpac letters' have never been sought or examined by the Attorney General's Department or any of the Attorney-General's portfolio agencies.
The `attachments' to the `Westpac letters' have never been sought or examined by any Treasurer, Attorney General, other Minister, or the Governor of the Reserve Bank.

The National Crime Authority (NCA) has never sought or examined the `attachments' to the `Westpac letters'. Recommendation 61 of the Report of the House of Representatives Standing committee on the inquiry into the banking industry, which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 27 November 1991, recommended that the "Westpac letters" be referred to the NCA for investigation into whether any criminal wrongdoings arose from the management of foreign exchange contracts by Partnership Pacific Limited. Following that recommendation, on 3 December 1991, the Attorney General's Department forwarded all relevant material in its possession (including the `Westpac letters' without the `attachments') to the NCA for consideration of what action, if any was warranted on its part.

Pursuant to the National Crime Authority Act 1984, the NCA has a charter to investigate activity where it amounts to "relevant criminal activity". After consideration of the documentation, the Acting Chairman of the NCA in a letter to the Department dated 1 April 1992, reported that the conduct of Partnership Pacific Limited or any of its employees did not fall within the definition of "relevant criminal activity". No subsequent inquiries were undertaken by the NCA into the matter.

The DPP also examined the "Westpac letters" without the attachments. In January 1992, the Assistant Director of the Head Office of the DPP concluded that the material available did not disclose any offence against the Commonwealth, other than possible taxation offences which fell within the investigative responsibilities of other agencies. No further correspondence on the matter was entered into by the DPP after that date.
The ASC did not identify, seek or examine any of the documents in question.

In June 1991, the Attorney General's Department referred the `Westpac letters' without the `attachments' to the Australian Federal Police (AFP). After investigation of the letters, the AFP advised the Attorney General's Department on 11 September 1991 that there was no obvious breach of Commonwealth law warranting further involvement by the AFP.

In September 1991, the Attorney General's Department referred the `Westpac letters' without the `attachments' to the New South Wales Police Service and the Victorian Police. In January 1992, the Victorian Police advised the Attorney General's Department that the material provided disclosed no offences against Victorian law, and that no further action was warranted. In September 1992, the New South Wales Police Service advised the Attorney General's Department that the material provided disclosed no offences against New South Wales law, and that no further action was warranted.
(4) and (5) These questions relate to matters which are not within the knowledge of the Treasurer or the Treasury. Westpac Banking Corporation advises that:

The `attachments' to the `Westpac letters' have always been in Westpac's possession or control and have been produced in legal proceedings where they are relevant to claims being made against Partnership Pacific Limited.
(6) The `attachments' to the `Westpac letters' have not come into the possession of the Government or any of its agencies.
(7) to (9) These questions relate to matters which are not within the knowledge of the Treasurer or the Treasury. Westpac Banking Corporation advises that:

The suspense account books have never been found despite a number of searches since 1987—first, when the so-called Westpac letters were prepared and subsequently in connection with discovery in legal proceedings.

The suspense account was created because the accounting system in existence in PPL at the time necessitated a large amount of paperwork (as many as three or four deal slips for each position created for each client). The suspense account acted as a temporary holding account for those deals, entered into on behalf of certain clients, that PPL found difficult, for purely administrative reasons, to allocate on the deal date. While PPL no longer has the suspense account books, from the transactional documents relating to the amounts transferred into the suspense accounts (that is, from deal slips and dealer position sheets) which are generally available, an independent firm of accountants retained by the Westpac on behalf of PPL has been able to ascertain the total value of the contracts transferred into the suspense accounts, together with the exchange rates and, from this, the suspense accounts have largely been reconstructed. The reconstruction exercise was undertaken so that PPL and its clients can litigate, mediate or negotiate on an informed basis.

This reconstruction has been examined by independent actuaries who have used statistical techniques to examine the certainty of the conclusions drawn in the accountants' reports. On the basis of these actuarial examinations we are confident that the accountants' reports can be relied upon.

An extensive report from those independent accountants, detailing the reconstruction and the effect on individual borrowers, has been made available on a confidential basis to the handful of former PPL customers who, in relation to their claims in respect of their managed foreign currency loans, have chosen to pursue a mediatory mechanism or to litigate.

Furthermore, the unavailability of the suspense account books is not something which has adversely affected the position of PPL borrowers, because to the extent that Westpac has been unable to produce those books, those borrowers have argued that an adverse inference should be drawn and these borrowers have used that inference in mediations or negotiations.

(10) It is not a statutory requirement for the Reserve Bank to "monitor the efficacy" of Australian banks or bankers. The Banking Act 1959 makes the Reserve Bank responsible for the prudential supervision of banks and for the protection of banks' depositors. This involves the Reserve Bank in closely monitoring the operations of banks against a range of prudential criteria. The Reserve Bank has no statutory duty in relation to the probity of individual banking transactions. These issues are for the law enforcement authorities, and the courts; the Australian Banking Industry Ombudsman and the Code of Banking Practice are relevant to dealings with retail customers.
(11) It would be inappropriate for the Treasurer to instruct the Reserve Bank to do anything in relation to the matters raised by Senator Bell.

(12) to (19) The Reserve Bank does not delegate any of its statutory responsibilities to other authorities. It follows from the answer to Question 10 that, since the Reserve Bank was not responsible for investigating matters relating to the `Westpac letters', it has no responsibilities to delegate in this matter. Rather, disputes of this nature (between banks and their customers) are properly matters for the courts, the law enforcement authorities and, in certain cases, the Australian Banking Industry Ombudsman. It would be inappropriate for the Government or the Reserve Bank to usurp the judicial function of the courts by intervening in disputes between banks and their customers.

(20) Authorities to carry on banking business are granted by the Governor-General following the submission of an application to the Treasurer pursuant to section 9 of the Banking Act 1959. Bank authorisation is determined on the basis of such factors as:
financial strength;
capacity to satisfy the Reserve Bank's prudential supervision requirements; and
economic benefit to the people of Australia.

(21) and (22) Banking authorities granted under section 9 of the Banking Act are not subject to review. Each authorised bank must comply on an on-going basis with the Reserve Bank's prudential supervision requirements; penalties may be imposed for non-compliance. Banking authorities have only ever been revoked following decisions by banks to cease conducting bank business in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Prime Minister instructed the Governor-General not to submit to the Queen any requests from national organisations for permission to add the prefix `Royal' to their names; if so: (a) when was this instruction given; and (b) what was the reason for this instruction.

(2) Has the Prime Minister instructed the Governor-General not to submit to the Queen, as Head of the Order of Australia, the half-yearly honours lists for her approval; if so: (a) when was this instruction given; and (b) what was the reason for this instruction.

(3) Has the Prime Minister ordered the removal of all photographs of the Queen from conference rooms and public areas of the department; if so: (a) when was this instruction given; and (b) what was the reason for this instruction.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) The Federal Government has not supported applications from organisations seeking the right to use the prefix `Royal' in their names since 1983.

Between 1983 and 1993, the Governor-General received a small number of applications directly and, with the consent of the Government, made recommendations on them to the Queen based on his own assessment of their eligibility.

On 7 July 1993, the then Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services formally advised the Governor General that applications from organisations seeking the right to use the prefix `Royal' in their names should not be supported.

(b) The Government considers that Australian names have their own honour and distinction which reflect our unique heritage and identity. This has been reflected in the establishment of an indigenous honours system and it is inappropriate for Imperial nomenclature to be used as a mark of distinction for Australian organisations.

(2)(a) and (b) In January 1994 the Acting Prime Minister wrote to the Governor-General indicating the Government's wish that, as provided under Clause 10 of the Constitution of the Order of Australia, the Governor-General should exercise all powers and authorities of the Sovereign in the Order, including the approval of awards and honorary awards in the Order. As a result the approval of all honours in the Australian system of honours and awards, except the Victoria Cross for Australia, is now granted by the Governor-General.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Social Security: Benefits Paid to Overseas Born Residents

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Can the value of benefits paid to overseas born residents who have been residing in Australia for: (a) up to, and including, 6 months; (b) up to, and including, 12 months; and (c) up to, and including, 24 months, be provided.
(2) Can a breakdown be provided of the answer to (1) by benefit type.

(3) Can details be provided of any debts raised from the above payments which: (a) will be; or (b) have been, recovered from assurances of support provided on behalf of, or by, the benefit recipients.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Information in respect of the cost of benefits referred to in the honourable Senator's question is not readily available. To collect and assemble it would be a major task and I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of money and effort involved in assembling such information.

The Department of Social Security does not collect data relating to overall period of residence in Australia. The information collected relates to period of permanent residence status. This may or may not coincide with the overall period of residence in Australia, depending on whether a person applies for a permanent visa "offshore," or while in Australia on a temporary visa.
Over the two-year period from 1 October 1993 to 1 October 1995, the numbers of overseas-born residents who received income support payments were as follows:
(a) up to and including 6 months after grant of permanent residence: 37,558.
(b) up to and including 12 months after grant of permanent residence: 48,066.
(c) up to and including 24 months after grant of permanent residence: 52,997.
(2) The breakdown of the answer to (1) by benefit type is shown in the table below.
Note that the numbers are taken over a two-year period from 1 October 1993 to 1 October 1995.
Note also that the numbers do not take account of duration of payment. A person may only have received one fortnight's payment, but would still be counted.

There are two factors which should be noted in relation to the 6-month figures: while there is a 26-week residence requirement for allowances, refugees are exempt from this requirement; and qualification for Newstart Allowance is based on 12 months' registration with the CES, for which a person does not need to be a permanent resident.

(3) The Department pursues the recovery of all Assurance of Support debts. In the period from 1 October 1993 to 1 October 1995, the Department raised 805 Assurance of Support debts, totalling $4,865,757. As at 13 November 1995, the Department had recovered $1,252,249 of those debts.

The Department does not disaggregate debt recovery information by the year in which the debt began to accrue. Some of the 805 Assurance of Support debts raised over this period would have begun to accrue well before October 1993; on the other hand, some debts which had begun to accrue in 1995 would not be included in this figure.
