TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 29 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the first United Nations Review of the Asia Pacific Decade of Disabled Persons 1993-2002, which was held in Bangkok on 24-25 June 1995:

(1) Is it a fact that although Australia had originally agreed to send an official representative, at the last moment this decision was reversed; if so: (a) what was the reason; and (b) was an official apology tendered.

(2)(a) Is it a fact that this was a very important conference at which the Governments of 22 of the 33 countries in the Asia Pacific region were represented, and goals and target dates for the achievements of those goals were agreed; and (b) did Australia have any input into the setting of those goals and target dates.

(3)(a) Is it a fact that Australia was one of the countries instrumental in the setting up of the Decade of Disabled Persons; and (b) is the Government now going to commit itself to the goals and target dates which came out of the conference.
(4) Will the Government take part in the rest of the Decade of Disabled Persons; if so, what will the level of participation be.

(5) Is the Government prepared to help with expenses for members of the disabled community who wish to be officially involved in this and other projects on behalf of the disabled community in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The honourable senator is referring to a meeting hosted in Bangkok by the Economic and Social Committee for Asia and the Pacific, known as ESCAP, to discuss progress made in the Asian Pacific Decade of Disabled Person. As with all relevant ESCAP meetings, Australia was invited to provide a report and send a delegation to this meeting.

We do not accept every such invitation, but carefully consider whether our presence would have any special value to this country, or to our neighbours in the Asia and Pacific region, and weigh this up against the many other calls on our time and resources.

(a) Initially my department indicated that we would be represented at the Bangkok meeting. Following further consideration it was decided that the expense involved was not justified in the light of other more pressing calls on funding.
(b) The ESCAP secretariat was advised that we would regrettably be unable to attend this particular meeting but was assured of our commitment to the Decade. Our report was provided as requested.

(2)(a) The meeting was well attended by countries throughout the Asian Pacific region. The main item for discussion was the Agenda for Action which had been set at a previous meeting in 1993. The goals and target dates referred to in the honourable senator's question derive from that agenda for action.

(b) Australia contributed to the development of the goals and targets through participation in previous discussions on the Agenda itself, and through continued correspondence with the ESCAP secretariat on issues within the Agenda. It should be noted that Australia is relatively advanced, in any comparison, with Agenda items and goals.
(3)(a) Australia co-sponsored the resolution which proclaimed the Decade of Disabled Persons.

(b) Australia had already committed itself to the Agenda for Action and the draft goals and target dates. Only minor variations to the goals and target dates came out of the meeting. Like other countries, we have taken the time following the meeting to consider these, and I am pleased to advise the honourable senator that we do commit ourselves to these. As was noted earlier, Australia is already relatively advanced against these goals and targets.

(4) This Government will certainly maintain its commitment to the Asian and Pacific Decade of Disabled Persons. The level of our further participation will be considered as opportunities arise and in the context of this commitment.

(5) The Government already provides substantial funds to peak consumer groups to represent the interests of people with a disability and would encourage those groups to consider how they can support the Decade when making decisions about their expenditure priorities. Several representatives of disability consumer groups in fact attended the Bangkok meeting, and I would hope that these people continue their active involvement.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 27 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the fact that, under the Therapeutic Goods Act, a licence must be obtained for all pharmaceuticals manufactured in Australia by meeting specifications set down by the Therapeutic Goods Administration, such as the formulation composition, place and method of manufacture, so the goods may be approved for export and meet Australian quality standards:
(1) Why is it also necessary for exporters, if they are not the manufacturers and so registered, to register the goods in their name.

(2) How is it possible for anyone other than the manufacturers of the pharmaceutical to supply to the Therapeutic Goods Administration details of formulation, composition, et cetera, with regard to patent and intellectual property, as required by the Therapeutic Goods Administration to register goods for export in their name.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) This provision is not intended to restrict exports but rather to ensure that when exports are undertaken, there is a person in Australia responsible for the action. An Australian resident is required to do this to ensure that there is traceability in the event of recall action; that the exporter and not the manufacturer is responsible for any defects in the product, caused for example by incorrect storage or transportation, and also to provide a specific deterrent to drug counterfeiting of products included in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods.

In addition, without an Australian sponsor for each export action, Australian manufacturers of pharmaceuticals have no knowledge of where their products are being directed, the conditions in which they arrive, and the promotional activity undertaken in regard to those products in the country of sale. Indiscriminate action by third parties involving branded products of Australian manufacturers thus has considerable potential to impact adversely on future exports of that company's products, without that company even being aware that the export had taken place.

Considerations such as these led to the provisions of the Therapeutic Goods Act being drafted to ensure that individual manufacturer's products could not be exported without the company being aware that such action was underway.
(2) By obtaining the details from the manufacturer, under normal commercial arrangements.
Alternatively products can be exported by third parties under an agency arrangement in which the person who exports or arranges the exports does so on behalf of the Australian sponsor.
The export arrangements have worked quite satisfactorily since February 1991, with some 9476 export certificates being issued by the TGA to the end of September 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 28 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Can details be provided of the "Meeting the Challenge" program currently being offered through the Commonwealth Employment Service.
(2) Do the participants in this training program receive an amount of money, depending on their eligibility, in addition to their Job Search Allowance; if so, how much do they receive.
(3) Who is eligible for this program.
(4)(a) When was the program established; and (b) for how long is it likely to run.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) "Meeting the Challenge" is a work preparation course conducted under JOBTRAIN in Western Australia. Each course runs for four weeks and three days. The course includes an Introduction period, Theory/Practical exercises which focus on Personal Development and Career Planning followed by a two week Work Experience placement.
(2) Eligible participants receive Formal Training Assistance which may include:
a living component (equivalent to the Job Search/Newstart/Youth Training Allowance);
access to a range of ancillary allowances to cover additional expenses incurred while in training such as for books and equipment, help with living away from home and fares; and
a training component of $30 a week for trainees over 21 years and all sole parent pensioners.
(3) Eligible participants are those who have been unemployed for 26 weeks or those under the Youth Training Initiative (YTI) who have been unemployed for over 13 weeks.
(4)(a) The pilot "Meeting the Challenge" program was established in July 1995.
(b) The program is contracted to run until June 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 3 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that many dementia-specific residential care units face imminent closure due to lack of funding because of the Government's inflexibility in aged care funding.

(2) Is it a fact that people suffering moderate to severe dementia need high levels of support, yet facilities specifically designed for dementia sufferers receive funding that fails to recognise this.

(3) Is it a fact that the current formulas for aged care funding recognise only the physically frail as requiring such high levels of support and, because of this inflexibility, many dementia-specific residential care units are picking up the financial shortfall themselves in an effort to maintain the support needed to adequately care for people suffering dementia.

(4) Is it a fact that these facilities have now reached a crisis point, with one such unit in Victoria being forced to close and many others at imminent risk of closure because of insufficient funding.

(5) With reference to the fact that, while the Government has recognised the problem and is presently restructuring funding formulas, in the interim many dementia-specific care units are facing the risk of closure: (a) is the Minister aware of this problem; and (b) what steps are being taken to help dementia care units continue to provide the support needed for people suffering dementia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The issue of funding for dementia specific facilities must be placed in context. Dementia specific facilities are one care option for residents with dementia, involving segregation of residents.

Facilities of this type represent around 5% of places available in nursing homes and hostels, and yet 50-80% of residents of nursing homes and hostels generally have some identified cognitive or behavioural deficit.

There are other successful models of care operating across the industry. The common elements of good dementia care are informed management, staff trained in dementia, good care practices and programs and involvement of families. Appropriate physical design is one other factor.

The Government works to actively support all these elements, through funding, training programs and research. Over the last decade, we have substantially increased funding for hostels, including dementia specific hostels, from $40 million to $310 million per year. Personal care funding, which covers the care needs of people with dementia, has tripled in real terms.

(3) The current formula, used to determine aged care funding, does take account of care needs associated with cognitive deficits and challenging behaviours, as well physical frailty. Nevertheless, we are looking at how well the residential care classification and funding systems identifies the care needs of people with very challenging behaviours. (See also (5)).
(4) I am not aware of any facilities which have closed; I understand one facility in Victoria is in the process of converting to a general hostel.

(5) I am aware, that some operators of dementia specific facilities report that they are having difficulties within current funding arrangements. Part of the problem appears to be that some dementia specific facilities, that are part of a wider complex, are isolated from the broader infrastructure of the organisation and run as a separate cost centre. This approach can lead to significant inefficiencies.

Some other organisations that have chosen to include dementia specific units within the overall structure of a general aged care facility have been able to provide an excellent service within current funding arrangements.

I have, however, given a firm commitment to change the existing resident classification and funding arrangements in the next Budget to ensure better identification and funding of the care of people with very challenging behaviours and in particular for those who are also ambulant.

In making such changes, however, the Government is strongly committed to an equitable funding solution. This means ensuring that the residential care classification and funding systems operate in such a way that the increasing needs of people with dementia can be met in the full range of residential services, including dementia specific facilities.

I have recently met with representatives of the Uniting Church's Community Services Australia, and I have said I am willing to fund an immediate management review to assist a small number of services Community Services Australia judge to be facing the greatest pressure. The reviews will identify both underlying structural issues, which need to be addressed in addition to funding relativities, and options which might assist these facilities to manage in the period between now and the Budget.

These options could encompass changed management and infrastructure arrangements including cross-subsidisation and admission and discharge criteria. I have also offered to provide some finite, time limited funding in a small number of the most pressing cases to assist facilities to manage while the review is undertaken.
A similar offer is being made to other organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 9 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that the Commonwealth Government established a scientific committee to determine the validity of the road, river and stream reserve systems in Western Australian forests.

(2) Is it a fact that the Commonwealth has established as a `rule of thumb' that linear reserve systems, which are less than 400 metres in width, will not be accredited under the Commonwealth guidelines for national reserve criteria.
(3)(a) Who established this rule of thumb guideline; and (b) when and to which State was the existence of this guideline communicated.

(4) Is it a fact that Victoria has an extensive system of non-statutory linear reserves, a large proportion of which are less than 400 metres in width, and that these reserves, in some major forest types, comprise a substantial proportion of the reserve system which has been accredited as complying with the national reserve criteria by the Commonwealth.
(5) What proportion of the reserve systems in each forest type, which have been accredited by the Commonwealth in Victoria, comprise linear reserves which are less than 400 metres.
(6) Does the Commonwealth propose to establish a scientific committee to review the validity of these reserve systems according to the Commonwealth criteria; if not, why not.
(7) Has the Commonwealth credited, or does it propose to credit, any linear reserve systems which are less than 400 metres in width in Tasmania or New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The following information has been provided by the Forests Task Force within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet
(1) Yes.

(2) The `rule of thumb' (strips less than 400 metres not to be accredited) was generally adopted for consideration of linear reserves, but with the caveat that individual circumstances would need to be closely examined (it may, for instance, only be possible to represent certain forest types in this way). In Tasmania the Commonwealth has also accepted inclusion of narrow linear reserves where exclusion of these reserves is not technically possible and their contribution is minor (12% of the total reserve system).

(3) (a) The `rule of thumb' was developed by technical officers from a number of Commonwealth agencies involved in the Deferred Forests Assessment (DFA) process. (b) This position was made clear to Victoria and Tasmania during DFA negotiations. Western Australia was informed in writing after exchange of correspondence on the issue.

(4) Victoria has an extensive system of non-statutory reserves. However, these comprise a range of areas of different shapes that had been set aside from logging for specific conservation purposes. These areas do include some linear connecting corridors. In contrast, the non-statutory forest reserves in WA consist predominantly of narrow linear road river and stream reserves, and these comprise a substantial proportion of the total reservation area (e.g. 20% of reserved Jarrah is in linear strips and stream buffers).

Consistent with Tasmania and New South Wales, Victoria has taken a different approach to deferred forests areas than Western Australia. Victoria will protect all areas outside an agreed Wood Utilisation Plan pending the conclusion of Regional Forest Agreements. Accordingly, the DFAs in Victoria are very large and the issue of administration reserves is of relatively little significance. Since Western Australia has chosen to proceed with the approach of tightly defined deferred forest areas designed to meet no more than the shortfall in reservation levels, the Commonwealth has needed to ensure that only those administrative reserves that could clearly contribute to a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system are counted for the purposes of the DFA.

(5) In the State wide analysis of 19 broad forest types, administration reserves were discussed in relation to one forest type (lowland forest) which was 13% protected in formal reserves and 3% protected in special protection zones which included linear components. As outlined in the response to part four of the question, the issue of linear reserves which were less than 400 metres is of lesser importance in Victoria because of the approach used in the DFA process.

(6) No, for reasons outlined in parts four and five of the question. However, the contribution of linear reserves will be considered by governments in more detail in the Comprehensive Regional Assessments process.

(7) Linear reserves were not an issue in the Tasmanian DFA process. In that State only 1-2% of all reserves are narrow linear strips. Linear reserves of less than 400 metres width were not a part of the New South Wales DFA process.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Communications and the Arts: Land Access Code

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 18 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the land access code required to be developed by the Government under the Telecommunications Act 1991 now being developed.
(2) If the land access code has been developed, when will the code be tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The land access code is currently being developed.
(2) I would expect that the code would be available for tabling in the autumn sittings of 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the future plans for the 1st Military Hospital at Yeronga, Brisbane.
(2) Is it a fact that the hospital will be relocated to the Army base at Enoggera; if so, when.
(3)(a) If the hospital is relocated, what will the department do with the existing site; and
(b) will the vacated site be sold; if so, for what purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) 1 Military Hospital and the Medical Centre at Enoggera will amalgamate with 2nd Field Hospital and relocate to Enoggera.
(2) Yes, in December 1996.

(3)(a)&(b) With the relocation of 1 Military Hospital, Defence will have no further use for the property and will seek to dispose of it. The consideration of the future use of the property will be progressed in consultation with State and local planning authorities and other interested agencies.
